Sec. 2-31. - Meetings. 
(a)  The board of commissioners shall hold regular meetings on the second Tuesday of each month at 2:00 p.m., unless otherwise ordered by the board. 
(b)  Special meetings may be held upon call by the chairman of the board of commissioners or any three members. Due notice of such meetings shall be in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1(d). 
(c)  Meetings shall be held in the board of commissioners' meeting room, Sumter County Courthouse, Americus, Georgia. 
Sec. 2-32. - Agenda. 
There shall be a written agenda prepared prior to each board meeting. Persons who desire to address the members of the board at a meeting shall notify the clerk of the board of commissioners by the close of business on the Thursday preceding the next meeting. The chairman of the board of commissioners shall have the discretion to recognize any member of the public desiring to address the board. 
Sec. 2-33. - Parliamentary procedure. 
The proceedings of the board of commissioners shall be governed by Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, provided such is not inconsistent with any special rules of the board of commissioners and this Code. 
(Ord. of 1-18-2011) 
Secs. 2-34—2-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Related laws reference— Payroll development authority, art. IV. 
Cross reference— Any ordinance fixing the salary of any county officer or employee saved from repeal, § 1-6(4); dog control officer, § 14-35; office of the county emergency management director, § 30-32. 
State Law reference— Fair Employment Practices Act of 1978, O.C.G.A. § 45-19-20 et seq.; random drug testing of state employees in high-risk jobs, O.C.G.A. § 45-20-90 et seq.; municipal or county governments not to require residence as condition of employment, O.C.G.A. § 45-2-5; Public Employee Hazardous Chemical Protection and Right to Know Act of 1988, O.C.G.A. § 45-22-1 et seq.; Drug-Free Public Work Force Act of 1990, O.C.G.A. § 45-23-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-66. - Purpose. 
The general purpose of this article is to establish a system of personnel administration that meets the legal and administrative needs of the county. This system shall be consistent with the following merit principles: 
(1)  Recruiting, selecting and advancing employees on the basis of their relative ability, knowledge and skills, including open competition of qualified applicants for initial appointments. 
(2)  Establishing pay rates consistent with the principle of providing comparable pay for comparable work. 
(3)  Training employees, as needed, to assure high-quality performance. 
(4)  Training employees on the basis of the adequacy of their performance, correcting inadequate performance, and separating employees whose inadequate performance cannot be corrected. 
(5)  Assuring fair treatment of applicants and employees in all aspects of personnel administration without regard to political affiliation, race, color, national origin, sex, age, religion or handicapped status. 
(6)  Establishing a procedure for the presentation and adjustment of employee grievances based on alleged inequitable treatment because of some conditions of their employment or based on alleged discrimination because of race, color, national origin, sex, age, religion or handicapped status. 
(7)  Assuring employers protection against partisan political coercion and prohibiting their use of official authority for interfering with or affecting the results of an election or the nomination for an office. 
(Ord. of 2-13-90, art. I) 
Sec. 2-67. - Personnel system. 
This personnel system shall apply to all employees of the county, except: 
(1)  Members of the county commission and their elected positions. 
(2)  Members of appointed or elected boards and commissions, judges and the county attorney. 
(3)  Persons employed to make or conduct a temporary and special inquiry, investigation or examination on behalf of the county commission or a committee thereof. 
(4)  Temporary or provisional positions unless specifically covered by action of the county commission. 
(5)  Volunteer personnel who receive no regular compensation from the county. 
(Ord. of 2-13-90, art. II) 
Sec. 2-68. - Administration. 
(a)  The county administrator (hereinafter identified as CA) shall serve as personnel officer. The CA shall have full responsibility for all administrative and technical activities of the personnel system. 
(b)  The county commission shall adopt by resolution personnel policies, which shall have the force and effect of law and which may be amended by a three-fifths vote of the county commission. As needed, the CA shall submit recommendations for revised or additional personnel policies for presentation to and consideration by the county commission. 
(Ord. of 2-13-90, art. III; Ord. of 11-13-18(3), § 1) 
Sec. 2-69. - Grievance procedures. 
(a)  A grievance is any dispute concerning the interpretation or application of this article; or the personnel policies governing personnel practices or working conditions; or a decision relative to any disciplinary action, dismissal, demotion or a charge of discrimination. 
(b)  Grievances shall be processed in accordance with procedures established by the personnel policies. 
(Ord. of 2-13-90, art. IV) 
Sec. 2-70. - Political activity. 
Employees of the county are encouraged to exercise their right to vote; but no employee shall make use of county time or equipment to aid a political candidate, political party or political cause, or use a county position to persuade, coerce or intimidate any person in the interest of a political candidate, political party or political cause. Federally funded positions are subject to the Hatch Act. 
(Ord. of 2-13-90, art. V) 
Sec. 2-71. - Employment of relatives. 
No hiring authority shall appoint or employ any person who is a member of his immediate family to a position under his supervision nor within his department. 
(Ord. of 2-13-90, art. VI) 
Sec. 2-72. - Equal employment opportunity guaranteed. 
All applicants for positions and employees of the county shall be assured of fair and equitable treatment in all aspects of personnel administration. Any applicant or employee who alleges discrimination in any personnel transaction shall have the right to counsel with the CA. If the claim is not satisfactorily resolved, they may exercise the right of an appeal to the county commission as the final authority. 
(Ord. of 2-13-90, art. VII; Ord. of 11-13-18(3), § 1) 
Sec. 2-73. - Unlawful acts prohibited. 
In the application procedure no person shall give false information; no person shall give or receive money, service or other valuable consideration; and no employee shall act in a manner obstructing or unduly benefiting an applicant's prospects for appointment or promotion. 
(Ord. of 2-13-90, art. VIII) 
Sec. 2-74. - Penalties. 
Any person who willfully violates any provision of this article or of the personnel policies established under this article may have one of the following judgments rendered: 
(1)  Dismissal from county service and forfeiture of annual and sick leave or other employee benefits as approved by the county commission. 
(2)  Ineligibility for appointment to or employment in a position in the county service for the period of time stipulated in the personnel policies. 
(3)  Suspension for a period of time as stipulated by the personnel policies. 
(4)  Such other appropriate action as the board of commissioners may deem appropriate. 
(Ord. of 2-13-90, art. IX) 
Sec. 2-75. - Status of present employees. 
(a)  Employees having served in their current positions for six months or more prior to adoption of the personnel policies shall have permanent status, except those employees hired as temporary employees. Employees with less than six months' continuous employment in their current positions shall serve a probationary period as defined in the policies. 
(b)  If a sworn officer has not successfully completed state mandated training within the initial six months of employment, the probationary period will be extended. 
(Ord. of 2-13-90, art. X) 
Sec. 2-76. - At-will employment. 
All employees employed by the board of commissioners are employed as at-will employees, and no employee is employed under an employment contract. All employees may be terminated at the will of the board of commissioners and in conformity with this article. 
(Ord. of 2-13-90, art. XII) 
Sec. 2-77. - Claims against employees. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Claim includes all claims presented against an employee prior to institution of a proceeding. 
Employee means the members of the governing body of the county, employees of the county, elected or appointed county officers and their appointees and employees, including appointed members of county commissions, past, present, and future. The term "employee" does not include employees of the county board of health, the livestock authority, the recreational authority, or the airport authority. 
Proceeding includes any matter of a civil nature in or before any court or agency of this state or of any other state or of the United States. 
(b)  Exclusions. There is excluded further from the operation of this section any claim or proceeding as to which insurance is provided by the county. 
(c)  Construction. Nothing contained in this section shall be deemed to constitute any waiver, by the county or by any employee, of the governmental immunity afforded it under the constitution and laws of the state. The county and its employees specifically reserve the right to assert their immunity prior to the entry of judgment in any claim or proceeding, and subsection (f) shall not be applicable to require the county or any employee to pay any sums based on claims from which the county and its employees are immune. Nothing contained herein shall be interpreted in any way to reduce or eliminate the rights of any employee of the county against any other party. 
(d)  Defense of employees. Whenever any claim is made or proceeding is brought against any employee, either against him asserting personal liability for damages arising out of the performances of his duties or in any way connected therewith, whether based on negligence, violation of contract rights or violation of civil, constitutional, common law or other statutory rights, whether federal, state or local, the county shall, upon his written request, provide for his defense unless otherwise limited by the terms of this section. The board of commissioners of the county may decline defense of an employee or decline payment of a claim against an employee if the employee has failed to give notice in writing of any claim or proceeding to the board within 30 days after the employee has notice of a claim or if the employee has failed to give such notice within five days after service of a proceeding. 
(e)  Grounds for refusal of defense. 
(1)  The county shall refuse to provide the defense of a claim or proceeding brought against an employee if it determines that: 
a.  The act or omission did not arise out of and in the course of his employment. 
b.  The employee acted or failed to act because of actual or intentional misconduct, fraud, corruption, malice or in bad faith. 
c.  The proceeding is a criminal prosecution. 
d.  Provisions of a defense against the claim or proceeding would not be in the best interest of the county. 
e.  The employee acts or fails to act as a result of, or at a time when, the employee's own self-indulgence substantially impaired the employee's judgment (as, for example, an officer or employee who causes damage or injury while intoxicated or under the influence of drugs while on the job). 
f.  The employee acts or fails to act, except in emergencies or the existence of extenuating circumstances, directly contrary to advice of the county attorney or safety personnel. 
g.  The employee acts or fails to act in such manner as to constitute a criminal act (as, for example, misappropriation of property or funds). 
h.  The employee fails to cooperate in the defense of the claim or proceeding. 
i.  The employee acted or failed to act in willful disregard of county policy or specific instructions of the employee's supervisor. 
(2)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the county from providing a defense against a claim or proceeding where there is a conflict of interest between one employee or group of employees of the county as compared with another employee or group of employees. 
(3)  The determinations required by subsection (1) of this subsection (e) shall be made by the board of commissioners of the county. The commissioners will make this decision upon the advice of the county administrator, the county attorney, and department heads, and upon any internal investigation of the claim or proceeding. The commissioners may refuse at any time, prior to, or after approval of assumption of the defense, to provide for the defense of an employee if it is determined that any of the grounds for refusal set forth in this section exists. 
(4)  Upon approval of the defense of a claim or proceeding against an employee, the board of commissioners of the county shall refer the matter to the county attorney for disposition. In the event two or more employees or groups of employees are involved, and the interest of one employee or group of employees conflict with the interest of another employee or group of employees, then and in such event, the board of commissioners of the county shall specify which employee or group of employees shall be represented by the county attorney and shall authorize other employees or groups of employees to employ counsel at the expense of the county; provided, however that the selection and compensation of such other counsel shall be subject to the prior approval by the board of commissioners of the county. 
(f)  Payment of judgments, settlement of claims. 
(1)  Where defense of a claim or proceeding against an employee is provided by this section, all final judgments awarded in courts of competent jurisdiction against the employee in proceedings to which this section applied or any amount payable under any settlement of such proceeding or of claims in accordance with this section shall be paid by the county as hereinafter provided. All compromises of claims or proceedings governed by this section shall be submitted to the board of commissioners of the county for its prior approval. 
(2)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, payment of judgments and claims shall be limited as follows: 
a.  No sum will be paid where the employee's liability is based on a discretionary act, and the county and the employee reserve the right to assert all governmental and sovereign immunity in defense of such claims. Payment of judgments and claims pursuant to this section shall be made only where liability is based upon a ministerial act of the employee. It is the intent of this section to provide for the payment of claims or judgments only where the defense of sovereign or governmental immunity may not be asserted initially as a defense to the claim or proceeding. 
b.  No sum will be paid in any one claim or proceeding on behalf of any employee in excess of $50.00 in the case of any claim or claims brought by one claimant, and $200.00 for any number of claims of numerous claimants arising out of the same occurrence. 
c.  No sum will be paid under the provisions of this section for punitive or exemplary damages. 
d.  No sum shall be paid under the provisions of this section unless the claimant unconditionally releases the employee and the county from any and all claims, causes of action or judgment arising out of the subject claim or proceeding. 
e.  There is excluded further from the operation of this section any claim or proceeding as to which insurance is provided by the county. There is further excluded from the operation of this division any claim or proceeding as to which the county has, by resolution or otherwise, provided for the payment and defense of claims or proceedings arising from the ownership, use or maintenance of county motor vehicles. 
(Ord. of 12-19-00, §§ 1—6) 
Secs. 2-78—2-110. - Reserved.

DIVISION 3. - DISASTER RECOVERY COMMISSION[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Civil emergencies, ch. 30. 

Sec. 2-156. - Created. 
A disaster recovery commission is created for the purpose of assisting the City of Americus and County of Sumter in establishing community-wide policies for the purpose of decreasing the long term effects of disasters and in assisting with the recovery process of disasters in the city and county and for the purpose of promoting and establishing disaster recovery programs for the city and county. 
(Res. of 4-20-95, § I) 
Sec. 2-157. - Name. 
The name of the disaster recovery commission shall be Sumter County Disaster Recovery Commission. 
(Res. of 4-20-95, § II) 
Sec. 2-158. - Duties. 
The duties of the disaster recovery commission shall be: 
(1)  To promote public interest and participation in the restoration efforts following disasters that occur within or that touch on the City of Americus and the County of Sumter; 
(2)  To initiate, plan, direct and coordinate programs for assisting disaster recovery for the community on a sustainable basis; 
(3)  To implement and maintain a community disaster recovery system; 
(4)  To study, investigate and develop plans for improving the health, sanitation, safety and security of the city and the county by correcting disaster-caused damage to the streets, highways, alleys, rivers and stream banks, lots, yards and other similar places in the city and county; 
(5)  To aid in the reconstruction and restoration of damaged homes by the removal and elimination of trash and other debris resulting from disasters; 
(6)  To encourage community-wide volunteer efforts in disaster recovery in the city and county; 
(7)  To protect local citizens from unscrupulous individuals and firms who would seek to take advantage of the vulnerability of citizens following disasters; 
(8)  To assist disaster victims with their recovery process, including decision making and money management skills; 
(9)  To advise and recommend plans to other agencies of the city and county for the mitigation and recovery process; and 
(10)  Otherwise to promote public interest in the general improvement of the environment of the city and the county. 
Nothing in this section shall be construed to abridge or change the powers and duties of other commissions, departments, boards and like agencies of the city and the county. 
(Res. of 4-20-95, § III) 
Sec. 2-159. - Authority. 
In order to perform the duties prescribed in section 2-158, the disaster recovery commission shall have the following authority to: 
(1)  Adopt bylaws to facilitate the attainment of its purpose and functions; 
(2)  Initiate, plan, direct and coordinate community-wide efforts to achieve its goal; 
(3)  Work with the county emergency management agency, the Red Cross, local churches, and all organizations willing to assist in the task of the commission; 
(4)  Solicit and accept donations and appropriations of money, services, products, property and facilities for expenditure and use by the commission for the accomplishment of its objectives; 
(5)  Employ, pay and terminate the employment of such staff as may be required for the fulfillment of commission purposes; 
(6)  Recruit and utilize volunteers and organizations from within and without the county to assist the commission in attaining its purpose and functions; and 
(7)  Make recommendations to city and county governing bodies as well as to the private sector regarding measures which it deems necessary to accomplish its objectives. 
(Res. of 4-20-95, § IV) 
Sec. 2-160. - Members. 
(a)  The disaster recovery commission shall consist of not more than 22 members who shall be residents of the City of Americus or the county and who shall serve without pay. Nine of the members shall be appointed by the mayor and city council of the city, and nine members shall be appointed by the board of commissioners of the county. One from each body shall, if possible, be a citizen who was directly affected by a disaster of the types for which the commission is activated to work. 
(b)  In addition to the appointed members of the commission, the county administrators of both the city and county, the emergency management agent, and the director of the city-county chapter of the American Red Cross shall serve as nonvoting ex officio members of the commission and shall be counted a part of the commission membership. Ex officio members each may designate another individual to serve in their stead. Each substitute must have the authority to act on behalf of the agency or office which he represents. 
(Res. of 4-20-95, § V; Ord. of 11-13-18(3), § 1) 
Sec. 2-161. - Terms of office. 
The terms of office of the members of the disaster recovery commission shall generally be for three years each. The terms of the initial members shall be staggered. Members whose terms have expired shall continue as members until their successors shall have been appointed. The appropriate governing authority shall fill each vacancy from a list of two names submitted by the commission. 
(Res. of 4-20-95, § VI) 
Sec. 2-162. - Officers. 
The disaster recovery commission shall elect from its membership a chairman and such other officers as may be desired. Officers shall be elected on a calendar year basis for a term of two years but may be reelected for succeeding terms. 
(Res. of 4-20-95, § VII) 
Sec. 2-163. - Powers. 
The disaster recovery commission shall have the power to receive and disburse funds within the limitations placed on such appropriations, gifts and grants as are given to it, and in connection with projects or undertakings previously approved under the terms of section 2-158. Within the same limitation, the commission shall be empowered to contract with any private or public agency to the extent required for its proper operation and to create and contract with not-for-profit corporations. The commission shall keep such records as will enable it to make such reports and accounting as from time to time are requested by the city and/or the county, and the same shall be subject to verification and examination by auditors of the city and/or county. Any project or undertaking begun by the commission shall be terminated at any time upon the decision of either the board of commissioners of the county or the mayor and city council of the city that the continuance thereof is not in the public interest. 
(Res. of 4-20-95, § VIII) 
Sec. 2-164. - Active, inactive status. 
The nature of the disaster recovery commission being disaster recovery, and such disasters occurring at infrequent intervals, the length of time needed for recovery from the effects of such disasters differing, depending on the extent and type of disaster, the commission shall have periods of "active status" and "inactive status." During a period of inactive status, the commission and its membership shall be dormant, and any membership can be automatically extended for one term of service. During a period of inactive status, the commission would meet annually for purposes of coordinating with the ex officio members and participation in any training in disaster relief as would be deemed appropriate. Active status shall be immediately initiated upon the declaration of a disaster within the confines of the county, by joint resolution of the city council and county board of commissioners, or by declaration of active status by the county emergency management agent. 
(Res. of 4-20-95, § IX) 
Secs. 2-165—2-185. - Reserved.
