DIVISION 6. - INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY 

Sec. 2-236. - Intent. 
It is the intention of the board of commissioners to participate in the operation and function of the Sumter County Industrial Development Authority and by this division the board of commissioners does hereby activate the Sumter County Industrial Development Authority. 
(Res. of 8-23-95) 
Sec. 2-237. - Rights of county. 
By the enactment of this division, the board of commissioners is vested with the right to use, exercise and enjoy all of the provisions granted to them through the act creating the Sumter County Industrial Development Authority. 
(Res. of 8-23-95) 
Secs. 2-238—2-270. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - JOINT HOSPITAL AUTHORITY 

Sec. 2-271. - Participating units. 
All of the following counties and municipalities in the state listed in the table below (individually, a "participating unit," and collectively, the "participating units") have determined to act together for the creation of a joint hospital authority pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 31-7-70 et seq., and have acted, are acting, or will act together to create the joint hospital authority referred to in this division by having each of their respective governing bodies duly adopt the resolution from which this division derives. 
Names of Participating Units 
(1)  Ben Hill County 
(2)  Bibb County 
(3)  Bulloch County 
(4)  Calhoun County 
(5)  Chatham County 
(6)  Clinch County 
(7)  Coffee County 
(8)  Colquitt County 
(9)  Crisp County 
(10)  Decatur County 
(11)  City of Donalsonville 
(12)  Dougherty County 
(13)  Jasper County 
(14)  Jeff Davis County 
(15)  Miller County 
(16)  Thomas County 
(17)  Tift County 
(18)  Sumter County 
(Res. of 11- -85) 
Sec. 2-272. - Findings. 
There is an urgent, existing and future need for a joint hospital authority to function within an area of operation, which includes all of the area within the boundaries of all of the participating units (collectively, the "area of operation") to provide needed hospital and other health care facilities to citizens of the state within the area of operation and otherwise to promote the public purposes of O.C.G.A. § 31-7-70 et seq. and the general welfare of the citizens of the state. 
(Res. of 11- -85, § 1) 
Sec. 2-273. - Created, activated. 
There is hereby created and activated a public body corporate and politic and a public corporation known as the "South Georgia Hospital Authority" (the "authority") pursuant to the power granted by the general assembly to counties and municipalities acting together to so create a joint hospital authority pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 31-7-72(d). The authority hereby created and activated shall have all the powers granted to hospital authorities under O.C.G.A. § 31-7-70 et seq. The principal office of the authority initially shall be located in the City of Macon, Georgia, and such principal office may be changed by the authority from time to time. 
(Res. of 11- -85, § 2) 
Sec. 2-274. - Initial members of board of trustees. 
There shall be 14 members of the initial board of trustees of the authority, each of whom shall be a resident of the participating unit that appointed them. The terms of the initial members of the board of trustees shall be staggered. 
(Res. of 11- -85, § 3) 
Sec. 2-275. - Filling of vacancies. 
(a)  Subsequent appointments of members to fill vacancies on the membership of the board of trustees of the authority that occur for any reason for either an unexpired term or a new full term of office shall be made in the following manner. 
(1)  First, the governing body of the particular participating unit that originally nominated the initial member appointed pursuant to this division whose office has become vacant, or any successor to such initial member whose office shall have become vacant, shall submit to the board of trustees a list of three eligible persons who reside in the particular nominating participating unit. 
(2)  Second, the board of trustees at its next regular meeting shall either select one of the three persons named in such list as a member of the authority to fill the vacancy or decline to select any of the persons named on the list. 
(3)  Third, if the board of trustees declines to select any of the persons named on the list, it shall notify the governing body of the particular nominating participating unit; and upon receipt of such notice, the governing body of the particular nominating participating unit shall submit a second list of three eligible persons, no one of whom was named on the first list, to the board of trustees, and the board of trustees at its next regular meeting after receipt of the second list shall select one of the three persons named on the second list as a member of the authority to fill the vacancy. 
(b)  Whenever an appointment to fill a vacancy on the board of trustees of the authority is made, either for an unexpired term or a full term, consideration shall be given by the applicable nominating participating unit in nominating proposed members and by the board of trustees in selecting members as to whether a licensed doctor of medicine or registered nurse currently serves on the authority. If no licensed doctor of medicine or registered nurse currently serves on the authority, consideration shall be given to the nomination and choice of a licensed doctor of medicine or a registered nurse to fill such vacancy. 
(c)  Any member appointed to the authority to fill the unexpired initial term of one of the initial members of the authority named in this division shall be appointed to serve a term of office equal in length to the remainder of the initial term of office of such person's predecessor in office. Any member appointed to the authority to fill a vacancy caused by the expiration of an initial or subsequent full term of office shall be appointed to serve a term of office equal in length to four years. If for any reason at the end of any term of office of any member of the authority, a successor thereto shall not have been elected, the member whose term of office shall have expired shall continue to hold office until such member's successor shall have been appointed. 
(Res. of 11- -85, § 4) 
Sec. 2-276. - Organization. 
The board of trustees of the authority shall organize itself, carry out its duties and responsibilities, and exercise its powers and prerogatives in accordance with the terms and provisions of O.C.G.A. § 31-7-70 et seq. 
(Res. of 11- -85, § 5) 
Sec. 2-277. - Supplemental to other hospital authorities. 
The hospital authority created by this division is intended to be in addition to and supplemental to any existing local hospital authorities created and activated under O.C.G.A. § 31-7-70 et seq. in any of the participating units and is not intended in any way to impair any rights, powers or responsibilities of any such existing local hospital authorities. 
(Res. of 11- -85, § 6) 
Sec. 2-278. - Resolution, effective upon adoption. 
The resolution on which this division is based shall become effective immediately upon its adoption by all of the governing bodies of all of the participating units named in this division, each of whom may consider the adoption of the resolution on which this division is based at the same time or at different times. After the date on which all of the governing bodies of all of the participating units shall have adopted the resolution on which this division is based, the authority shall be deemed to be fully created, activated, and existing under O.C.G.A. § 31-7-70 et seq. Once the resolution on which this division is based shall have been duly adopted by all of the governing bodies of all of the participating units, the resolution on which this division is based shall be executed by all of such governing bodies of all of the participating units in a single counterpart and shall be dated its effective date, which effective date shall be the last date on which a governing body of a participating unit shall have adopted the resolution on which this division is based. 
(Res. of 11- -85, § 8) 
Sec. 2-279. - Failure of participating unit to adopt enabling legislation. 
Notwithstanding any provision of this division to the contrary, if for any reason any of the governing bodies of any of the participating units named in the resolution on which this division is based shall have failed to adopt the resolution on which this division is based by November 19, 1985, the resolution on which this division is based shall be deemed to be amended and modified, without further action by any of the governing bodies of the participating units, to exclude from the list of the original named participating units any such originally named participating unit that shall have so failed to adopt the resolution on which this division is based and to exclude from the list of the original named members of the board of trustees of the authority any member of the board of trustees shown to have been nominated by any such participating unit that shall have so failed to adopt the resolution on which this division is based; and except for such exclusions, the resolution on which this division is based shall otherwise be deemed to be of full force and effect. If the contingency contemplated by this section occurs, the governing bodies of the remaining approving participating units shall be authorized to execute a conformed counterpart of the resolution on which this division is based that deletes reference to any such original named participating unit (and any member of the board of trustees nominated by such participating unit) that shall have failed so to adopt the resolution on which this division is based by November 19, 1985. 
(Res. of 11- -85, § 9) 
Secs. 2-280—2-300. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - HOSPITAL AUTHORITY 

Sec. 2-301. - Need. 
Upon an investigation of the conditions with reference to the preservation of health in the county, there is an actual need for a hospital authority throughout Sumter County, Georgia, to function in both Sumter County and the City of Americus. 
(Res. of 6-3-48) 
Sec. 2-302. - Created. 
There is now, by virtue of this division pursuant to the law of the state, created for the county, including the City of Americus, a hospital authority, which will be officially known hereafter as, "Americus and Sumter County Hospital Authority." 
(Res. of 6-3-48) 
Sec. 2-303. - Trustees. 
In order to properly operate the hospital, which will be governed by the hospital authority, there shall be nine trustees, five of whom shall be appointed by the board of commissioners of the county from different sections of the county, and four of whom shall be appointed by the mayor and city council of the city. 
(Res. of 6-3-48) 
Sec. 2-304. - Election of trustees. 
The initial county trustees of the hospital authority shall be elected for staggered terms of two years. All of the trustees shall act with the four trustees to be elected by the mayor and city council and shall continue to act as such until their successors are elected and qualified. Outside of the staggered initial election, all of the trustees elected shall serve for a period of two years, and their terms as trustee shall be for a period of two years. 
(Res. of 6-3-48) 
Sec. 2-305. - Qualifications of trustees. 
All of the trustees to serve for the hospital authority shall be active, experienced businessmen. One of the five trustees or members of the Americus-Sumter County Hospital Authority to be appointed by the board of commissioners of the county shall be allowed to be a licensed physician or surgeon. 
(Res. of 6-3-48; Res. of 12-27-84) 
Secs. 2-306—2-350. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - COUNTY ISSUED GOVERNMENT PURCHASING CARDS AND CREDIT CARDS 

Sec. 2-351. - Intent and scope. 
This article is intended to comply with O.C.G.A. § 36-80-24 regarding the use of county issued government purchasing cards and credit cards. 
(Ord. of 12-15-15(1)) 
Sec. 2-352. - Definitions. 
The below terms shall be defined as follows: 
Authorized elected official means an elected official designated by public vote of the Sumter County Board of Commissioners to receive a purchasing card and/or credit card issued by the county. 
Card administrator means the purchasing card and credit card administrator designated by the Sumter County Board of Commissioners. 
County means Sumter County and/or the board of commissioners of said county. 
County purchasing card, county p-card, or county credit card means a financial transaction card issued by any business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, used by a county official to purchase goods, services, and other things of value on behalf of the county. 
Financial transaction card means an instrument or device as the term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-9-30(5). 
User agreement means the required agreement between the board of commissioners and the authorized elected officials which governs and restricts the use of a county purchasing card and/or credit card. 
(Ord. of 12-15-15(1)) 
Sec. 2-353. - Designated elected officials. 
(a)  The Sumter County Board of Commissioners, in its discretion, may authorize specific elected officials to use a county purchasing card and/or credit card by adoption of a resolution in a public meeting. 
(b)  No authorized elected official may use a county purchasing card or credit card until and unless said official has executed the county's purchasing card and credit card user agreement. 
(c)  The county will not make payment to any business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, for amounts charged by an elected official to any purchasing cards or credit cards issued by the county's governing authority that are not issued in compliance with this article or for any purchases on any such cards that are not authorized by this article. 
(Ord. of 12-15-15(1)) 
Sec. 2-354. - Card administrator. 
The board of commissioners shall designate a county purchasing card and credit card administrator (hereafter "card administrator"). The card administrator shall: 
(1)  Manage county issued purchasing cards and credit cards; 
(2)  Serve as the main point of contact for all county purchasing card and credit card issues; 
(3)  Serve as liaison to the elected officials authorized to use a purchasing card and/or credit card and their staff, as well as to the issuer of any such purchasing card or credit card; 
(4)  Provide training on card policies and procedures to the elected officials authorized to use a purchasing card and/or credit card and their staff; 
(5)  Develop internal procedures to ensure timely payment of cards; 
(6)  Assist authorized elected officials to dispute transactions when necessary; 
(7)  Establish internal procedures to ensure compliance with this article, county procurement ordinances and policies, county purchasing card and credit card user agreements, applicable agreements with the business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, issuing card, and state law, specifically, O.C.G.A. §§ 16-9-37 and 36-80-24; 
(8)  Document internal controls, audits and other measures to prevent and detect misuse or abuse of the cards; 
(9)  Audit and reconcile transactions monthly; and 
(10)  Maintain records for at least seven years or as otherwise provided by the county's record retention policy. 
(Ord. of 12-15-15(1)) 
Sec. 2-355. - Use of cards. 
(a)  Authorized purchases. 
(1)  County purchase cards and credit cards may be used to purchase only goods and services directly related to the public duties of the authorized elected official. All purchases are subject to the terms of this and all other ordinances, the county purchasing card and credit card user agreement, the county's financial policies, and the adopted budget. 
(2)  Only authorized elected officials may use a county purchase card and/or credit card for purchases or payments. The cards and their use are not transferrable to employees. The authorized elected official shall use care to ensure that others do not have access to the card account number, expiration date, and security code. 
(3)  Unless otherwise approved by the governing authority or established in the county purchasing card and credit card user agreement, the card limits are as follows: 
a.  Per transaction: $750.00. 
b.  Per month: $3,000.00. 
(b)  Unauthorized purchases. County purchasing cards and credit cards shall not be used for goods and services not directly related to the official responsibilities of the authorized elected official. Additionally, cards shall not be used to avoid compliance with the county's purchasing ordinances and procedures, to purchase goods and services that are not approved in the county's budget, to purchase goods and services exceeding the per transaction or per month limit, or to make purchases not in compliance with the county purchasing card and credit card user agreement. 
(c)  Receipts and documentation. Receipts, invoices and other supporting documentation of all purchases made with a county purchasing card or credit card shall be obtained and maintained by the authorized county elected official for five years or as otherwise provided by the county's record retention policy. If an original or duplicate cannot be produced, a sworn affidavit of the authorized elected official may be substituted. The documentation must include the supplier or merchant information (i.e., name and location), quantity, description, unit price, total price, price paid without sales tax, and an explanation of the purchase sufficient to show that the expense was in the performance of official county duties. 
(d)  Public records. All receipts, statements, and other documentation of purchases are public records subject to the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70 et seq. 
(Ord. of 12-15-15(1)) 
Sec. 2-356. - Review of purchases and audit. 
(a)  Compliance. Proper documentation of purchases, internal controls, and other measures prevent and allow detection of misuse or abuse of county issued purchase cards and credit cards. Authorized elected officials and staff who make purchases and process payments under this program shall comply with the procedures established in this article. 
(b)  Review of purchases. All purchases shall be reviewed according to the following procedure: No later than 15 days after each purchase, authorized elected officials shall submit the receipt therefore to the card administrator or other person designated by the card administrator with a description of the nature of the purchase. Before payment may be issued, the card administrator shall verify that the purchase is in compliance with this article and the county's financial policies. 
(c)  Audits. The card administrator shall perform an annual review of the card program to ensure adequacy of internal policies and procedures, cardholder spending limits, monthly reconciliation procedures, and documentation for transactions. Elected officials and staff shall cooperate with such review. 
(Ord. of 12-15-15(1)) 
Sec. 2-357. - Violations. 
(a)  An elected official shall reimburse the county for any purchases made with a county issued purchase card or credit card in violation of this article or the user agreement. 
(b)  In the discretion of the county governing authority, failure to comply with the procedures outlined in this article may result in one or more of the following: 
(1)  A warning; 
(2)  Suspension of the elected official's authority to use a county purchase card or credit card; 
(3)  Revocation of the elected official's authority to use a county purchase card or credit card; and 
(4)  Collection of an amount equal to the total of any improper purchases, including, but not be limited to declaring such purchases as an advance on salary to the extent allowed by law. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall preclude the county from referring misuse of a purchase card or credit card to the appropriate law enforcement authorities for prosecution. 
(Ord. of 12-15-15(1)) 
Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. of 6-15-10 repealed the former Ch. 6, Arts. I—III, and enacted a new Ch. 6, Arts. I—III, as set out herein. The former Ch. 6 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. of 12-11-90; Ord. of 2-11-92; Ord. of 11-10-92; Ord. of 9-8-98; Amd. of 1-11-00; Ord. of 12-17-02; Ord. of 12—05. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
Cross reference— Businesses, Ch. 22; alcoholic beverages at Reeves Landing, § 46-31. 
State Law reference— Use of proceeds of alcoholic beverage tax for prevention, education and treatment, Ga. Const. art. 3, sec. 9, par. 6; Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.; furnishing to, purchase of or possession by persons under 21 years of age, use of false identification, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23; public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41; furnishing alcoholic beverages to persons under 21 years of age, jurisdiction of municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-10; treatment of alcoholics and intoxicated persons, O.C.G.A. § 37-8-1 et seq.; driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-391. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. 
Unless otherwise defined herein, the definitions contained within O.C.G.A. § 33-1-1 et seq. shall be applicable to this chapter. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alcoholic beverages means and includes all alcohol, distilled spirits, beer, malt beverages, wine or fortified wine. 
Establishment means any physical location or section thereof for the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
License means the permit granted to a licensee for the operation of an establishment for the sale of alcoholic beverages or. 
Licensee means any person engaged in selling or conducting the sale, at retail or wholesale, or the dispensing of any alcoholic beverages. 
Live means any activity or entertainment which is carried on by actual living persons in the physical presence of business patrons. 
Live entertainment means entertainment for the benefit of patrons which is carried on in the actual physical presence of such patrons, including, but not limited to dancing. 
Mainstream performance house means a theater, concert hall, auditorium or similar establishment which regularly features live performances such as plays or concerts which are not distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on the depiction, description or display or the featuring of specified anatomical areas of specified sexual activities and where such depiction, if any, is only incidental to the primary purpose of any performance. 
Permitted location means any location, premises or building that is not located within 100 yards to an alcoholic treatment center and must be a business or otherwise commercial location that meets all state and local building code and zoning requirements of this county and does not violate the distance restrictions set forth in section 6-65 herein. 
Premises means the definite closed or partitioned establishment, whether room, shop or building wherein alcoholic beverages are sold or consumed, including the sidewalk serving area or outside, open air or patio type serving area on the private property of an establishment. 
Special event permit means a limited permit issued to the owner or lessee of a permitted location in order to serve wine, and/or beer and malt beverages, and/or distilled spirits at a private function or special event without charge to the participants. 
Specified anatomical areas means any of the following: 
(1)  Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals or pubic region; cleft of the buttocks; or any portion of the female breast encompassed within an area falling below the horizontal line one would have to draw to intercept a point above the top of the areola, or any portion of the areola, or any simulation thereof. This definition shall include the entire lower portion of the human female breast, but shall not include any portion of the cleavage of the human female breast, exhibited by a dress, blouse, shirt, leotard, bathing suit, or other wearing apparel, provided the areola is not so exposed. 
(2)  Human male genitalia in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
Specified sexual activities means and includes any of the following: 
(1)  The fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttocks, anus or female breasts; 
(2)  Sex acts, normal or perverted, actual or simulated, including intercourse, oral copulation or sodomy; 
(3)  Masturbation, actual or simulated; 
(4)  The displaying of the male or female pubic hair, anus, vulva or genitals; or 
(5)  Excretory functions as part of or in connection with any of the activities set forth in (1) through (4) above. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-2. - Brown bagging. 
It shall be unlawful for any business to allow customers to bring with them for consumption on the premises beer, wine or distilled spirits, which is known as "BYOB" or "brown bagging." 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
State Law reference— Municipal home rule, Ga. Const. art. IX, II; alcoholic beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.; local regulation of sales of alcoholic beverages generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq. 
Sec. 6-3. - Persons under the age of 21. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 21 to enter any establishment or section of an establishment which sells alcoholic beverages by the drink, unless accompanied by an adult, over 21 years of age, that is responsible for that underage person. Any establishment that chooses to admit persons under the age of 21, as set forth herein, must employ a readily visible method of determining persons who are over the age of 21 before selling any alcoholic beverage to any patron. An acceptable example would be an armband system that would only be issued to persons who have proven to the establishment, as set forth in subsection 6-31(b), to be over the age of 21. Persons under the age of 21 may enter a full-service restaurant which is licensed to sell alcoholic beverages, to be served for a meal without being accompanied by an adult, over 21 years of age. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person in charge of or employed by any establishment which sells alcoholic beverages by the drink to allow any person under the age of 21 to visit such place for business, except as allowed in subsection (a) herein above. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to furnish or sell alcoholic beverages to a person under the age of 21. 
(d)  No person under the age of 21 shall enter into a package store which sells distilled spirits. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 21 to: 
(1)  Allow anyone to purchase for him any alcoholic beverages; or 
(2)  Attempt to or enter the premises of an establishment for the purchase of alcoholic beverages. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful to sell or furnish in any manner whatsoever alcoholic beverages to any person under the age of 21, except that alcoholic beverages in reasonable quantities may be sold and served at tables in restaurants and food type establishments to persons age 21 or older for consumption by such persons only, when accompanied by persons under the age of 21. 
(g)  No person shall allow or require a person in his employment under the age of 21 years of age to dispense, serve, sell or take orders for any distilled spirits for consumption on premises. This section shall not prohibit persons under 21 years of age who are employed in supermarkets, drug stores and convenience stores from selling or handling packaged wine, beer, ale or malt liquors which are sold for consumption off the premises. This section does not prohibit such persons from setting up tables, clearing tables, or serving food in restaurant establishments when not in the same room with a bar or lounge. Further, persons that are 18 years or older may take orders and serve beer and wine beverages for consumption on the premises in restaurants. 
(h)  This section shall not prohibit invited persons under 21 years of age from being present in separate and distinct rooms restricted to private functions such as wedding parties and not open to the general public. Such persons under 21 years of age shall not be permitted to consume alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10; Ord. of 8-17-10) 
State Law reference— Alcohol and under age persons, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-3-2.1, 3-3-23 et seq. 
Secs. 6-4—6-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DEALERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-26. - Compliance with federal, state and county ordinances required. 
All licensees shall at all times comply with federal and state laws, county ordinances and rules and regulations of the state revenue commissioner, including licensing qualifications. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-27. - Compliance with this article required. 
No person shall operate an establishment involving the sale of alcoholic beverages without first having complied with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-28. - Display of license; copy of regulations to be kept on premises. 
All holders of a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall promptly display said license in the licensee's establishment and shall keep a copy of this chapter on the premises. The licensee shall instruct any person working there with respect to the terms hereof and each licensee or its agents selling alcoholic beverages shall at all times be familiar with the terms hereof. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-29. - Open to inspection. 
Places of business under this article shall at all times during the period allowable by law for operation of the business, be open to inspection by the sheriff's department or any officer thereof and/or to any person designated by the sheriff. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-30. - Alcohol regulations; hours of service. 
(a)  Applicability only to unincorporated areas of the county. The provisions of this section shall apply only to the unincorporated areas of the county. 
(b)  Accountability. Every licensee and its servants, employees, officers, and any and all other persons acting on behalf of the licensee may be equally guilty of a violation of any provision contained in this section. 
(c)  Election day. Alcoholic beverages may not be sold, whether by the package or for consumption on the premises, within 250 feet of a polling place when the polls are open. 
(d)  Package sales of malt beverages, wine, or distilled spirits. No package sales of malt beverages, wine, or distilled spirits shall be conducted on Sundays or Christmas except between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. pursuant to the approval of the electorate in a referendum pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-3-7. 
(e)  Consumption on the premises. 
(1)  No sales of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises may be conducted between the hours of 2:55 a.m. and 8:00 a.m.; and 
(2)  No sales of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises may be conducted on Sundays or Christmas except: 
a.  Between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 2:55 a.m. pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-3-7(m); and 
b.  Between 12:30 p.m. and 12:00 midnight in any licensed establishment which derives at least 50 percent of its total annual gross sales from the sale of prepared meals or food in all of the combined retail outlets of the individual establishment where food is served and in any licensed establishment which derives at least 50 percent of its total annual gross income from the rental of rooms for overnight lodging, pursuant to the approval of the electorate in a referendum pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-3-7. 
(f)  Marking displays on Sundays and Christmas. During such times that sales are prohibited on Sundays or Christmas as provided in this section, licensees open on Sundays or Christmas shall ensure that alcoholic beverages on display are plainly marked with a sign stating "Not For Sale" or that the alcoholic beverages are fully covered or that the alcoholic beverages are stored from the view of patrons or that the alcoholic beverages are locked and made not readily accessible. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10; Ord. of 8-17-10; Ord. of 3-15-16, § 1) 
State Law reference— Local authorization and regulation of sales of alcoholic beverages on Sunday; Sales of alcohol on Sundays, Christmas Day and election days; O.C.G.A. § 3-3-7(m) and O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20. 
Sec. 6-31. - Management and operation. 
(a)  The licensee shall be responsible for his/her employee's compliance with all state and local laws pertaining to alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  Failure to request and properly check identification. 
(1)  No licensee, or such licensee's employee or agent, shall furnish, serve or sell any alcoholic beverage to any person without first requesting to see and being furnished with proper identification as provided for in subsection (b) of this section in order to verify the age of such person. 
(2)  For the purpose of this section, the term "proper identification" means any document issued by a governmental agency containing a description of the person, such person's photograph, or both, and giving such person's date of birth and includes, without being limited to, a passport, military identification card, driver's license, or an identification card authorized under O.C.G.A. §§ 40-5-100—40-5-104. "Proper identification" shall not include a birth certificate and shall not include any traffic citation and complaint form. 
(3)  In addition to any other postings required by this section or by state or federal law, all licensees shall post in a conspicuous place within the licensed premises a sign which shall contain the following statement: 
"SALE OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES TO ANY PERSON FAILING TO FURNISH PROPER IDENTIFICATION IS PROHIBITED BY LAW." 
Such sign shall be printed in letters of at least one inch in height. 
(4)  Any person who fails to comply with the requirements of this Code section shall be guilty of an ordinance violation. In addition, the failure of a licensee, or such licensee's employer or agent, to comply with the provisions of this section shall constitute grounds for the suspension or revocation of a license, or the imposition of other penalties, as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. 
(5)  Exception for consumption on the premises licensees. Notwithstanding subsection (b)(1) above, any person who fails to furnish proper identification after being requested to do so may be sold or furnished an alcoholic beverage if the licensee's manager on duty makes a determination that no reasonable or prudent person could reasonably be in doubt that such person is actually 21 years old or older. Failure of a manager to comply with the provisions of this section resulting in the sale of alcohol to an individual under the age of 21 shall, in addition to any penalties that may be applicable with respect to subsection (b)(4) above, result in a mandatory three-day license suspension. This exception shall only apply in those establishments having a consumption on the premises license. 
Any violations of such laws by the licensee and/or employees may subject the licensee to civil penalties not to exceed $1,000.00 fine and/or the possible suspension or revocation of the alcohol license. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-32. - Maintenance of premises. 
Each licensee shall keep and maintain an orderly, respectable, and sanitary place of business under this article. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-33. - Storage of inventory or stock. 
No licensed retailer shall keep any alcoholic beverage stored in any warehouse in the county, nor shall they enter into any type of arrangement whereby alcoholic beverages ordered by him are stored by him by any license wholesaler. A retailer shall keep no inventory or stock or alcoholic beverages at any place except at his licensed place of business and within his licensed place of business. The storage space for alcoholic beverages shall be: 
(1)  Immediately adjacent to the room in which it is licensed to do business; and 
(2)  There shall be but one entrance to the storage area and this shall be through the retail store area. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-34. - Off-premises sales prohibited. 
No retailer shall sell or deliver any alcoholic beverage to any person except in the retailer's place of business. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-35. - Boisterous conduct. 
No boisterous, noisy or disorderly conduct will be permitted in or about any place of business under this article. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Secs. 6-36—6-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Local licenses generally, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-4-49 et seq., 3-5-40 et seq., 3-6-40, 3-7-40. 

Sec. 6-56. - Applicability. 
The provisions of this division shall apply to all holders of a license to sell alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-56.1. - Licenses or permits constitute grant or privilege. 
All alcoholic beverage licenses or permits issued hereunder constitute a mere grant or privilege to carry out such business during the term of the license subject to all terms and conditions imposed by this chapter and related laws and other ordinances of Sumter County relating to such business, as amended from time to time by the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-57. - Required. 
(a)  Every operator of an establishment for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages must obtain a license therefore. 
(b)  A separate retail license shall be required for each place of business. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-58. - Display. 
Licenses pursuant to this division must be posted in a conspicuous place and in such manner that it can be readily seen. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
State Law reference— Display of license, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-3. 
Sec. 6-59. - Application. 
(a)  Generally. No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages at retail shall be granted until the application, accompanied by a check or cash in the amount required for the license and setting forth the name of all owners, the business, and its location, shall have been approved by the sheriff's office, health department, code enforcement department, and fire and rescue department. After all departments named herein have approved the issuance of the license, it may be issued by the board of commissioners. No person or entity shall sell or attempt to sell alcoholic beverages at wholesale or retail until they have received their county and state licenses authorizing them to do so. All new alcoholic beverage applications shall receive two readings with public input at public hearings held by the board of commissioners before approval may be granted. Each reading, with public input, shall be conducted at two successive meetings, held at least six calendar days apart. All applications for licenses shall be made on the forms prescribed by the county clerk. 
(b)  Sworn statements. 
(1)  The applicant shall make a sworn statement of his qualifications according to this division and shall place such statement on file with the clerk before any license is issued. 
(2)  If the application covers a partnership, all members of the partnership must be qualified to obtain a license and must make sworn statements of those qualifications. 
(c)  In person. All applications for license shall be made under oath to the county clerk. 
(d)  False information. Any statement on an application for license to sell alcoholic beverages which shall later be found to be false or omission of facts shall subject the applicant to prosecution for perjury under the laws of this state. 
(e)  [State application.] The applicant shall submit a copy of his state application upon applying for a local alcoholic beverage license. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10; Ord. of 5-14-13; Ord. of 11-9-16, § 1) 
Sec. 6-60. - Eligibility. 
(a)  No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be granted to any person unless the person is 21 years of age prior to filing an application for the license. 
(b)  Licenses may be granted to a corporation existing under the laws of the state or to a foreign corporation authorized to do business in the state; provided, however, that any such corporation shall be required to designate a manager or responsible employee that will be employed on the premises full-time as its local agent responsible for compliance with all the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-61. - Availability of investigation reports on applicant and employees; authority to require fingerprints and photographs of the applicant and employees. 
(a)  A consent statement by the applicant that all necessary investigation reports on the applicant and any employees in the applicant's establishment, including but not limited to credit reports and reports from law enforcement agencies, may be obtained; any information in these reports may be furnished to the county; and the applicant will be responsible for the costs thereof. If so requested, the applicant shall also obtain these consent forms from each employee who will be employed in applicant's establishment. The county may, at its option, require fingerprints and/or photographs of applicant's employees for the purpose of conducting its investigation. 
(b)  Licensees will, upon request, furnish to the sheriff the names and addresses of each employee hired, within one week of such hiring. The licensee also shall, upon request, furnish the consent form for investigation of each employee hired for the establishment during the continuance of the license granted hereunder. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-62. - Character of applicant and employees. 
(a)  All applicants for alcoholic beverage licenses must be of good character, and all managers, clerks or other employees shall be of like character or the application will not be considered. 
(b)  No license shall be issued to any person who has been convicted under any federal, state or local law of any felony or of any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
(c)  The board of commissioners may, in its discretion, consider any extenuating circumstances which may reflect favorably or unfavorably on the applicant, application, or the proposed location of the business. If in its judgment, circumstances are such that the granting of the license would not be in the best interest of the general public, these circumstances may be grounds for denying the application. 
(d)  Ascertainable standards of good moral character which may be considered by the board of commissioners in deciding of a license will be issued include, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Present and prior compliance with county ordinances; 
(2)  Prior supervision over employees and customers; 
(3)  Truthfulness in submitted application; 
(4)  Criminal and civil court records; 
(5)  Employment history; 
(6)  Credit reports; 
(7)  Payment of county, city, state and federal taxes. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-63. - Persons to whom licenses not issued. 
No license shall be granted to any person or entity for the operation of an establishment offering the sale of alcoholic beverages in any area prohibited by law or by the zoning regulations for the county. No license will be granted to any person or entity that has not fully paid all taxes, costs, fees, citations or any liquidated claim or amount such person or entity owes to the government of Sumter County. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-64. - Building to be complete; attachment of evidence of ownership or copy of lease of application. 
No license shall be issued to any person unless the building in which the establishment will be located is complete, and every applicant for a retail license shall attach to its application evidence of ownership or a copy of a lease/rental agreement if the applicant is leasing or renting the building. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-65. - Proximity of premises to churches, schools, colleges. 
No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages will be issued that does not meet the proximity requirements of O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21, and an applicant shall provide certification by a Georgia Registered Surveyor that the location of the establishment meets the requirements of such code section. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-66. - License fee for sale of distilled spirits by the package or consumption on the premises. 
(a)  The annual fee for a retail license for the sale of distilled spirits by the package shall be $1,500.00. The annual fee for a retail license for the sale of distilled spirits for consumption on the premises shall be $2,500.00. 
(b)  Such annual fees shall not be prorated and are payable to the Sumter County Board of Commissioners. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
State Law reference— Limitation on fee, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-50. 
Sec. 6-67. - License fee for sale of beer and wine. 
(a)  The annual fee for a retail license to sell beer by the package shall be $300.00. The annual fee for a retail license to sell beer for consumption on the premises shall be $300.00. 
(b)  The annual fee for a retail license to sell wine by the package shall be $300.00. The annual fee for a retail license to sell wine for consumption on the premises shall be $300.00. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
State Law reference— Authority to fix license fee, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-42. 
Sec. 6-68. - License fee for sale of alcoholic beverages by wholesalers. 
(a)  The annual fee for a wholesale license for the sale of beer shall be $1,000.00. 
(b)  The annual fee for a wholesale license for the sale of wine shall be $1,000.00. 
(c)  The annual fee for a wholesale license for the sale of distilled spirits shall be $1,000.00. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
State Law reference— Limitations on fee for wholesale licenses, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-4-50, 3-5-43. 
Sec. 6-69. - License expiration, date. 
All licenses concerning alcoholic beverages will expire on December 31 of each year. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-70. - Renewal of all alcoholic beverage licenses. 
All alcoholic beverage licenses in this division may be renewed by payment of the required fees provided: 
(1)  The license and location are the same; and 
(2)  The licensee is still in compliance with the requirements of state and county laws and regulations pertaining to the original issuance of the license and pertaining to the operation of the business under the license at the time of application for renewal; but 
(3)  If a complaint is received as to the licensee's alleged violation of state or county law or regulation, the license shall not be renewed but shall be referred to the board of commissioners for decision as to whether renewal shall be granted as follows: 
a.  The board of commissioners shall conduct a hearing after giving the licensee reasonable notice of the time and place of such hearing, as well as the purpose thereof; 
b.  The licensee may remain open for business until a decision by the board of commissioners is made and shall have a period of three days following that decision in which to pay the required fees if the decision of the board is to permit renewal of the license. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-71. - Sale of retail alcoholic beverage business. 
It shall be unlawful (and shall call for immediate revocation of all licenses involved, both of the seller and purchaser) for any retail alcoholic beverage licensee to purchase the business of any other licensee and attempt to operate the purchased business with seller's license. In the event of a bona fide sale of any licensed retail business under this classification to persons other than licensed dealers, full disclosure of the persons involved, the purchase price, and such other information as the board of commissioners shall determine shall be given to them as a condition to this sale. In addition to the revocation of the license of any person violating the provisions of this section, the person or persons shall be subject to a civil penalty of $1,000.00. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-72. - Transferability; surrender of license upon sale; closing business. 
Licenses for the sale of distilled spirits only shall be transferable or assignable under the following conditions: 
(1)  Licenses may be transferred to members of the licensee's immediate family provided the transferee has first been approved to hold such license under the terms and conditions of this section. 
(2)  In the event of the death of a license holder, the holder's heirs or estate shall be permitted to operate the establishment or transfer the license to another qualified individual who has first been approved under the terms and conditions contained in this section. 
(3)  In no event shall any license be transferable if there are any fees, taxes or other revenues due to the county by the license holder. 
(4)  Any permitted transfers of licenses under this section shall be subject to a transfer fee payment of $125.00. 
(5)  In any other event in which a licensed business is sold or closed, it shall be the duty of the licensee to immediately surrender the license to the county clerk. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-73. - Revocation or suspension. 
(a)  No license which has been issued or which may hereafter be issued by the county under this division shall be suspended or revoked, except for due cause as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  Upon failure of the licensee to comply with the terms, provisions, requirements and responsibilities of this article, or upon the failure of the licensee to timely pay the annual license fee called for herein, or upon the violation by the licensee of any law regulating the sale of alcoholic beverages or upon the conviction of the licensee of any felony, aggravated misdemeanor, misdemeanor involving moral turpitude or drug-related conviction or upon licensee's permitted or maintaining a breach, or breaches of the peace at licensee's establishment, or upon the existence of any other condition which would make the continued operation of the licensee's establishment detrimental, harmful or undesirable to the community, then any license provided for herein may be suspended or revoked by the county. 
(c)  Upon information concerning any of the provisions outlined in this section hereinabove, the county shall serve notice upon licensee, either by certified mail addressed to licensee's establishment or by service by the sheriff or his/her deputy, requiring the licensee to appear before the board of commissioners and show cause why the licensee's alcoholic beverage license should not be suspended or revoked. This hearing shall not be held sooner than three days from the receipt of said notice by the licensee and no later than 45 days from the receipt of said notice. Said notice shall set forth the date, time and place of the hearing on the matter; this notice shall also state the condition alleged which could, if sustained, result in suspended or revocation of a licensee's license. 
(d)  Within ten working days following the hearing on this matter, the board of commissioners shall render a decision on the matter, notifying licensee in writing of its decision by certified mail addressed to licensee's establishment or by personally delivering it to licensee by the sheriff or his/her deputy. In the event of revocation, no refund shall be made on any portion of any license fee paid and the establishment will immediately cease to operate upon said notification of the board of commissioner's decision. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-73.1. - Notification and reporting of disciplinary actions. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section, the following terms shall be defined in the same manner and in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. Tit. 3, including O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2.1, as follows: 
Bar means any premises at which a retailer licensed pursuant to O.C.G.A. Tit. 3 to sell alcoholic beverages derives 75 percent or more total annual gross revenue from the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises. 
Disciplinary action means any citation or arrest arising out of the violation of any law, rule, regulation, resolution, or ordinance of a governmental entity relating to the manufacture, distribution, sale, or possession of alcoholic beverages against a licensee, an employee of a licensee, or any person holding a financial interest in the license of the licensee on the premises or place of business of any licensee. 
Governmental entity means the United States government, any state government, any local government, and any department, agency, or instrumentality thereof. 
Licensee means any person issued a license pursuant to O.C.G.A. Tit. 3 by a governmental entity to operate a bar. 
(b)  (1)  Reporting of disciplinary actions by licensees. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2.1(b)(1), a licensee in the county shall notify the Georgia Department of Revenue of the details of any disciplinary action taken against such licensee by the county or any of its officers, departments, agencies, or instrumentalities, including the date such action was taken, the nature of such action, and any other information required by the Georgia Department of Revenue. The licensee shall provide the notification required in this subsection within 45 days of any disciplinary action being taken. 
(2)  Revocation or suspension of license for failure to report. A licensee's violation of paragraph (b)(1) of this subsection shall constitute grounds for revocation or suspension of the licensee's license. 
(c)  Reporting of disciplinary actions by county clerk. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2.1(c), any disciplinary action by the county or its officers, departments, agencies, or instrumentalities against a licensee shall be reported by the county clerk to the Georgia Department of Revenue within 45 days of any such action being taken. 
(d)  Method of reporting. All notification and reporting of disciplinary actions under subsections (b) and (c) of this section shall be made by utilizing the reporting method implemented by the Georgia Department of Revenue. 
(Ord. of 8-9-16, § 1) 
Sec. 6-74. - Permitted location for special events at which alcoholic beverages are served. 
(a)  No alcoholic beverages shall be sold, dispensed, distributed, poured or served at any location, premises, or building in the county except as set out in this chapter unless otherwise provided for under this chapter. 
(b)  The owner or lessee of a location at which alcoholic beverages are to be furnished and served at a private function or special event by a person at a location not otherwise required to be licensed pursuant to this chapter shall first obtain a qualifying location permit designating such location as a "permitted location." Such qualifying location permit shall be good for the calendar year in which it is issued and may be renewed annually as set forth in this chapter. The owner or lessee of such location seeking to be a permitted location shall contact the county clerk and complete an application for an annual permit as a permitted location. The fee for a permitted location shall be $50.00 per year. 
(c)  To qualify as a "permitted location," the location, premises or building shall not be located nearer to an alcoholic treatment center and must be a business or otherwise commercial location that meets all state and local building code and zoning requirements of this county and does not violate the distance restrictions set forth in section 6-65 herein. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to furnish and serve alcoholic beverages at a private function or special event at a permitted location unless food is also served at the private function or special event. 
(e)  Alcoholic beverages furnished and served at a private function or special event may be consumed only on the premises to persons of lawful age as set forth in section 6-3, and alcoholic beverages may not be removed from the premises in an open container. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any alcoholic beverages to be sold at a private function or special event, i.e. "no cash bar" sales will be permitted, unless the permitted location also holds an on premises consumption license for alcoholic beverages. 
(g)  Locations, premises or buildings for which an on-premises consumption license has been issued pursuant to this chapter shall be deemed a "permitted location" under this section without further application. However, alcoholic beverages may not be sold or dispensed from the area or premises licensed for the sale and dispensing of alcoholic beverages on Sunday except as authorized in this chapter. 
(h)  The "permitted location" licensee shall be responsible for any violation of this chapter which occurs at the "permitted location" whether by the licensee's employees or agents, a caterer or their employees or agents, or a lessee or invitee of the licensee, their lessee or invitees or any of their employees or agents. 
(i)  The person holding the private function or special event, and not otherwise required to be licensed pursuant to this chapter must purchase and furnish the alcoholic beverages. 
(j)  The times for the serving of alcoholic beverages at a permitted location shall be as set forth in section 6-30 of this chapter. 
(k)  No building or location owned by the government of Sumter County, Georgia shall be subject to section [6-]74 of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10; Ord. of 3-15-16, § 2) 
Sec. 6-75. - Special event permits. 
(a)  In order to serve wine, and/or beer and malt beverages, and/or distilled spirits at a private function or special event, at a permitted location, the person organizing the private function or special event shall be required to: 
(1)  Apply to the county for a "special event permit." The application shall include the name and business address of any caterer providing food service for the private function or special event, the date, time and location of the event, which location must be a permitted location as set forth in this chapter or otherwise exempt as set forth under this chapter. No person and/or entity may apply for and be granted a special event permit more that once every three months from the grant of the last permit. 
(2)  Pay the cost of such permit to the county clerk which shall be $50.00 per day, not to exceed two days. If the application meets all of the requirements of this chapter, the county clerk shall issue the special event permit. If the county clerk finds that the application does not meet the requirements of this chapter and denies the special event permit, the applicant may appeal in writing to the county council within five days of the date of the denial. 
(b)  The "special event permit" shall be maintained at the site of the private function or special event during the hours alcoholic beverages are served. 
(c)  The person holding the private function or special event, and not otherwise required to be licensed pursuant to this chapter, must purchase the alcoholic beverages. 
(d)  The "special event permit" licensee shall be responsible for any violation of this chapter which occurs at the event whether by the licensee's employees or agents, invitee of the licensee or invitee of the invitee of the licensee. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-76. - Exceptions. 
(a)  The requirements of this chapter shall not apply to a private function held for business development purposes or charitable purposes at which alcoholic beverages are served by a person or organization not otherwise required to be licensed pursuant to this chapter to members and invited guests of such persons or organization holding the event at a permitted location or at a location not otherwise required to be permitted pursuant to this chapter, provided that the person or organization purchased and served the alcoholic beverages and receives no payment from invited guests, and the event is not open or accessible to the general public. 
(b)  The requirements of this chapter shall not apply to a private function held at a private residence at which alcoholic beverages are purchased and served by a person not otherwise required to be licensed pursuant to this chapter to invited guests of such person, provided that the person holding the event purchases the alcoholic beverages and receives no payment from invited guests, and the event is not open or accessible to the general public. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Secs. 6-77—6-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TAX 

Sec. 6-91. - Tax to be in addition to other charges. 
The excise tax provided for in this division shall be in addition to any license fee, tax or charge which may now or in the future be imposed upon the business of selling alcoholic beverages at retail or wholesale, within the unincorporated area of the county. The county shall collect the maximum excise tax allowable by law upon the wholesale of malt beverages, spirituous liquors and wine as prescribed in O.C.G.A. §§ 3-5-80, 3-4-80, 3-6-60, or as hereafter prescribed by subsequent state law. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-92. - Payment of taxes. 
The taxes levied in this division shall be paid by the retailer to the wholesaler at the time of delivery of the beverages to the retailer. It shall be the duty of each retailer to pay and it shall be the duty of each wholesaler to receive the proper amount of the tax levied upon each case delivered. It shall further be the duty of all persons, firms or corporations selling these beverages at wholesale or making delivery of them in the unincorporated area of the county to remit by the tenth (10th) of the calendar month all sums collected by the wholesaler during the preceding calendar month. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-93. - Examination of books and records. 
The books and records of all wholesalers selling or delivering these beverages and all retailers thereof in the unincorporated area of the county shall be subject to inspection and audit by the agents of the county to ensure compliance herewith. It shall be unlawful for any person to deny to any authorized agent of the county reasonable access to its books and records and shall be the duty of each person to keep accurate records of payments and collections of the case tax and remittances. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-94. - Penalties. 
(a)  The failure to make a timely report and remittance required shall render a wholesaler liable for a penalty equal to 25 percent of the total due during the first 30-day period following the date the report and remittance were due and a further penalty of 50 percent of the amount of this remittance for each successive 30-day period or any portion thereof during which the report and the remittance were not filed. 
(b)  The filing of a false or fraudulent report shall render the wholesale dealer making the report liable to a penalty equal to 100 percent of the amount of the remittance which would be required under an accurate and truthful report. 
(c)  Any person, wholesaler or retailer that shall violate the provisions hereof shall, upon conviction, be punished as prescribed by law and may in addition be subject to suspension or revocation of the license to sell such beverages. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-95. - Taxes collected upon delivery. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any retailer of alcoholic beverages to receive and retain these beverages unless he shall have paid the tax thereon. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any wholesaler of alcoholic beverages to sell or deliver beverages to any retailer thereof unless he shall concurrently with this delivery collect the tax imposed. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any wholesaler of alcoholic beverages to fail to remit to the county when promptly due, the taxes levied, and collected by the wholesaler. It shall be unlawful for any person engaged as a retailer of these beverages to receive these beverages from another retailer unless tax has been paid. 
(d)  It shall further be unlawful for any retailer of alcoholic beverages to receive and retail these beverages from another retail store, whether the other store shall be owned by the receiving retailer or not unless the tax shall have been paid and remitted to the county. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-96. - Unpaid taxes. 
Alcoholic beverages on which county taxes have not been paid are subject to seizure and may be destroyed or sold by public sale as provided by law. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
ARTICLE III. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT BUSINESS 

Sec. 6-97. - Findings; public purpose. 
(a)  Based on the demonstrated experience of other urban counties and municipalities, including but not limited to Atlanta and Fulton County, Georgia; DeKalb County, Georgia; Orlando, Florida; Orange County, Florida; Indianapolis, Indiana; Los Angeles, California; Beaumont, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; St. Paul, Minnesota; and Austin, Texas, which experience is found to be relevant to similar problems that could face Sumter County. 
(b)  It is the finding of the Board of Commissioners of Sumter County that public nudity (either partial or total) under circumstances related to the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages in so-called "nude bars" or establishments offering so-called "nude entertainment" or "adult entertainment" in conjunction with the sale of alcoholic beverages, enhances criminal behavior and tends to create undesirable community conditions. 
(c)  Among the acts of criminal behavior found to be associated with nudity and alcohol are disorderly conduct, prostitution, public indecency and drug trafficking. Among the undesirable community conditions identified with the concentration of adult entertainment establishments are depreciation of property values in neighborhoods surrounding nude bars or adult entertainment establishments where alcoholic beverages are sold, increased expenditure for and allocation of law enforcement personnel to preserve law and order, increased burdens on the judicial system as a consequence of the criminal behavior hereinabove described, and acceleration of community blight by the concentration of adult establishments in particular areas. 
(d)  Other negative effects which were found by the board are the apparent connection of these establishments to organized crime and illegal drug sales; the potential spread of communicable disease to law enforcement personnel who answer calls at adult establishments and to patrons of such establishments; and the potential proliferation of adult entertainment establishments after the initial opening of an adult entertainment establishment in a particular neighborhood. 
(e)  The board, therefore, finds that it is in the best interest of the health, welfare, safety and morals and preservation of its businesses, neighborhoods, and of churches, schools, and parks to prevent the adverse impact of adult entertainment establishments. Therefore, the board finds that the prohibition of live nude conduct establishments licensed to serve alcohol for consumption on the premises is in the public welfare of furthering legitimate governmental interest, such as reducing criminal activity, protecting against property devaluation and deterioration, and eliminating undesirable community conditions normally associated with establishments which serve alcohol and allow and/or encourage nudity, and that such prohibition will not infringe upon the protected constitutional rights of freedom of speech and/or expression. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-98. - Conduct prohibited. 
The following types of entertainment, attire and conduct are prohibited upon any premises licensed to sell, serve or disperse alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises within unincorporated area of the county. 
(1)  The employment or use of any person live, in any capacity, in the sale or service of alcoholic beverages or food while such person is unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing, as to expose any portion of his or her specified anatomical areas. 
(2)  Live entertainment where any person appears unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose any portion of his or her specified anatomical areas or where such person performs acts of specified sexual activities or acts which simulate specified sexual activity, as defined herein. 
(3)  The holding, promotion, sponsoring or allowance of any contest, promotion, special night, event or any other activity where live patrons of the licensed establishment are encouraged or allowed to engage in any of the conduct proscribed in subsections (1) and (2) above. 
(4)  Nothing contained in this section shall apply to the premises of any mainstream performance house or museum which derives less than 20 percent of its gross annual income from the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Sec. 6-99. - Penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to perform any acts prohibited in section 6-98 above and any such conduct will be a violation of this Code and shall be punishable as provided under section 1-11 of this Code. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a licensee to permit any conduct prohibited in section 6-98 above which he knows or has reasonable cause to know is taking place on the premises. Any such conduct by a licensee shall be a violation of this Code and shall be punishable as provided under section 1-11 of this Code. Also, upon conviction, a licensee may have his/her alcoholic beverage license revoked or suspended as provided in section 6-73 of this Code. 
(Ord. of 6-15-10) 
Chapter 10 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
