ARTICLE II. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Nudity and related acts on premises, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-41; employee solicitation of patrons for drinks on premises, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-42. 

Sec. 10-31. - Findings; public purpose. 
Based on the experience of other urban counties and municipalities, including but not limited to Atlanta and Fulton County, Georgia; Dekalb County, Georgia; Cobb County, Georgia; Richmond County, Georgia; and Ft. Lauderdale and Palm Beach, Florida, which experiences are relevant to the problems faced by the county, the notorious and self-evident conditions attendant to the commercial exploitation of human sexuality, which do not vary greatly among generally comparable communities within the country are noted. Moreover, it is the finding of the board of commissioners that public nudity (either partial or total) under certain circumstances, particularly circumstances related to the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages in so-called "nude bars" or establishments offering so-called "nude entertainment" or "adult entertainment," begets criminal behavior and tends to create undesirable community conditions. Among the acts of criminal behavior identified with nudity and alcohol are disorderly conduct, prostitution, and drug trafficking and use. Among the undesirable community conditions identified with nudity and alcohol are depression of property values in the surrounding neighborhood, increased expenditure for and allocation of law enforcement personnel to preserve law and order, increased burden on the judicial system as a consequence of the criminal behavior hereinabove described, and acceleration of community blight by the concentration of such establishments in particular areas. Therefore, the limitation of nude conduct in establishments licensed to sell alcohol for consumption on the premises is in the public welfare; and it is a matter of governmental interest and concern to prevent the occurrence of criminal behavior and undesirable community conditions normally associated with establishments that serve alcohol and also allow and/or encourage nudity. To that end, this article is hereby adopted. 
(Ord. of 11-8-93, § 1) 
Sec. 10-32. - Prohibited acts. 
The following types of entertainment, attire and conduct are prohibited upon any premises licensed to sell, serve or dispense alcohol beverages: 
(1)  The employment or use of the services of any person, in any capacity, in the sale or service of alcohol beverages while such person is unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose to view any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola or of any portion of the male or female pubic hair, anus, cleft of the buttocks, vulva or genitals. 
(2)  Live entertainment where any person appears in the manner described in subsection (1) of this section or where such person performs acts of or acts that simulate any of the following: 
a.  Sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual act prohibited by law. 
b.  The touching, caressing or fondling of the breasts, buttocks, anus, vulva or genitals. 
c.  The displaying of the male or female pubic hair, anus, vulva or genitals. 
(3)  The holding, promotion, sponsoring or allowing of any contest, promotion, special night, event or any other activity where patrons of the licensed establishment are encouraged or allowed to engage in any of the conduct described in subsections (1) and (2) above. 
(Ord. of 11-8-93, § 2) 
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Dogfighting, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-37; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; sale of dog meat for human consumption prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-160; fish, O.C.G.A. § 27-4-30 et seq.; wild animals, O.C.G.A. § 27-5-4 et seq.; authority to exercise animal control, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(3); control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq.; animal bites, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-4; inoculation of dogs and cats against rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-6; rabies inoculation tags, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-6; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; livestock running at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq.; Dead Animal Disposal Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-5-1 et seq.; Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; permitting dogs in heat to run at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6; liability of owner or keeper of vicious or dangerous animal for injuries caused by animal, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-7. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Animals at large. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a domestic animal to be allowed to run at large in the unincorporated parts of Sumter County unless such animal has an animal collar with a current metal rabies vaccination tag and an additional metal tag affixed thereto that is inscribed with the owner's last name and address or telephone number. In lieu of a collar and tags, a domestic animal may have a microchip implant placed under the skin of a domestic animal by a licensed veterinarian that identifies the animal's owner and the animal's current rabies inoculation records. 
(b)  A domestic animal for the purposes of this ordinance shall refer to dogs and cats only. 
(c)  Any domestic animal found to be running at large without the required tags as described in (a) above may be seized by the Sumter County Animal Control Officer and taken to the local animal shelter for adoption or to be euthanized. 
(Ord. of 3-18-2014(1)) 
Sec. 14-2. - Violation, penalty. 
Upon finding of guilt for the violation of this section, the offender shall be subject to a fine not exceeding $100.00. 
(Ord. of 3-18-2014(1)) 
Secs. 14-3—14-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DANGEROUS DOGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq. 

Sec. 14-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Board means the animal control board. 
County governing authority means the board of county commissioners. 
Dangerous dog means any dog that, according to the records of an appropriate authority: 
(1)  Inflicts a severe injury on a human being without provocation on public or private property at any time after March 31, 1989; or 
(2)  Aggressively bites, attacks or endangers the safety of humans without provocation after the dog has been classified as a potentially dangerous dog and after the owner has been notified of such classification. 
Dog control officer means an individual selected by a local government pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 4-8-22 to aid in the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article. 
Owner means any natural person or any legal entity, including but not limited to a corporation, partnership, firm, or trust owning, possessing, harboring, keeping, or having custody or control of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within this county. 
Potentially dangerous dog means: 
(1)  Any dog that without provocation bites a human being on public or private property at any time after March 31, 1989. 
(2)  Any dog that without provocation attacks and bites another animal or fowl and is of sufficient size, and has sufficient aggressive behavior to endanger the safety of other domestic animals, farm animals and human beings on public or private property at any time after March 31, 1989. 
Proper enclosure means an enclosure for keeping a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog while on the owner's property securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen, fence or structure suitable to prevent the entry of young children and designed to prevent the dog from escaping. Any such pen or structure shall have secure sides and a secure top; and, if the dog is enclosed within a fence, all sides of the fence shall be of sufficient height and the bottom of the fence shall be constructed or secured in such a manner as to prevent the dog's escape either from over or from under the fence. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements for the dog. 
Records of an appropriate authority means records of any state, county or municipal law enforcement agency; records of any county or municipal animal control agency; records of any county board of health; records of any federal, state or local court; or records of a dog control officer as provided in this article and by the laws of the state. 
Severe injury means any physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations requiring multiple sutures or cosmetic surgery or a physical injury that results in death. 
(Ord. No. 1990-1, § 1, 2-13-90; Ord. of 7-11-95, § I) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-32. - Exceptions to definitions. 
The term "dangerous dog" and "potentially dangerous dog," as defined in section 14-31, shall not include the following: 
(1)  A dog that inflicts an injury upon a person when the dog is being used by a law enforcement officer to carry out the law enforcement officer's official duties; and 
(2)  A dog who inflicts an injury within the meaning of this article if the injury was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a willful trespass or other tort, or was tormenting, abusing or assaulting the dog, or had in the past been observed or reported to have tormented, abused or assaulted the dog or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. 
(Ord. No. 1990-1, § 2, 2-13-90) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-33. - Dangerous dog warning symbol. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-8-21 et seq., the board of commissioners adopts by reference the uniform dangerous dog warning symbol. An official copy of such symbol is on file in the office of the clerk of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. of 5-9-89) 
Sec. 14-34. - Animal control board. 
(a)  There is created and established an animal control board. The purpose of the board shall be to conduct the hearings provided for in section 14-36. 
(b)  The board shall be the board of health. 
(c)  No member of the board shall participate in a hearing on any matter in which such member previously participated in the classification of the dog at issue. In the event of a vacancy during the term of any member by reason of death, resignation, or otherwise, the appointment of a successor by the county governing authority shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term of such member. 
(Ord. No. 1990-1, § 3, 2-13-90) 
Cross reference— Authorities, boards and commissions, § 2-111 et seq. 
Sec. 14-35. - Dog control officer. 
The county governing authority shall appoint a dog control officer, who shall serve at the pleasure of the governing authority. The dog control officer's compensation shall be established from time to time by the governing authority. 
(Ord. No. 1990-1, § 4, 2-13-90) 
Cross reference— Officers and employees generally, § 2-66 et seq. 
Sec. 14-36. - Procedure for classifying dangerous dogs and potentially dangerous dogs; notice; hearing. 
(a)  The dog control officer, upon receiving a report of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the county from a law enforcement agency, animal control agency, rabies control officer, or county board of health shall make such investigations and inquiries with regard to such report as may be necessary to determine the validity of such report and whether the dog should be classified as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog or reclassified as a dangerous dog if previously classified as a potentially dangerous dog. 
(b)  Should the dog control officer determine that a dog is a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, the dog control officer shall classify such dog accordingly. The dog control officer shall then notify the dog's owner of such classification. The notice to the owner shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  The notice shall be in writing and mailed by certified mail to the owner's last known address; 
(2)  The notice shall include a summary of the dog control officer's findings that formed the basis for the dog's classification as a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog; 
(3)  The notice shall be dated and shall state that the owner, within 15 days after the date shown on the notice, has a right to request a hearing on the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; 
(4)  The notice shall state that the hearing, if requested, shall be before the animal control board; 
(5)  The notice shall state that if a hearing is not requested, the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog will become effective for all purposes on a date specified in the notice, which shall be after the last day on which the owner has a right to request a hearing; and 
(6)  The notice shall include a form to request a hearing before the animal control board and shall provide specific instructions on mailing or delivering such request to the board. 
(c)  When the animal control board receives a request for a hearing as provided in subsection (b) of this section, it shall schedule such hearing within 30 days after receiving the request. The board shall notify the dog owner in writing by certified mail of the date, time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed to the dog owner at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing. At the hearing, the owner of the dog shall be given the opportunity to testify and present evidence. In addition, the board shall receive at the hearing such other evidence and hear such other testimony as the board may find reasonably necessary to make a determination either to sustain, modify or overrule the dog control officer's classification of the dog. 
(d)  Within ten days after the date of the hearing, the animal control board shall notify the dog owner in writing by certified mail of its determination on the matter. If such determination is that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog, the notice shall specify the date upon which that determination is effective. 
(Ord. No. 1990-1, § 5, 2-13-90) 
Sec. 14-37. - Requirements for possessing a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog. 
(a)  No one shall have, own or possess within the county a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog without a certificate of registration. 
(b)  The dog control officer shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog if the owner presents to the dog control officer or the dog control officer otherwise finds sufficient evidence of: 
(1)  A proper enclosure to confine the dangerous or potentially dangerous dog; and 
(2)  The posting of the premises where the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is located with a clearly visible sign warning that there is a dangerous dog on the property. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall receive such sign from the dog control officer at the time the owner pays the annual registration fee as required in subsection (d) of this section. 
(c)  In addition to the requirements of subsection (b) of this section, the owner of a dangerous dog shall present to the dog control officer evidence of: 
(1)  A policy of insurance in the amount of at least $15,000.00 issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in this state insuring the owner of the dangerous dog against liability for any personal injuries inflicted by the dangerous dog; or 
(2)  A surety bond in the amount of $15,000.00 or more issued by a surety company authorized to transact business in this state payable to any person or persons injured by the dangerous dog. 
(d)  The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall pay an annual registration fee at the time the annual certificate of registration is issued. The annual registration fee shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. Certificates of registration shall be renewed in the month of the initial registration. 
(e)  The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer if the owner is moving from the county. 
(f)  The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who is a new resident of the state shall register such dog as required by this article within 30 days after becoming a resident of the state and county. 
(g)  The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who moves to the county from any other county within the state shall register such dog as required by this article within ten days after becoming a resident of the county. 
(h)  The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer within 24 hours if the dog is on the loose, is unconfined, has attacked a human, has died, or has been sold or donated. If the dog has been sold or donated, the owner shall also provide the dog control officer with the name, address and telephone number of the new owner of the dog. 
(Ord. No. 1990-1, § 6, 2-13-90) 
Sec. 14-38. - Restrictions on permitting dangerous or potentially dangerous dogs outside a proper enclosure. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for an owner of a dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is muzzled and restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the physical restraint of a responsible person. The muzzle shall be made in a manner that will prevent it from biting any person but not cause injury to the dog or interfere with its vision or respiration. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of a potentially dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the restraint of a responsible person. 
(Ord. No. 1990-1, § 7, 2-13-90) 
Sec. 14-39. - Confiscation of dogs; grounds; disposition. 
(a)  A dangerous dog shall be immediately confiscated by the dog control officer or by a law enforcement officer or by another person authorized by the dog control officer if: 
(1)  The owner of the dog does not secure the liability insurance or surety bond required by section 14-37(c); 
(2)  The dog is not validly registered as required by this article; 
(3)  The dog is not maintained in a proper enclosure as defined in this article; or 
(4)  The dog is outside a proper enclosure in violation of section 14-38(a). 
(b)  A potentially dangerous dog shall be confiscated in the same manner as a dangerous dog if: 
(1)  The dog is not validly registered as required by this article; 
(2)  The dog is not maintained in a proper enclosure as defined in this article; or 
(3)  The dog is outside a proper enclosure in violation of section 14-38(b). 
(c)  Any dog that has been confiscated under the provisions of this section shall be returned to its owner upon the owner's compliance with the provisions of this article as determined by the dog control officer and upon the payment of reasonable confiscation costs. If the owner has not complied with the provisions of this section within 20 days of the date the dog is confiscated, the dog shall be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. 
(Ord. No. 1990-1, § 8, 2-13-90) 
Sec. 14-40. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  The owner of a dangerous dog who violates the applicable provisions of section 14-37 or 14-38 or whose dangerous dog is subject to confiscation under section 14-39(a) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of high and aggravated nature. In addition to any confinement that might be imposed for a conviction under this subsection, for the second conviction, a fine of not less than $500.00 shall be imposed; and for a third or subsequent conviction, a fine of not less than $750.00 shall be imposed. 
(b)  The owner of a potentially dangerous dog who violates the applicable provisions of section 14-37 or 14-38 of this article or whose potentially dangerous dog is subject to confiscation under section 14-39(b) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. In addition to any confinement that might be imposed for a conviction under this subsection, for a second conviction, a fine of not less than $150.00 shall be imposed; and for a third or subsequent conviction, a fine of not less than $300.00 shall be imposed. 
(c)  If an owner who has a previous conviction for a violation of this article knowingly and willfully fails to comply with the provisions of this article, such owner shall be guilty of a felony if the owner's dangerous dog attacks or bites a human being under circumstances constituting another violation of this article. The owner of a dangerous dog who is convicted for a violation of this subsection shall be punished by a fine of not less than $1,000.00 nor more than $5,000.00 or by imprisonment for not less than one nor more than five years or by both such fine and imprisonment as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 4-8-28(c). 
(d)  An owner who knowingly and willfully fails to comply with the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a felony if the owner's dangerous dog aggressively attacks and causes severe injury or death of a human being under circumstances constituting a violation of this article. The owner of a dangerous dog who is convicted of a violation of this subsection shall be punished by a fine of not less than $5,000.00 nor more than $10,000.00 or by imprisonment for not less than one nor more than ten years or by both such fine and imprisonment as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 4-8-28(d). 
(e)  In addition to the penalties for violations under subsection (c) or (d) of this section, the dangerous dog involved shall be immediately confiscated by the dog control officer or by a law enforcement officer or another person authorized by the dog control officer and placed in quarantine for the proper length of time as determined by the county board of health; and thereafter the dangerous dog shall be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. 
(f)  No owner of a dangerous dog shall be held criminally liable under this article for injuries inflicted by the owner's dog to any human being while on the owner's property. 
(Ord. No. 1990-1, § 8, 2-13-90) 
Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]

ARTICLE II. - MINIMUM HOUSING STANDARDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Water Well Standards Act of 1985, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-120; authority to adopt technical codes, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(12); access to and use of public facilities by physically handicapped persons, O.C.G.A. § 30-3-1 et seq.; ordinances relating to repair, closing and demolition of dwellings unfit for human habitation or buildings or structures that imperil health, safety or morals, O.C.G.A. § 36-61-11; authority to demolish structures where drug crimes are committed, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7; authority to repair, close or demolish unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7; county or municipal ordinances relating to unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9 et seq.; construction standards generally, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.; water efficiency requirements, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.; minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25; enforcement of minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26; flow-rate restrictions on plumbing fixtures, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-3; fire escapes in buildings, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-50. 

Sec. 18-31. - Code requirements and regulations. 
(a)  Pursuant to and in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25, all of the codes referenced in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20(9)(B)(i), as modified and amended pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20(9)(B)(ii), are hereby adopted by reference. 
(b)  The office of code enforcement for Sumter County shall maintain current and up-to-date copies of such codes on file the code enforcement office located in the Sumter County Courthouse and such codes shall be available for inspection and review by the public during regular business hours of the office of code enforcement. Such codes are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which this section shall take effect, the provisions of such codes shall be controlling within the unincorporated areas of Sumter County. 
(c)  The following shall be applicable to such codes: 
(1)  Said codes shall be enforced by office of code enforcement and, where applicable, the Chief of the Sumter County Fire Department, or his or her designee. 
(2)  Any reference to the term "board of adjustments and appeals" in said codes shall mean the Sumter County Zoning Board of Appeals as established by section 23.06, which shall have the same powers, duties and authority given to the board of adjustments and appeals in said incorporated codes. 
(3)  In hearing and deciding appeals from decision of the office of code enforcement or the chief of the fire department made pursuant to their authority under the state minimum codes, the rules of procedure of the adopted codes shall apply; provided, however, that the rules for appointment and terms of office for the appeals board in said adopted codes shall not be applicable to the zoning board of appeals. 
(d)  Any person charged with the violation of any provision of any of such codes, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. of 1-14-97, §§ 2-101—2-104; Ord. of 3-13-2012) 
Sec. 18-32. - Applicability. 
(a)  No person shall occupy nor shall let, rent or lease to another for occupancy any dwelling, roominghouse, dwelling unit, or rooming unit that does not comply with the minimum standards as set forth in the state minimum standard building codes. 
(b)  No person shall use for commercial occupancy or shall let to another for commercial occupancy any commercial building, room or space that does not comply with the minimum standards of the state minimum standard building codes. 
(c)  Specifically and specially exempt from this article are all sheds built for the storage of farm equipment, farm supplies and animals. A "shed" is defined as a constructed roof, open on at least one side, and with no electrical supplied to such shed, or not completely enclosed and electrical supply may not be furnished to such shed without compliance with the electrical code. A shed may not be used for residential/commercial use without complying with the building code. 
(d)  All persons performing work that is covered by the terms of this article, and who are required to have a valid license from a licensing agency of the state, shall have a valid license at the time of performing any work that is covered by the terms of this article, and shall exhibit the license to the county inspector upon request. No person who is required to be licensed by an agency of the state who does not have a license shall be issued a permit, nor perform any work or service that is covered by the terms of this article. 
(e)  Buildings that are 400 square feet in size and smaller that are to be used only for storage, or for parking of automobiles or equipment, are exempt from compliance with the building code. However, if such buildings are ever used for human occupancy, commercial use, they must comply with the building code. 
(Ord. of 1-14-97, § 3-104; Amd. of 6-9-98) 
Sec. 18-33. - Building permit and inspection fees. 
(a)  Building permit and construction and inspection fees shall be computed based upon the value of all structures and buildings being built. Such valuation shall be based upon the building valuation data as set by the county as of the time of application for the permit. Once a valuation of the structures and buildings is computed, such valuation shall be used in determining the actual building permit and inspection fees by reference to the schedule provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Building permit and construction and inspection fees for Sumter County are established as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. 
(c)  The building permit and construction and inspection fee for the moving of any building or structure into, out of or within the county shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. 
(d)  The building permit and construction and inspection fee for the demolition of a building or structure within the county shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. 
(e)  Building permits and associated building permit and construction and inspection fees shall also be required for all major renovations, repairs or remodeling undertaken under the same schedule of building permit and inspection fees as provided in this section; except no such building permit and inspection fee shall be required where the renovations, repairs or remodeling cost less than $2,000.00. 
(Ord. of 1-14-97, §§ 4-101—4-105) 
Sec. 18-34. - Electrical permit and inspection fees. 
There are hereby established electrical permit and inspection fees to be paid for work done within the county pursuant to section 18-31, and the fees for such electrical permits and inspections are as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. 
(Ord. of 1-14-97, § 5-101) 
Sec. 18-35. - Plumbing permit and inspection fees. 
There are hereby established plumbing permit and inspection fees to be paid for work done within the county pursuant to section 18-31, and the fees for such plumbing and inspection are as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. 
(Ord. of 1-14-97, § 6-101) 
Sec. 18-36. - Mechanical permit and inspection fees. 
There are hereby established mechanical permit and inspection fees for permits and inspections required or authorized by the state heating and air conditioning code (the Standard Mechanical Code) as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. 
(Ord. of 1-14-97, § 7-101) 
Sec. 18-37. - Inspections. 
The building inspector of the county shall be authorized to carry out such inspections and issue such permits as may be required by this article, but he may only issue such permits upon the payment of the fees as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. Such building inspector may make such inspections and investigations, notwithstanding any other provisions of this article providing for any other person or entity to make such inspections. 
(Ord. of 1-14-97, § 8-101) 
Sec. 18-38. - Fees and penalties. 
Permit and inspection fees required by this article shall be paid for prior to obtaining the permits provided for in this article. Where work for which a permit is required by this article is begun or initiated prior to obtaining the required permit, the fees required by this article shall be paid and, as a penalty for the failure to secure a permit, an additional amount equal to the original fee required shall be paid to the county; however, the payment of such penalty shall not relieve any person from otherwise complying with the requirements of this article in carrying out the work for which the permit is required, nor shall the payment of any such penalty relieve such person from any other penalties prescribed in this article relating to the work performed. 
(Ord. of 1-14-97, § 9-101) 
Sec. 18-39. - Work plan prerequisite to issuance. 
No building, other structure, or any construction or part thereof shall hereafter be constructed, enlarged or altered until a plan of the proposed work, together with a statement of the materials to be used, shall have been submitted to the county inspector. The applicant shall also submit an estimate of costs of all material to be used in the building. If the construction in accordance with the provisions contained in this article, the building inspector shall issue a permit for the proposed construction. 
(Ord. of 1-14-97, § 10-101) 
Sec. 18-40. - Removal of nonpermitted, nonconforming structures. 
Structures erected without a permit or not in conformity with this article shall be removed and the violator prosecuted. 
(Ord. of 1-14-97, § 10-102) 
Sec. 18-41. - Permit to precede work, compliance with technical codes required. 
No building shall be constructed, enlarged, altered or moved until a building permit has been obtained from the building inspector; and such official shall not issue such permit if the proposed construction, enlargement, alteration or moving would in any manner violate the housing, building, fire, plumbing, electrical, heating and air conditioning, zoning, or subdivision codes or regulations or any other codes or ordinances adopted by the county. 
(Ord. of 1-14-97, § 10-103) 
Sec. 18-42. - Application for permit. 
All applications for building permits shall be made in duplicate upon forms provided for this purpose by the office of the building inspector or county administrator with payment in the amount necessary to cover the cost of such building permit, together with all other exhibits and information as provided and set forth in section 18-31. 
(Ord. of 1-14-97, § 10-104) 
Sec. 18-43. - Persons responsible. 
All permits required under the minimum housing standards shall be obtained by the person actually doing the work, or the person in charge and responsible for the performance of the work. The owner of the property is not required to obtain the permit when the owner contracts with someone else to perform the work or oversee the work. The owner may obtain the permit when the owner is doing his own work, or when the owner is his own contractor. 
(Ord. of 1-14-97, § 10-105) 
Sec. 18-44. - Display of permit. 
All building permits called for in this article shall be displayed in a manner on the property under construction or on which repairs are being made so as to be visible from the public street closest to such construction site. 
(Ord. of 1-14-97, § 10-106) 
Sec. 18-45. - Penalty for violation. 
All persons violating any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. of 1-14-97, § 10-107) 
Sec. 18-46. - Persons in violation of article. 
Persons in violation of this article shall be issued a cease and desist order by the building inspector and shall pay a penalty of not less than $100.00 and not more than $1,000.00 for each day of noncompliance with this article after the cease and desist order has been issued. 
(Ord. of 1-14-97, § 10-108) 
Chapter 20 - CONDEMNATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Procedures for acquisitions by sale or donation of property with a low fair market value. 
When Sumter County seeks as a condemning authority to obtain a fee simple interest in real property, the acquisition by sale or donation of any such property with a low fair market value shall be conducted as follows: 
(a)  The board of commissioners may determine that an appraisal is unnecessary if the assessment of the property's value is uncomplicated and the anticipated value of the property is estimated at $10,000.00 or less, based on a review of available data. When an appraisal is determined to be unnecessary, the board of commissioners shall select a person with sufficient understanding of the local real estate market to prepare a value estimate. 
(b)  The board of commissioners may approve acquisitions exceeding the $10,000.00 threshold, up to a maximum of $25,000.00, without an appraisal if the property owner is offered the option of having the county appraise the property and declines an appraisal. If the property owner elects to have the county appraise the property, the county shall obtain an appraisal and shall not use the above-described procedures. 
(Ord. of 3-20-18, § 1) 
Secs. 20-2—20-30. - Reserved. 
Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; cable communications, ch. 26; mobile home parks, § 42-56 et seq.; taxation, ch. 62; utilities, ch. 70. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 22-1—22-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS, ITINERANT MERCHANTS AND ITINERANT VENDORS 

Sec. 22-31. - License required. 
It shall be unlawful for a transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor as defined in section 22-32 of this article to engage in such business within the county without first obtaining a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 5-11-93, § L-101; Ord. of 3-15-05) 
Sec. 22-32. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article a transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor is defined as any person, firm or corporation, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident of the county or not, who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares and merchandise within said county, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad box care, or boat, public room in hotels, lodging houses, apartments, shops, or any street, alley, or other place within the county, for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wards and merchandise, either at private sale or at public auction provided that such definition shall not be constructed to include any person, firm, or corporation who, while occupying such temporary location does not sell from stock in possession, but solely exhibits samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery. The person, firm, or corporation so engaged shall not be relieved from complying with the provisions of this article merely by reason of associating temporarily with any local dealer, trader merchant or auctioneer, or by conducting such transient business in connection with, as a part of, or in the name of any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer. Such definition shall not be construed to include any corporation or other entity which engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares, and merchandise within said county, and which is organized and operating as a non-profit corporation, and which has qualified for non-profit status under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. Such corporation or other entity shall confirm its non-profit status by producing documentary evidence at the request of the county clerk or other county official. 
(Ord. of 5-11-93, § L-102; Ord. of 3-15-05) 
Sec. 22-33. - Application. 
Applicants for license under this article, whether a person, firm or corporation, shall file a written sworn application signed by the applicant, if an individual, by all partners if a partnership, and by the president if a corporation, with the county clerk showing: 
(a)  The name or names of the person or persons having the management or supervision of applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it will be carried on in the county; the local address or addresses of such person or persons while engaged in such business; the permanent address or addresses of such person or persons; the capacity in which such person or persons will act (that is, whether as proprietor, agent or otherwise); the name and address of the person, firm or corporation for whose account the business will be carried on, if any; and if a corporation, under the laws of what state the same is incorporated; 
(b)  The fingerprints of the person or persons having the management or supervision of applicant's business or in lieu thereof, at least three letters of recommendation from reliable property owners in the county, certifying as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility, or other evidence which establishes to the satisfaction of the commissioners the good character and business responsibility of such person or persons; 
(c)  The place or places in the county where it is proposed to carry on applicant's business, and the length of time during which it is proposed that such business shall be conducted; 
(d)  The place or places, other than the permanent place of business of the applicant where applicant within the six months next preceding the date of said application conducted a transient business, stating the nature thereof and giving the post office and street address of any building or office in which such business was conducted; 
(e)  A statement of the nature, character and quality of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold or offered for sale by applicant in the county, the invoice value and quality of such goods, wares and merchandise, whether the same are proposed to be sold from stock in possession or from stock in possession and by sample; at auction by direct sale or by direct sale and by taking orders for future delivery; where the goods or property proposed to be sold are manufactured or produced and where such goods or products are located at the time said application is filed; 
(f)  A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers, and, if required by the county clerk, copies of all said advertising whether by hand bills, circular, newspaper advertising, or otherwise, shall be attached to said application as exhibits thereto; 
(g)  Whether or not the person or persons having the management or supervision of the applicant's business have been convicted of a crime, misdemeanor or the violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed therefor; 
(h)  Credentials from the person, firm or corporation for which the applicant proposes to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as such representative; and 
(i)  Such other reasonable information as to the identity or character of the person or persons having the management or supervision of applicant's business or the method or plan of doing such business as the county clerk may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this article in the protection of the public good. 
(Ord. of 5-11-93, § L-103; Ord. of 3-15-05) 
Sec. 22-34. - Investigation and insurance. 
Upon receipt of such application, the county clerk shall cause such investigation of such person's or persons' business responsibility or moral character to be made as he/she deems necessary to the protection of the public good. If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character and business responsibility are found to be unsatisfactory, the application shall be denied. If, as a result of the investigation, the character and business reputation appear to be satisfactory, the county clerk shall so certify in writing, and a license shall be issued by the county clerk. The county clerk shall keep a full record in his/her office of all licenses issued. Such license shall contain the number of the license, the date the same is issued, the nature of the business authorized to be carried on, the amount of the license fee paid, the expiration date of said license, the place where said business may be carried on under said license, and the name or names of the person or persons authorized to carry on the same. 
(Ord. of 5-11-93, § L-104; Ord. of 3-15-05) 
Sec. 22-35. - Bond. 
Before any license as provided by this article shall be issued for engaging in a transient or itinerant business as defined in section 22-32 of this article in the county, such applicant shall file with the county clerk a bond running to the county in the sum of $1,000.00 executed by the applicant, as principal, and two sureties upon which service of process may be made in the state; said bond to be approved by the county attorney, conditioned that the said applicant shall comply fully with all of the provisions of the ordinances of the County of Sumter and the statutes of the State of Georgia, regulating and concerning the sale of goods, wares, and merchandise, and will pay all judgments rendered against said applicant for any violation of said ordinances or statutes, or any of them, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against him by any person or persons for damage growing out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person transacting such business with such applicant, whether said misrepresentations or deceptions were made or practiced by the owners or by their servants, agents, or employees, either at the time of making the sale or through any advertisement of any character whatsoever, printed or circulated with reference to the goods, wares and merchandise sold or any part thereof. Action on the bond may be brought in the same of the county to the use of the aggrieved person. Such bond must be approved by the county attorney, both as to form, and as to the responsibility of the sureties thereon. 
(Ord. of 5-11-93, § L-105; Ord. of 3-15-05) 
Sec. 22-36. - Service of process. 
Before any license as herein provided shall be issued for engaging in business as an itinerant merchant, as herein defined, in the county, such applicant shall file with the county clerk an instrument nominating and appointing the county clerk, or the person performing the duties of such position, his true and lawful agent with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process for and on behalf of said applicant in respect to any matters connected with or arising out of the business transacted under said license and the bond given as required by section 22-35 of this article, or for the performance of the conditions of said bond or for any breach thereof, which said instrument shall also contain recitals to the effect that said applicant for said license consents and agrees that service of any notice or process may be made upon said agent, and when so made shall be taken and held to be as valid as if personally served upon the person or persons applying for the said license under this article, according to the law of this or any other state, and waiving all claim or right of error by reason of such acknowledgment of service or manner of service. Immediately upon service of process upon the county clerk, as herein provided, the county clerk shall send to the licensee at his last known address, by registered mail, a copy of said process. 
(Ord. of 5-11-93, § L-106; Ord. of 3-15-05) 
Sec. 22-37. - Exhibition of license. 
The license issued under this article shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business named therein. In the event that such person or persons applying for said license shall desire to do business in more than one place within the county, separate licenses may be issued for each place of business, and shall be posted conspicuously in each place of business. 
(Ord. of 5-11-93, § L-107; Ord. of 3-15-05) 
Sec. 22-38. - Fees. 
(a)  Licensees under this article shall pay a fee based upon use. The minimum fee shall be $100.00 dollars. An additional fee of $3.00 per every $1,000.00 of gross revenue shall be paid as provided in subsection (b) below. 
(b)  Every person conducting a business licensed under this article shall, on the first business day of each week, and upon discontinuance of business in the county, present to the clerk of said county, at the office of the board of commissioners of the county, a verified statement showing the total sales made during the preceding week and shall pay to the county clerk the amount of license fee hereinbefore provided, for sales made during the previous week. The county clerk and any other officer designated by him/her shall have power and authority to enter any store, building, or any other place in which such temporary business may be conducted at any time during business hours for ascertaining the amount of sales made and shall at all times have access to the books of such business. 
(Ord. of 5-11-93, § L-108; Ord. of 3-15-05) 
Sec. 22-39. - Transfer. 
No license shall be transferred without written consent from the board of commissioners as evidenced by endorsement on the face of the license by the county clerk showing to whom the license is transferred and the date of the transfer. 
(Ord. of 5-11-93, § L-109; Ord. of 3-15-05) 
Sec. 22-40. - Loud noises and speaking devices. 
No licensee under this article, nor anyone in his behalf shall shout, make any outcry, blow a horn, ring a bell or use any other sound device including any loud speaking radio or amplifying system upon any of the streets, alleys, parks or other public places of the said county or upon any private premises in the said county where sound of sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom capable of being plainly heard upon the streets, avenues, alleys or parks or other public places for the purpose of attracting attention to any goods, wards or merchandise which such licensee proposes to sell. 
(Ord. of 5-11-93, § L-110; Ord. of 3-15-05) 
Sec. 22-41. - Duty of sheriff to enforce. 
It shall be the duty of the sheriff of the county to examine all places of business and persons in their respective territories subject to the provisions of this article, to determine if this article has been complied with and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Ord. of 5-11-93, § L-111; Ord. of 3-15-05) 
Sec. 22-42. - Records. 
The county clerk shall deposit the record of fingerprints of licensee, together with a license number, with the sheriff; the sheriff shall report to the chief clerk any complaints against any person licensed under the provisions of this article and any conviction for violation of this article; the county clerk shall keep a record of all such licenses and of such complaints and violations. 
(Ord. of 5-11-93, § L-112; Ord. of 3-15-05) 
Sec. 22-43. - Revocation of license. 
(a)  The permits and licenses issued pursuant to this article may be revoked by the Board of Commissioners of Sumter County, after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license; 
(2)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with the selling of goods, wares or merchandise; 
(3)  Any violation of this article; 
(4)  Conviction of the licensee of any felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or 
(5)  Conducting the business licensed under this article in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or as to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(b)  Notice of hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee, at his/her last known address, at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(Ord. of 5-11-93, § L-113; Ord. of 3-15-05) 
Sec. 22-44. - Appeal. 
Any person aggrieved by the decision of the county clerk in regard to the denial of application for license as provided for in section 22-34 of this article or in connection with the revocation of a license as provided for in section 22-43 of this article, shall have the right to appeal to the Board of Commissioners of Sumter County. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the board of commissioners within 14 days after notice of the decision by the county clerk has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement setting forth the grounds for the appeal. The board of commissioners shall set the time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to such person in the same manner as provided in section 22-43 of this article for notice of hearing on revocation. The order of the board of commissioners on such appeal shall be final. 
(Ord. of 5-11-93, § L-114; Ord. of 3-15-05) 
Sec. 22-45. - Expiration of license. 
All licenses issued under the provisions of this article shall expire 90 days after the date of issuance thereof unless a prior date is fixed therein. 
(Ord. of 5-11-93, § L-115; Ord. of 3-15-05) 
Sec. 22-46. - Penalty. 
Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine in an amount not less than three times the total license fee paid by the licensee pursuant to section 22-38 of this article or by imprisonment not to exceed 60 days or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. of 5-11-93, § L-116; Ord. of 3-15-05)

Chapter 30 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— § 1 of an ordinance adopted Feb. 16, 2016, repealed the former Ch. 30, §§ 30-31—30-36, and enacted a new chapter as set out herein. The former Ch. 30 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from §§ I—VI of a resolution adopted Sep. 9, 1991. 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; disaster recovery commission, § 2-156 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 30-1—30-29. - Reserved 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 30-30. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to protect the health, safety, and general welfare of the county's citizens during times of a local or state declared emergency. 
(Ord. of 2-16-16, § 1) 
Sec. 30-31. - Definitions. 
When used in this article, the following words, terms, and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
Board of commissioners means the county board of commissioners. 
Chair means the chair of the county board of commissioners and shall expressly include any commissioner authorized to serve as acting chair as provided by law. 
County means Sumter County, a political subdivision of the State of Georgia. 
Emergency management means the preparation for and carrying out of all emergency and disaster functions to prevent, minimize, and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies or disasters, or the imminent threat thereof, whether of manmade or natural origin, other than those for which military forces or state and federal agencies are primarily responsible. These functions include, but are not limited to: fire and rescue services, law enforcement services, medical and health services, engineering services, warning and communication services, protection against the effects of radiological, chemical, or special weapons, evacuation of persons from stricken areas, emergency welfare services, emergency transportation services, plant protection, shelter, temporary restoration of public utility services, other functions related to the civilian population, and all other activities necessary or incidental to emergency and disaster preparedness. 
Georgia Emergency Management Act means O.C.G.A., tit. 38, ch. 3, as amended from time to time. 
Locally declared emergency means an emergency declared by the county board of commissioners pursuant to section 30-34 of this article enacting some or all of the local emergency powers addressed in this article. 
Participating municipalities means those municipalities within the county participating in the county's emergency management agency. 
State declared emergency or state of emergency means a declaration of an actual, threatened, or impending emergency or disaster by the Governor of the State of Georgia. A declaration of emergency by the Governor may enact some or all of the emergency powers, local or otherwise, addressed in this article. 
(Ord. of 2-16-16, § 1) 
Sec. 30-32. - Establishment of emergency management agency. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 38-3-27 and as otherwise provided by law, there is hereby established the county emergency management agency. 
(Ord. of 2-16-16, § 1) 
Sec. 30-33. - Emergency management director. 
(a)  Appointment of emergency management director. The board of commissioners shall nominate a local emergency management director for the entire county to the state's director of emergency management for approval in accordance with the Georgia Emergency Management Act. The nominee shall satisfy the minimum legal qualifications for appointment and service established by the Georgia Emergency Management Act. The local emergency management director shall thereafter be subject to the direction and control of the board of commissioners and serve at its pleasure. 
(b)  The local emergency management director shall appoint a deputy emergency management director in accordance with the Georgia Emergency Management Act or as otherwise permitted by law. If, despite reasonable efforts, the local emergency management director is unavailable and exigent circumstances require immediate action to avoid injury to person or property, the deputy emergency management director shall serve as acting emergency management director and shall have the same power and authority of the emergency management director arising under this article or otherwise provided by law. 
(c)  Duties of emergency management director. The emergency management director shall have the following duties: 
(1)  To represent the governing officials of the county and the participating municipalities therein on matters pertaining to emergency management. 
(2)  To assist county and city officials in organizing their departments for emergency operations. 
(3)  To develop, in conjunction with the county and city departments and officials, the county's plan for emergency and disaster functions as set forth in this article. Such plan shall be in compliance with the state emergency operations plan, and, after collaboration with the municipalities located in the county, shall be submitted for approval to the board of commissioners and thereafter to the state emergency management agency. 
(4)  To operate and maintain the local emergency management agency and carry out the day-to-day administration of the county's emergency management program, including the submission of required reports to the state emergency management agency. 
(5)  To submit reports as required by the county's governing officials in keeping with good management practices, including, but not limited to, financial records and daily activity records. 
(6)  To obtain and maintain, with the authority of governing officials, a facility to be used as the county's emergency operating center. 
(7)  To coordinate the activities of the county's emergency operating center staff during periods of an emergency, under the supervision of the county's governing officials. 
(Ord. of 2-16-16, § 1) 
Sec. 30-34. - Declaration of local emergency. 
(a)  Grant of authority to declare local emergency. The Board of Commissioners may declare a local emergency for the county in the event of an actual, threatened, or impending disaster or emergency that may result in the large-scale loss of life or injury, property damage, destruction, or a major disruption of routine community, business, or governmental affairs or operations in the county and which is of sufficient severity and magnitude to warrant assistance by federal, state, or local departments and agencies to supplement the efforts of available public and private resources. If a quorum of the board of commissioners is unavailable despite reasonable efforts and exigent circumstances require immediate action to avoid injury to person or property, the chair of the board of commissioners may declare a local emergency. Further, if despite reasonable efforts, the chair of the board of commissioners is unavailable and exigent circumstances require immediate action to avoid injury to person or property, the county administrator may declare a local emergency. Any such declaration of local emergency by the chair or county administrator may be rescinded or repealed by a majority vote of a quorum of the board of commissioners. 
(b)  Form of declaration of local emergency. Upon a declaration of local emergency, an official "declaration of local emergency" shall be adopted as outlined in subpart (a) of this section and filed with the county clerk. The declaration shall be communicated to the citizens of the affected area using the most effective and efficient means reasonably available. The declaration shall state the nature of the emergency or disaster and the conditions that require the declaration. A sample form of a declaration is included in Appendix A to this article. 
(c)  Request for state assistance. Consistent with a declaration of local emergency, the board of commissioners may ask the Governor to provide assistance to the county if it does not have adequate capacity to respond to the disaster or emergency such that state assistance is necessary to supplement local efforts to save lives, prevent injury, protect property, protect public health or safety, or avert or lessen the threat of a disaster. 
(d)  Continuance. The declaration of local emergency shall continue until the board of commissioners passes a written resolution that emergency conditions no longer exist. 
(e)  Effect of declaration of emergency; activation of emergency operations plan. A declaration of emergency by the Governor or a declaration of local emergency by the board of commissioners shall automatically activate the county's emergency operations plan and shall be the authority for deployment of personnel, use of any force to which the plan applies, and use or distribution of any supplies, equipment, or materials assembled, stockpiled, or arranged to be made available pursuant to the Georgia Emergency Management Act, the local emergency operations plan, and any other applicable laws. Upon a state declared emergency or a locally declared emergency: 
(1)  The local emergency management director shall have the legal authority to exercise the powers and to discharge the duties conferred upon the local emergency management agency, including the implementation of the emergency operations plan, coordination of emergency responses of public and private agencies and organizations, coordination of recovery efforts with state and federal officials, and inspection of emergency and disaster sites; and 
(2)  In responding to the emergency and surveying the damages caused thereby, the local emergency management director or his or her designee shall be authorized to enter at a reasonable time and in a reasonable manner any property, public or private, for the purpose of evaluating sites related to emergency management functions to protect the public's health, safety, or welfare; and 
(3)  The local emergency management director shall be authorized to execute a right of entry, license, or agreement on behalf of the county for the use of property for emergency purposes. Any such right of entry, license, or agreement shall be presented for ratification at the next meeting of the board of commissioners. A sample form of a right of entry, license, and agreement is included in Appendix B to this article; and 
(4)  No person shall refuse entry or access to any authorized representative or agent of the county who presents a directive of the emergency management director authorizing them to request entry to property for the purpose of evaluating sites related to emergency management functions to protect the public's health, safety, or welfare. No person shall obstruct, hamper, or interfere with any such authorized representative or agent performing official duties. 
(Ord. of 2-16-16, § 1; Ord. of 11-13-18(3), § 1) 
Sec. 30-35. - Emergency powers. 
(a)  Emergency powers. During the effective period of a declaration of a state or local emergency, the board of commissioners is authorized to implement local emergency measures reasonably necessary to protect life and property. The emergency powers of the board of commissioners and mayors of any incorporated areas shall include, but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  To enforce all rules, laws, and regulations relating to emergency management and to assume direct operational control over all emergency management resources; 
(2)  To seize any private property or to take it for temporary use for the protection of the public; 
(3)  To sell, lend, or distribute all or any property or supplies among the inhabitants of the county and to maintain a strict accounting of property or supplies distributed and for funds received for such property or supplies; 
(4)  To perform and exercise such other functions and duties and take such emergency actions as may be necessary to promote and secure the safety, protection, and well-being of the inhabitants of the county; 
(5)  To direct and compel the evacuation of all or part of the population from any stricken or threatened area for the preservation of life or other disaster mitigation, response, or recovery; 
(6)  To prescribe routes, modes of transportation, and destinations in connection with evacuation; 
(7)  To provide temporary emergency housing, emergency shelters, or emergency medical shelters; 
(8)  To transfer or modify the direction, personnel, or functions of any of the county's departments for the purpose of performing or facilitating emergency services; 
(9)  To utilize all available resources of the county and subordinate agencies over which the county has budgetary control as reasonably necessary to respond to the emergency or disaster; 
(10)  To utilize public property to cope with the emergency or disaster or when necessary for the protection of lives, health, welfare, or property; 
(11)  To suspend any ordinance, resolution, order, rule, policy, or regulation prescribing the procedures for conduct of the county's business, if strict compliance would prevent, hinder, or delay actions necessary to cope with the emergency or disaster, provided that such suspension shall provide for the minimum deviation from the requirements under the circumstances and further provided that, when practicable and applicable, relevant experts shall be retained or consulted to avoid adverse effects resulting from such suspension; and 
(12)  To perform and exercise such other functions, powers, and duties as may be deemed necessary to promote and secure the safety and protection of the civilian population, including individuals with household pets and service animals prior to, during, and following a major disaster or emergency. 
(b)  Additional powers and authority. The powers and authorities granted in this article to the local emergency management agency and its director shall be in addition to and in no manner construed as limiting any powers or authority established by the Georgia Emergency Management Act or as otherwise provided by law. 
(Ord. of 2-16-16, § 1) 
Sec. 30-36. - Assignment of emergency functions. 
The county emergency management agency shall be established around existing departments of the county and any municipalities located therein, and the emergency functions outlined in this article, unless otherwise directed by the emergency management director, are assigned as follows: 

 
Heads of departments listed above are responsible for developing appropriate annexes to the local emergency operations plan for their assigned emergency functions. Such annexes shall be submitted to the local emergency management director for inclusion in the local emergency operations plan. 
(Ord. of 2-16-16, § 1) 
Sec. 30-37. - Enforcement and remedies. 
(a)  Enforcement. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-4 and as otherwise provided by law, the county sheriff's office, the police department of any affected municipalities, the county emergency management director, and any other person authorized by law shall have the authority to enforce the provisions of this article and any rules, orders, or regulations implemented or adopted by the board of commissioners during a declared emergency. 
(b)  Injunctive relief. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-5 and as otherwise provided by law, in addition to the remedies prescribed in this section, the local emergency management director is authorized to obtain an injunction to restrain violations of the Georgia Emergency Management Act, this article, and any laws, rules, regulations, or orders implemented or adopted by the board of commissioners during a declared emergency. 
(Ord. of 2-16-16, § 1) 
Sec. 30-38. - Authority to waive procedures and fee structures. 
(a)  County business. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-54, when it becomes imprudent, inexpedient, or impossible to conduct the affairs of the county at the regular or usual place(s) due to an emergency or disaster, the board of commissioners may meet at any place within or outside the territorial limits of the county on the call of the chair or any two members. At such time, the board of commissioners shall by ordinance, resolution, or other means establish and designate an alternate or substitute site as its emergency temporary location where all or any part of the county's public business may be transacted and conducted during the emergency or disaster. 
(b)  Public works contracts. Upon a state or local declaration of emergency, the board of commissioners may enter contracts for public works without letting such contracts out to the lowest, responsible bidder and without advertising and posting notification of such contract as otherwise required by law; provided, however, that the emergency must be of such nature that immediate action is required and necessary for the protection of the public health, safety, and welfare. Any public works contract entered pursuant to this subsection shall be presented for ratification at the next meeting of the board of commissioners and entered on the minutes of the county as soon as practical with the nature of the emergency described therein in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 36-91-22. 
(c)  Purchasing. Upon a state or local declaration of emergency, the board of commissioners may suspend the county's purchasing ordinances, regulations, or policies. County officials shall continue to seek the best prices to the extent reasonably possible. 
(d)  Code enforcement. Upon a state or local declaration of emergency, the board of commissioners may by resolution or declaration temporarily suspend enforcement of the county's code of ordinances, or any portion thereof, if the emergency is of such nature that immediate action outside the code is required, such suspension is consistent with the protection of the public health, safety, and welfare, and such suspension is not in violation of any federal or state statutes or regulations. 
(e)  Fees. Unless section 30-39 is enacted or implemented, upon a state or local declaration of emergency, the board of commissioners may temporarily reduce or suspend any permit or application fees and any other rate structures to encourage the rebuilding of the areas impacted by the disaster or emergency. The term "fees" include fees or rates charged by the county for building permits, land disturbance permits, zoning applications, special land use permits, temporary land use permits, or other fees relating to the reconstruction, repair, or cleanup of areas impacted by the disaster or emergency. 
(f)  Temporary dwellings. Upon a state or local declaration of emergency, the board of commissioners or its authorized officials may issue temporary permits for mobile homes, trailers, recreational vehicles, or other temporary dwelling structures or parks in any zoning district, even though not otherwise permitted by the county's Code of Ordinances, provided that such temporary dwellings or parks are designed by a qualified individual and the plans are approved by the county health department. The temporary permit shall not exceed six months in duration. Upon a finding of continuing hardship, the board of commissioners may extend any such temporary permit for an additional six months. Upon expiration of a temporary permit, the temporary dwelling must be removed or brought into compliance with the applicable codes and ordinances. 
(Ord. of 2-16-16, § 1) 
Sec. 30-39. - Registration of building and repair services. 
(a)  This section shall become effective only upon a state or local declaration of emergency and a declaration or resolution by the board of commissioners expressly stating this section is in effect. The board of commissioners may terminate the effectiveness of this section by resolution. 
(b)  In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-56, before building, constructing, repairing, renovating, or making improvements to any real property, including dwellings, homes, buildings, structures, or fixtures within the unincorporated area of the county located in a declared emergency or disaster zone, any person, firm, partnership, corporation, or other entity not actively licensed through the county must register with the code enforcement office and obtain an emergency building permit, which shall be posted at the work site. 
(c)  The fee for registering pursuant to this section shall be established by the county's code enforcement office. Registration is not transferable. The cost of an emergency building permit shall be equal to the cost for a building permit under existing ordinances in non-emergent circumstances. 
(d)  Any person, partnership, corporation, or other entity registering pursuant to this section shall complete an application providing the following information under oath: 
(1)  Applicant's full name; 
(2)  Applicant's permanent address and phone number; 
(3)  Applicant's Social Security number or federal Employment Identification Number; 
(4)  If applicant is a corporation, the state and date of incorporation; 
(5)  Tag registration information for each vehicle to be used in the business; 
(6)  List of cities and counties where the applicant has conducted business within the past 12 months; 
(7)  Georgia sales tax number or authorization; 
(8)  Georgia business license number, if required; 
(9)  Copy of license from Secretary of State, if required; 
(10)  A signed and sworn affidavit verifying the applicant's legal presence in the United States as required by O.C.G.A. § 50-36-1; and 
(11)  At least one secure and verifiable document as defined in O.C.G.A. § 50-36-2. 
(Ord. of 2-16-16, § 1) 
Sec. 30-40. - Closed or restricted areas and curfews during emergency. 
(a)  The section shall only become effective upon a state or local declaration of emergency and a declaration or resolution of the board of commissioners expressly stating this section is in effect. The board of commissioners may terminate the effectiveness of this section by resolution. 
(b)  To preserve, protect, or sustain the life, health, welfare, or safety of persons or their property within a designated area under a declaration of emergency, it shall be unlawful for any person to travel, loiter, wander, or stroll in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, lanes, parks, or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots, or any other place during a declared state or local emergency between the hours specified by the board of commissioners. 
(c)  To promote order, protect lives, minimize the potential for looting and other crimes, and facilitate recovery operations during an emergency, the board of commissioners may impose reentry restrictions on designated areas. 
(d)  In the discretion of the emergency management director, the provisions of this section shall not apply to authorized and essential persons acting in the following capacities: 
(1)  Law enforcement personnel; 
(2)  Health care providers; 
(3)  Personnel of the county; 
(4)  National Guard or federal military personnel; 
(5)  Firefighters; 
(6)  Emergency response personnel; 
(7)  Personnel or volunteers of the county emergency management agency and any other disaster relief agency or non-profit authorized by the emergency management director; 
(8)  Utility repair crews; and 
(9)  Persons as designated on a list compiled by the emergency management director. 
(Ord. of 2-16-16, § 1) 
Sec. 30-41. - Prohibition on overcharging for goods, materials, services, and housing during state of emergency. 
To preserve, protect, or sustain the life, health, or safety of persons or their property, it shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation located or doing business in the county to overcharge for any goods materials, services, or housing sold within the county during a declared state or local emergency or subsequent recovery period. "Overcharging" means charging prices for goods, materials, services, or housing which are substantially in excess of the customary charges or, in applicable cases, substantially in excess of the supplier's or provider's costs for such goods, materials, services, or housing. A rebuttable presumption of overcharging shall arise from proof of a substantial increase in the price at which goods, materials, housing or services were offered in the usual course of business immediately prior to the onset of the emergency. 
(Ord. of 2-16-16, § 1) 
Sec. 30-42. - Volunteers. 
Other than officers and employees of the county and municipalities located therein, all persons performing emergency functions pursuant to this article may serve with or without compensation. While engaged in such emergency functions, volunteers duly assigned by the emergency management agency or in accordance with the local emergency operations plan shall have the same immunities as county and municipal officers and employees, regardless of whether they receive compensation for their services. Nothing in this section is intended to limit any other volunteers' immunities as provided by law. 
(Ord. of 2-16-16, § 1) 
Sec. 30-43. - Regulation continued in effect. 
All ordinances, resolutions, motions, and orders pertaining to civil defense, homeland security, emergency management, and disaster relief that are not in conflict with this article shall at all times remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. of 2-16-16, § 1) 
Sec. 30-44. - Penalties. 
Any person violating any provision of this article, or any rule, order, or regulation issued or implemented pursuant to this article, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. of 2-16-16, § 1)

WHEREAS, Sumter County, a political subdivision of the State of Georgia, has experienced an actual, threatened, or impending disaster or emergency that may result in the large-scale loss of life or injury, or property damage, destruction, or a major disruption of routine community, business, or governmental affairs or operations in the County and which is of sufficient severity and magnitude to warrant assistance by federal, state, or local departments and agencies to supplement the efforts of available public and private resources; 
WHEREAS, the nature of the disaster or emergency is [insert description of event] (hereafter "Emergency") which occurred on or about [insert date]; and 
WHEREAS, the Governor of the State of Georgia [has/has not] declared a state of emergency for Sumter County; and 
WHEREAS, in the judgment of the Sumter County Board of Commissioners, upon advice of the Sumter County Emergency Management Agency, the Emergency requires extraordinary and immediate action for the protection of the public health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of Sumter County, including, but not limited to individuals with household pets and service animals; and 
WHEREAS, to prevent or minimize injury to people and damage to property resulting from this Emergency, immediate action is required; and 
WHEREAS, the Sumter County Board of Commissioners is authorized to declare a local state of emergency pursuant to the Georgia Emergency Management Act, the Sumter County Code of Ordinances, and other applicable laws.

Chapter 34 - ENVIRONMENT[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 34-1—34-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOIL EROSION, SEDIMENTATION AND POLLUTION CONTROL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. of 10-19-2010(1), amended Art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. II, §§ 34-31—34-40, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. of 6-15-04; Ord. of 7-11-95, §§ I—VII. See also the Code Comparative Table.
