Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 50-1. - Road and street identification signs. 
(a)  Road and street identification signs will be placed at all intersections of public roads, and at the intersection of private roads that intersect with the public roads of the county, but in no event will the county erect road or street signs on interior private roads, or on roads or streets that a developer is required to erect in conformity with the subdivision ordinance of the county or any other ordinance of the county governing the identification of roads and streets in the county. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a person authorized by the county, to remove or damage a road or street sign erected by the county and such person shall be prosecuted under the penalties provided for in the ordinances of the county or under the laws of the state, as the commissioners deem best. 
(Ord. of 11-21-00) 
Secs. 50-2—50-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NAMING OF PUBLIC AND PRIVATE ROADS 

Sec. 50-31. - Legislative findings. 
In accordance with the power and authority vested in the board of commissioners the board of commissioners has determined that it is in the best interest of the health, welfare and safety of the citizens of the county, that this article be enacted to govern, regulate and control the naming of county roads so that there will not be two roads in the county known by the same name and to adopt procedures for the assignment of names of all county roads, assignment of addresses and for other purposes. 
(Ord. of 5-9-95, preamble) 
Sec. 50-32. - Adoption of official road name list. 
The board of commissioners will adopt an official county road name list, and the names of all roads on that road list shall be the official name of each road in the county. However, the road may not be a road that has not been accepted by the county. 
(Ord. of 5-9-95, § 1) 
Sec. 50-33. - Approval of official road name list. 
The board of commissioners shall approve an official road name list identifying all the roads in the county, and the roads shall be known by the names identified on that official road name list. 
(Ord. of 5-9-95, § 2) 
Sec. 50-34. - Naming of roads by board of commissioners. 
All roads, public and private, in the county will be named by the board of commissioners. Recommended names of roads may be submitted to the board of commissioners. The names must be approved by the board of commissioners before being officially added to the official road name list. 
(Ord. of 5-9-95, § 3) 
Sec. 50-35. - Notification to county inspector. 
(a)  Before any road name is accepted by the board of commissioners, the individual desiring to name a road must notify the county inspector of the proposed name of each road to be named, and also give to the county inspector an alternate name if the primary name is not accepted. 
(b)  The county inspector shall cause the official road name list of the county to be searched to determine if there is a county road on the official county road name list with the same name as the name requested for the new road. 
(c)  The county inspector shall notify the individual wishing to dedicate the road that the name suggested is, or is not, the name of a road that is currently used. If the name is one that is already used, another name will be required to be submitted for the road. 
(d)  If the name of the new road is not being used, the county inspector shall inform the board of commissioners of the new name and that it is not a duplicate road name. 
(Ord. of 5-9-95, § 4) 
Sec. 50-36. - Action of board of commissioners. 
The board of commissioners may accept the road with the name offered, or, at their discretion, may refuse the name offered and change the name of the road to a name that is acceptable to the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. of 5-9-95, § 5) 
Sec. 50-37. - Addresses. 
In order to promote and maintain an orderly, structured, coherent address plan, all residences, businesses, structures and other such facilities as may have need for an address on and along public and private roads in the unincorporated areas of the county shall have an address assigned by the county inspector or other duly appointed designee of the county administrator of the county. Addresses shall be assigned in conformance with the established county addressing plan for the unincorporated areas of the county that is in place as of May 9, 1995, the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this section derives. Persons needing an address shall contact the county inspector's office for such assignment. 
(Ord. of 5-9-95, § 6; Ord. of 11-13-18(3), § 1) 
Secs. 50-38—50-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HEAVY HAULING 

Sec. 50-71. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to regulate the use of heavy equipment, machinery and vehicles on county roads and rights-of-way. 
(Ord. of 12-12-95, preamble) 
Sec. 50-72. - Compliance with article required. 
Any person using a county right-of-way in carrying out his business by loading, transporting or unloading materials of any nature in excess of 25 tons, whether on the road surface or a county right-of-way, or crossing the unpaved portion of the right-of-way, including ditches or embankments, shall comply with the terms and conditions of this article. 
(Ord. of 12-12-95, preamble) 
Sec. 50-73. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Access site means any temporary roadway, drive, structure, fill or device, existing or constructed, that is used or employed for the purpose of crossing, travel upon or use of county road rights-of-way. 
County right-of-way means the shoulder, front slope, ditch, drain and back slope, facility or any appurtenance of any county road. 
County road means any county-owned or county-maintained highway, road, street, avenue, drive, detour or other way open to the public and intended or used for the passage of motor vehicles. 
Heavy equipment machinery and vehicles means all devices in, upon or by which any person or property may be transported or drawn, including but not limited to semitrailers, trailers, tractors and truck-tractors; however, vehicles in use immediately for the control or extinguishing of wildfires shall be exempt from this definition. 
Loading and unloading shall have its everyday meaning but also shall include any activity known as harvesting, mining of any product or material. 
Logger means a person in the business of or process of cutting timber from a tract of land and loading and hauling the timber to another site. 
Operations means those activities contemplated by this article, including the loading or transporting of raw materials such as stone, timber, oil, fill dirt, produce and kaolin. 
Operator means any individual, partnership, corporation, association, or private organization or any character, and the officer's agents and employees thereof carrying out the activities contemplated by this article. 
(Ord. of 12-12-95, § 1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 50-74. - Application for hauling. 
For each separate tract of land from which the hauling will take place, the applicant shall fill out an application, which at a minimum shall provide: 
(1)  His name, address and telephone number. 
(2)  The name of the owner of each tract. 
(3)  The approximate location of the site for access to county roads for each tract. 
(Ord. of 12-12-95, § 2) 
Sec. 50-75. - Inspection; installation of required culverts. 
(a)  Upon receipt of the information required by section 50-74, the county public works director (CPWD) shall, within two days, inspect each such site to determine if a culvert is required to provide ingress and egress from the county road to the tract and, if so, the length and diameter of the culvert. Should a culvert be required, it shall be installed at the expense of the applicant under the supervision of the CPWD. Applicants shall have the right to remove any culvert installed by them upon completion of the tree removal. 
(b)  After the initial inspections, the CPWD will complete the condition of road report and send a copy to the applicant and a copy to the county administrator of the county (CA). The CPWD will keep the original. 
(Ord. of 12-12-95, § 3; Ord. of 11-13-18(3), § 1) 
Sec. 50-76. - Road entrance. 
The entrance onto the county road from the loading operation shall be of sufficient width so that the hauling trucks entering the road will have to turn as little as possible on the pavement. 
(Ord. of 12-12-95, § 4) 
Sec. 50-77. - Requirements for removal of trees. 
During the removal of trees from a tract, the logger shall: 
(1)  Conduct all loading of logs at a site off the county right-of-way and behind the established ditch line maintained by the county. 
(2)  Refrain from loading or skidding any logs upon or across the county's right-of-way. 
(3)  Keep ditches clear of debris and residue so as to not interfere with proper drainage. 
(4)  Keep the road adjacent to the site clean and serviceable at all times to accommodate the passing public, emergency vehicles, school buses, mail carriers, etc. 
(Ord. of 12-12-95, § 5) 
Sec. 50-78. - Mud to be kept off roadway. 
Haulers shall use necessary means to prevent trucks and other equipment from transporting mud from the site on the adjacent roadway to such an extent as creates a danger to the passing public. 
(Ord. of 12-12-95, § 6) 
Sec. 50-79. - Notice of completion; inspection of site. 
(a)  Haulers shall notify the clerk of the board of commissioners within three days of the completion of loading removal or tree removal at each site, whereupon the CPWD shall inspect the site. Should the CPWD determine that the road and right-of-way is in as good condition as prior to the commencement of the loading removal or tree removal, the applicant's responsibility for that tract shall be terminated. If corrective repairs are necessary, the reasonable cost thereof shall be paid by the applicant within 30 days of written notification. 
(b)  The CPWD shall inspect each site within three days of receiving notice of completion by the applicant, and shall fill out a condition of road report and shall file the original with the CA, send a copy to the CA, and keep a copy for himself. The CA shall forward a copy of the condition of road report to the applicant. 
(c)  If the applicant disagrees with the final finding as stated on the final road report by the CPWD, the applicant can appeal the decision to the board of commissioners, which shall be heard at their next regular meeting. If the applicant disagrees with the decision of the board of commissioners, the applicant shall make such fact known by filing a written appeal; and within five days an arbitration board shall be impaneled. The arbitration board shall consist of three individuals; one person selected by the board of commissioners, one person selected by the applicant, and one person mutually agreed upon by the two persons selected. Once the arbitration board has been selected, each party shall submit his case to the arbitration board on a date and time certain to be set by the arbitration board within ten days of being appointed. The arbitration board shall make their final decision no later than 30 days after the date of the final hearing. The decision of the arbitration board shall be final. 
(Ord. of 12-12-95, § 7; Ord. of 11-13-18(3), § 1) 
Sec. 50-80. - Stop work orders. 
The board of commissioners hereby authorizes the CPWD to order all hauling operations to cease if it is determined that a hauler is failing to comply with this article. 
(Ord. of 12-12-95, § 8) 
Sec. 50-81. - Penalty. 
Prosecutions for violations of this article shall be upon citation as provided in O.C.G.A. § 15-10-63 or upon accusation of the county attorney or such other attorney as the board shall designate. The violator may be required to reimburse the county for the expense incurred by the county in repair work the violator was responsible for performing, plus a penalty of up to $500.00 for each separate violation. 
(Ord. of 12-12-95, § 9) 
Secs. 50-82—50-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ROAD AND STREET SPECIFICATIONS 

Sec. 50-116. - Provisions saved from repeal. 
The resolution dated June 14, 1983, which specified requirements for acceptance of roads and streets by the board of commissioners, is not repealed and shall continue in full force and effect pending a revision of the subject matter by the county. 
Chapter 54 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 34; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 42; utilities, ch. 70. 
State Law reference— Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; local, multijurisdictional and regional solid waste plans, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-31.1; scrap tire disposal restrictions, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-40.1; yard trimmings disposal restrictions, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-40.2; Litter Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-40 et seq.; authorization to provide garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2); transporting garbage or waste across state or county boundaries without permission, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-16; littering highways, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-249; transportation of biomedical waste, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-253.1; solid waste management education program, establishment of Georgia Clean and Beautiful Advisory Committee and Interagency Council on Solid Waste Management, O.C.G.A. § 50-8-7.3. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Solid waste management plan adopted. 
The Multi-Jurisdictional Ten-Year Solid Waste Management Plan for Sumter County adopted March 8, 1994, by the board of commissioners and as amended by ordinance dated August 8, 1995, is adopted as the solid waste management plan for the county in accordance with the Solid Waste Management Act of 1990 as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 12-8-31.1. 
(Ord. of 3-8-94; Ord. of 8-8-95) 
Secs. 54-2—54-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WASTE MANAGEMENT AND LITTER CONTROL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 54-31. - Purpose. 
It is the purpose of this article to provide for the healthy and sanitary management and disposal of solid waste in the county to ensure the public health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the county and encourage recycling of selected material through education and voluntary compliance. It shall apply to the preparation, storage, collection and disposal of all solid waste and shall prohibit unsanitary conditions in the unincorporated areas of the county. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, preamble) 
Sec. 54-32. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Ashes means the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke or other combustible materials. 
Brown goods means furniture, mattresses and similar residential or office furnishings. 
Building material means any material defined as, but not limited to, lumber, brick, block, stone, carpet, plumbing materials, plaster, concrete, roofing, floor tile, gutters or other substances accumulated as a result of the construction of or repairs or additions to structures or accessory structures or the demolition of such. 
Business trash means any accumulation of paper, cardboard, packaging materials, rags or accumulations other than garbage or household trash, which result from the operation of stores, offices, and similar business or commercial enterprises. 
Commercial establishment means any hotel, motel, restaurant, business, public or semipublic establishment of any kind, excluding industrial establishments. An operation conducted from a residence requiring a business license is a commercial establishment for purposes of this article. 
Commercial solid waste means all types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses and other nonmanufacturing activities, excluding industrial waste. 
Container means a refuse receptacle. 
County administrator (CA) means the county administrator or his duly authorized representative. 
County transfer station means the transfer station located at 361 McMath Mill Road in the county and operated by the solid waste authority of Crisp County. 
Disposal site means an area, location, tract of land or facility used or intended to be used for the disposal of solid waste, putrescible waste, or other waste. 
Garbage means the by-product resulting from the growing, harvesting, processing, handling, preparation, cooking or consumption of animal or vegetable food, or other matter subject to decomposition, decay, putrefaction for the generation of noxious or offensive gases or odors, or which during or after decay may serve as breeding areas or feeding material for flies, insects, or animals. 
Hazardous refuse means solid wastes and other materials that: 
(1)  Have been defined as hazardous wastes pursuant to the Solid Waste Disposal Act, 42 USC 6901 et seq. or regulations promulgated by the state board of natural resources at chapter 391-3-11; 
(2)  Have been defined as hazardous substances pursuant to the Comprehensive Environmental Response Compensation and Liability Act, 42 USC 9601 et seq.; or 
(3)  Constitute a hazard to health or safety, such as poison, acids, caustic matter or solutions, chemicals, infected materials, offal, fecal matter, explosives, radioactive materials, and highly flammable substances. 
Household trash means residential waste accumulation usually attendant upon housekeeping, such as paper, sweepings, dust, rags, bottles, cans or other residential refuse of any kind, other than garbage, excluding hazardous refuse, ashes and building material. 
Industrial establishment means any establishment involved in the manufacture or assembly of a product or any part thereof. 
Industrial waste means all waste, including solids, semisolids, sludges and liquids, created by or resulting from the operation of factories, processing plants or other manufacturing enterprises. 
Laws means applicable federal, state and local laws, statutes, rules, regulations, ordinances and other governmental requirements. 
Litter means all discarded manmade materials, including but not limited to garbage, household trash, industrial waste, building materials, appliances or portions thereof, refuse, waste materials, sand, gravel, slag, brickbats, rubbish, tin cans, trash, debris, dead animals or any other discarded, used or unconsumed substance not handled in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
Loading and unloading area means a space or area used by any moving vehicle for the purpose of receiving, shipping and transporting goods, wares, commodities and persons. 
Mobile home park means a parcel of land that has been planned and improved for the placement of two or more mobile homes for nontransient use and for rent. 
Multi-family dwelling means a building designed for or occupied by two or more families, such as apartments, duplexes and triplexes. 
Municipal solid waste means garbage, household trash, white goods, brown goods, bagged yard trimmings, except hazardous refuse. 
Refuse means solid waste accumulations consisting of any combination of ashes, building material, garbage, hazardous refuse, household trash, and other waste or discarded materials of all kinds. 
Refuse receptacle means a container approved by the CA as acceptable for the temporary reception and storage of refuse pending transportation to a permanent disposal site. The term shall include plastic bags where approved by the CA. 
Rules and regulations means the detailed rules and regulations approved by the board of commissioners the CA is authorized to use and enforce for the efficient and safe operation of this article. 
Sanitation fee means the amount to be paid by persons responsible under the terms of this article for the sanitary handling or disposal of solid waste by the county or their designee. 
Scavenge, scavenging means the unauthorized and uncontrolled retrieval of discarded refuse materials. 
White goods means appliances such as stoves and refrigerators. 
Yard trimmings means leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance other than mining, agricultural, and silvicultural operations. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § I; Amd. of 6-8-99; Ord. of 11-13-18(3), § 1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 54-33—54-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 54-56. - Authority of county administrator. 
The CA shall have charge of the administration of this article. The CA is authorized, with the written approval of the board of commissioners, to adopt and promulgate rules and regulations concerning waste collection, conveyance and disposal, and respecting the size, type, specifications, number and location of all containers and fees charged for collections. Such rules and regulations shall have the force of law, but shall not be contrary to anything in this article but supplementary thereto. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § II(1); Ord. of 9-18-07; Ord. of 11-13-18(3), § 1) 
Sec. 54-57. - Residential service. 
(a)  All residential, including but not limited to single-family residences, multi-family dwellings and mobile home parks in the unincorporated portions of the county are required to utilize the solid waste collection service of the county for the disposition of all municipal solid waste generated by such residences which shall be collected once a week. All other refuse, except hazardous refuse, shall be taken to the county transfer station by the residence producing the other refuse or otherwise managed and disposed of, all in conformity with applicable laws. 
(b)  Notwithstanding anything in this section to the contrary and consistent with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 12-8-30.10, any individual may dispose of solid waste originating from his own residence onto land or facilities owned by him when disposal of such waste does not thereby adversely affect the public health and is in accordance with applicable laws. However, the sanitation fee provided for in this article must be paid. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § II(2); Ord. of 9-18-07) 
Sec. 54-58. - Receptacles and containers required. 
Every person in possession, charge or control of any residence unit upon which municipal solid waste is accumulated or produced shall be initially provided a container by the county for the deposit of municipal solid waste generated at such residence unit. In the event one container is not sufficient for the person, an additional container may be obtained at the cost of the user. The fee will be as per the rate schedule adjusted from time to time by the board of commissioners. The container shall be kept in a suitable place readily accessible to the solid waste collection crews of the county or its designees, as the case may be, for the storage of all such municipal solid waste that will normally accumulate between the established collection dates. The CA shall determine the type, size, specifications, number and location of the receptacles and shall determine whether the receptacles and containers are in a serviceable condition. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § II(3); Ord. of 9-18-07; Ord. of 11-13-18(3), § 1) 
Sec. 54-59. - Receptacles and containers to be safe. 
All receptacles and containers shall be maintained in good serviceable condition at all times. Any receptacle or container that does not conform to the requirements of this article or to the rules and regulations of the CA, or which has ragged or sharp edges or other defects likely to hamper or injure the person collecting the contents therefrom or the public generally, shall be replaced by the county at the expense of the owner. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § II(4); Ord. of 9-18-07; Ord. of 11-13-18(3), § 1) 
Sec. 54-60. - Fees. 
(a)  Each residential unit shall pay a fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. 
(b)  The property owner of any multi-family dwelling, or any mobile home park, shall be responsible for the paying of the residential sanitation fee that is due to the county. The total sanitation fee for any multi-family dwelling, or any mobile home park, shall be computed by multiplying the number of such dwelling units times the sanitation fee. The number of units shall be those units as appears on the records of the Tax Assessors Office of Sumter County, Georgia. 
(c)  A property owner may file an appeal through the county tax commissioner's office by completing a county garbage collection fee appeal form which will be reviewed pursuant to rules established by the county board of commissioners. The filing of the appeal does not waive the requirement to pay the fees until the commission approves such exemption pursuant to the rules established by the commission. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § II(5); Amd. of 6-8-99; Res. of 1-16-01; Ord. of 9-18-07) 
Sec. 54-61. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Generally. It is the principal objective of this article to attain a clean, healthy, safe and litter-free community. Enforcement procedures shall be utilized only where other means fail. 
(b)  Solid waste management plans. A solid waste management plan must be submitted with every application for a building permit. The inspection department shall obtain the approval of the CA of the solid waste management plan. The management plan submitted shall be consistent with the county's management plan as approved by the state. 
(c)  Monitoring by employees. Solid waste collection employees, inspection department employees, and other county employees shall be alert to observe violations of the provisions of this article, including but without limitation loose trash and garbage, waste, litter, containers not in compliance, or any other thing or matter which may be in violation of this article or the rules and regulations of the CA. An employee observing such violations shall report the violation to his supervisor, who in turn shall cause the information to be conveyed to the CA for required action. 
(d)  Collection of sanitation fees. The fees due the county shall be paid promptly annually as part of the property owner's taxes and if not paid in a timely manner shall be collected by the county through any lawful means. Also, the nonpayment of the fees provided for in this article shall constitute a lien against the real and personal property of the person or legal entity responsible for the payment of the fees. 
(e)  Penalty for violation. The violation of any provision of this article, or of the rules and regulations of the CA promulgated under this article, or the failure to do any act or meet any standard required by this article, or the failure to comply in any way with any requirement of this article or the rules and regulations, shall constitute an offense triable in the magistrate court of the county, and is punishable by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or imprisonment for 60 days or both as provided in O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20. 
(f)  Prima facie case. Whenever litter is thrown, deposited, dropped or dumped from any motor vehicle, boat, airplane, wagon, wheelbarrow, or other conveyance in violation of this article or the rules and regulations promulgated by the CA under this article, it shall be prima facie evidence that the operator of the conveyance has violated this article. 
(g)  Presumption. Whenever any litter which is dumped, deposited, thrown, or left on public or private property in violation of this article or of the rules and regulations promulgated by the CA under this article is discovered to contain any article or articles, including but not limited to letters, bills, publications or other writings that display the name of the person thereon in such manner as to indicate that the article belongs or belonged to such person, it shall be a rebuttable presumption that such person has violated this article. 
(h)  Specific penalties cumulative. Where any section of this article contains specific remedies or punishments, the specific remedies or punishments shall not be exclusive but shall be in addition to all other remedies and punishments provided in this article or otherwise provided by law for the violation of or noncompliance with this article of the rules and regulations of the CA. 
(i)  Additional penalties. In addition to all punishments and penalties provided in this article or otherwise by law, the magistrate's court may impose the following additional or alternative sentences, either as a direct sentence, or as a condition to probation: 
(1)  The court may direct the convicted person to pick up and remove from any public street or highway or public right-of-way any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone else prior to the date of the execution of the sentence; or 
(2)  The court may direct the convicted person to pick up and remove from any public beach, public park, private right-of-way, or with the prior permission of the legal owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, any private property upon which it can be established by any competent evidence that the person has deposited litter, any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone prior to the date of the execution of the sentence. 
(j)  Action in emergencies. Nothing contained in the foregoing subsections of this section or elsewhere in this article shall require intermediate measures where the violation is of such nature or degree as to constitute an immediate, clear and present danger to the health and safety of the public. The failure to take the steps provided in this article shall not constitute a defense to any proceeding to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § VIII; Ord. of 9-18-07; Ord. of 11-13-18(3), § 1) 
Sec. 54-61.1. - Appeals. 
Appeals must be filed with the county tax commissioner's office within 45 days of the property owner receiving his or her tax bill with includes the solid waste fee. The appeal must be in writing on an approved appeal form which can be obtained from the county tax commissioner's office. The appeal must set forth in detail the reason the property owner believes that the solid waste fee is not owed or has been incorrectly assessed to the property owner. If the property owner wishes to present oral argument, the property owner, in his or her appeal, must request to argue the appeal before the county board of commissioners. A date will be set to hear argument within 45 days of filing the appeal with the tax commissioner, or at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the board of commissioners, but in no event will argument be scheduled any sooner than 30 days from the filing of the appeal. 
All appeals will be reviewed as they are brought to the county's attention. The county shall have up to 45 days to determine if the relief sought in the appeal shall be granted. A written response giving notification to the property owner of the county's appeal decision will be provided within the stated timeframe. 
After receiving the county's decision, any other and further appeals by the property owner must be properly filed with the superior court of the county. 
(Ord. of 9-18-07) 
Sec. 54-62. - Nonrepealer. 
This article is not intended to repeal or modify in any way any other ordinance of the county relating to the abatement of or punishment for nuisances, junk or other matters affecting the health and safety of the public. All remedies provided in this article are supplemental to and in addition to all other remedies provided by the codes and ordinances of the county and by state laws. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § IX; Ord. of 9-18-07) 
Secs. 54-63—54-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COLLECTION 

Sec. 54-86. - Precollection practices. 
The following practices and procedures shall be followed by persons in the unincorporated areas of the county in order to facilitate the collection of solid waste: 
(1)  Refuse. All refuse shall be managed by such persons in accordance with applicable laws, and all municipal solid waste shall be placed and maintained in containers satisfying the requirements of this article and of the rules and regulations of the CA. Containers shall be maintained at all times with tightfitting lids or covers, and secured in such manner as to prevent the overturning by the elements or by dogs or other animals. 
(2)  Garbage. Garbage placed in containers for collection shall be enclosed in paper or plastic bags. Garbage shall be drained of all liquids prior to its being placed in refuse receptacles. 
(3)  Injurious trash items. Municipal solid waste or refuse brought to the county transfer station with potential for inflicting injury, such as broken glass, light bulbs, sharp pieces of metal, fluorescent tubes, and television tubes shall be securely packaged or wrapped in such a manner as will prevent injury to the collection crews or other persons. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to material placed in mechanically handled containers. 
(4)  Hazardous refuse. Hazardous refuse will not be collected by the county. No person shall place any hazardous refuse in any refuse receptacle or other container for collection by the county and shall not haul or deliver any hazardous refuse to the county transfer station. All applicable laws relating to the generation, management, handling, treatment, storage or disposal of hazardous refuse shall be observed by all persons, and the county reserves the right to report any discovered or known violations of such laws to the appropriate state, federal or local authorities. 
(5)  Building materials. Building materials will not be collected by the county. The owner of the premises or the contractor, builder or person doing the repairs, remodeling construction or demolition shall be required to haul and transfer the debris to the county transfer station. 
(6)  Tree and vegetable removal; home occupants. Trees cut by the owner or occupant shall be taken to the transfer station by the owner. When a tree is cut from private property by anyone other than the owner, such party shall remove and legally dispose of all wood and limbs. The owner, tenant or other persons in possession of the property shall be responsible to see that such tree trimmer or other person outlined above complies with this provision. 
(7)  Other. Grass clippings, leaves, pine straw and/or pine cones shall be placed in a bag on the shoulder of the road or disposed of as provided in subsection (6) above. 
(8)  Ashes. It shall be unlawful to deposit hot ashes in garbage containers. Ashes or clinkers shall not be placed or deposited upon streets, sidewalks or side parks. 
(9)  Pet litter. Pet litter must be placed in securely tied plastic bags not to exceed ten pounds in weight and placed in the container. 
(10)  Household furniture and furnishings. Household furniture, furnishings and brown goods shall be placed on the shoulder of the road or disposed of as provided in subsection (6) above. 
(11)  Appliances. Appliances (white goods) may be placed on the shoulder of the road or disposed of as provided in subsection (6) above. 
(12)  Disposable diapers. Disposable diapers must be placed and tied securely in plastic bags and placed in the regular container. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § III; Ord. of 11-13-18(3), § 1) 
Sec. 54-87. - Collection practices. 
(a)  Residential. Garbage accumulated by residents shall be stored in refuse receptacles complying with the requirements of the CA as to size, shape and materials, and shall be placed at such locations convenient for servicing by the county as shall be designated by the CA for weekly pickup. Service for disabled citizens will be handled as by the rules and regulations implemented by the board of commissioners once the disability is certified by a licensed physician and the certification is submitted to the CA for approval. 
(b)  Commercial. Refuse accumulated by commercial establishments shall be stored in containers meeting the requirements of the CA as to size, shape and materials; and such receptacles shall be compatible with the collection equipment and methods of the county. 
(c)  Issuance of permits. The building inspector of the county shall not issue a building permit for industrial establishments, commercial establishments or multi-family dwellings until the CA gives his approval to proposed plans for the storage, disposal and other management of refuse, and until the applicant for a permit has submitted proof that all the applicant's taxes and fees due the county are paid and are current. The term, "applicant's taxes and fees" includes any and all taxes and fees on property that the applicant has an interest in or is responsible for managing. 
(d)  Locations of containers. The county will not collect municipal solid waste from commercial establishments or multi-family dwellings unless the municipal solid waste is placed in approved containers and located at a place approved by the CA. 
(e)  Multi-family units. All multi-family dwellings of 50 or more units served by the county shall be containerized with plastic or metal containers furnished by the county. Multi-family dwellings of less than 50 units serviced by the county may be containerized with plastic or metal containers furnished by the county as determined by the CA in accordance with section 54-58. 
(f)  Containerizing trash. All commercial establishments shall containerize all refuse generated by the establishment, including outside as well as inside debris from the premises. 
(g)  Transfer station. All industrial waste, building material, roofing material, material from remodeling and demolition that is hauled and taken to the county transfer station in accordance with this article shall be hauled and taken by the owner or by the person responsible to the owner for the removal of such material in compliance with applicable laws. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § IV; Ord. of 11-13-18(3), § 1) 
Sec. 54-88. - Wheeled garbage containers. 
(a)  Inspections. Where a wheeled garbage container is furnished by the county, it shall be normally the only container authorized for garbage collection and shall be subject to inspection by the county. Should additional containers be needed, they may be obtained for a fee by contacting the CA. 
(b)  Placing for collection. The owner, occupant, tenant or other person occupying any building, house or structure within the unincorporated areas of the county as a residence or business using a wheeled garbage container shall have the container at the curb or designated location not earlier than 7:00 p.m. on the day before and not later than 7:00 a.m. on the designated garbage pickup days. 
(c)  Removal after collection. The owners, occupant, tenant or other person occupying any building, house or structure within the unincorporated areas of the county as a residence or business using a wheeled garbage container for curbside service shall return the container to the side or rear of building no later than 24 hours after collection. Where the collection point is located more than 100 yards from a home, the container may be stored at another location approved by the CA. 
(d)  Vacating dwelling. Wheeled garbage containers furnished by the county shall not be removed from the premises to which they are delivered. 
(e)  Loss or damage to container. If the wheeled container furnished by the county is damaged, lost or destroyed through negligence of the person to whom the container was assigned, the person shall reimburse the county for the cost of a replacement container. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § V; Ord. of 11-13-18(3), § 1) 
Sec. 54-89. - Commercial establishments. 
(a)  Generally. Commercial establishments shall store refuse in containers meeting the requirements of applicable laws, including but not limited to this article and the rules and regulations promulgated by the CA in part to eliminate wind-driven debris and unsightly litter in and about the establishment. Any spillage or overflow shall be cleaned up immediately by the establishment. 
(b)  Loading and unloading areas. All loading and unloading areas shall be provided with appropriate refuse receptacles for loose debris, paper, packaging materials and other trash and refuse. The owner or occupant of the commercial establishment shall place a sufficient number of containers, not less than the number required by the rules and regulations adopted by the board of commissioners for that establishment, in the area to maintain a clean, neat and sanitary condition at all times. The occupant of the premises shall maintain surveillance to ensure that all refuse is placed in the proper container in compliance with applicable laws, including but not limited to this article, and that the area is kept clean and free of litter. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § VI; Ord. of 11-13-18(3), § 1) 
Secs. 54-90—54-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES 

Sec. 54-111. - Generally. 
The activities specified in this division are hereby declared to be unlawful and in violation of this article. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § VII (preamble)) 
Sec. 54-112. - Public streets and private property. 
No person shall place any litter, refuse, garbage or trash in any street, median strip, alley or other public place of travel, nor upon any other public property, nor upon any private property except with the written consent of the owner or occupant thereof, and then only in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § VII(1)) 
Sec. 54-113. - Blockage of drainage. 
No person shall place any litter, refuse, trash, trees, grass, refuse receptacles, containers, or garbage on, over, or so close to any drainage culvert, manhole or ditch as to cause such material to interfere in any way with the proper and efficient drainage. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § VII(2)) 
Sec. 54-114. - Appliances. 
No person shall leave outside any building in a place accessible to children any appliance, refrigerator or other container that has an airtight snap lock or similar device without first removing the door. This section shall not apply to any appliance, refrigerator or container that has been placed on or adjacent to the rear of the building and that has been crated, strapped or locked so that it will be impossible for a child to obtain access to any compartment thereof. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § VII(3)) 
Sec. 54-115. - Vacant units, lots and rental units. 
No owner or occupant of any property in the unincorporated areas of the county shall allow litter, garbage, refuse, rubbish, filth, debris, building material, household trash or yard trimmings to accumulate on his property. The county will not remove such accumulation from the property. If any owner, occupant or other person responsible for the existence of any of those conditions shall fail to remedy the conditions within seven days, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, after notice, the conditions shall be a violation of this article and abatable as a nuisance. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § VII(4)) 
Sec. 54-116. - Scavenging. 
No person other than the owner thereof shall disturb or interfere with any container used for the purpose of storing refuse pending its collection, or remove any contents therefrom or remove such container from its location. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § VII(5)) 
Sec. 54-117. - Scattering of refuse and littering prohibited. 
No person shall: 
(1)  Throw or deposit any refuse on any public or private street or scatter such refuse or litter on any public or private property. 
(2)  Throw or deposit any refuse, trash or debris in any marsh area, stream, drainage ditch, body of water or beach area. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § VII(6)) 
Sec. 54-118. - Securing loads on vehicles. 
(a)  No vehicle shall be driven or moved on any public road in the unincorporated areas of the county unless such vehicle is constructed or loaded or covered in such a manner so as to prevent any of its load from blowing out, dropping, escaping, or shifting in such a manner as to: 
(1)  Create a safety hazard; or 
(2)  Deposit litter, rubbish, junk, trash or debris on public or private property. 
Nothing in this section shall prohibit the necessary spreading of any substance in public road maintenance. 
(b)  No person shall load any vehicle, which is to be operated on any public road in the unincorporated areas of this county, unless such load is fully covered and the covering thereon is securely fastened so as to prevent said covering or load from: 
(1)  Becoming loose, detached, or in any manner becoming a hazard to other users of the public road; or 
(2)  Depositing litter, rubbish, junk, trash or debris on public or private property while such vehicle is on a public road. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be deemed to supersede any federal or state laws or regulations applying to the securing of loads on motor vehicles. 
(d)  The provisions of this section and regulations based thereon shall not apply to organic debris that escapes during the transportation of silage from field or farm to storage and storage to feedlot or during the transportation of agricultural or farm products or silvicultural products from farm or forest to a processing plant or point of sale or use. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § VII(7); Ord. of 12-20-2011) 
Sec. 54-119. - Unlawful dumping. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, drop, dump or otherwise leave any litter on the premises of another without the consent of such other person, and without complying with applicable laws, including but not limited to this article and the rules and regulations of the CA adopted pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § VII(8); Ord. of 11-13-18(3), § 1) 
Sec. 54-120. - Ownership of refuse. 
All refuse, including refuse deposited in refuse containers provided by the county, shall be and shall remain the property of the owner or occupant until the same has been placed in vehicles of the county or its designee in accordance with this article. The county has no responsibility or liability for any injuries or damage resulting from the refuse. 
(Ord. of 5-14-96, § VII(9)) 
Sec. 54-121. - Disposal fees. 
Fees specified in exhibit "A," relating to commercial rates, and exhibit "B," relating to residential collection, hauling and disposal fees, are given in the schedule of fees and charges. 
Sec. 54-122. - Violation; penalty. 
Upon finding of guilt for the violation of this section, the offender shall be subject to imprisonment for a term not to exceeding six months or by fine not exceeding $1,000.00, or both. 
(Ord. of 12-20-2011) 
Chapter 58 - RESIDENTIAL, COMMERCIAL, AND INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Section 1 of an ordinance adopted Dec. 15, 2015(2), amended the title of Ch. 58 to read as herein set out. Formerly, this chapter was titled, "Subdivisions." 
Cross reference— Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any subdivision plat saved from repeal, § 1-6(11); buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 34; floods, ch. 38; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 42; roads and bridges, ch. 50; utilities, ch. 70. 
State Law reference— Local restrictions on condominiums, O.C.G.A. § 44-3-114; Georgia Land Sales Act, O.C.G.A. § 44-3-1 et seq.; Georgia Condominium Act, O.C.G.A. § 44-3-70 et seq.; approval by planning commission or governing authority on plat of subdivision required for filing or recording in superior court clerk's office, O.C.G.A. § 15-6-67(d). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 58-1. - Purpose. 
Pursuant to the authority conferred by the Georgia General Planning Enabling Act of 1957 (Act No. 358, as amended), this chapter is enacted for the following purposes, among others: 
(1)  Encouraging the development of an economically sound and stable community; 
(2)  Assuring the provision of required streets, utilities and other facilities and services to new land developments; 
(3)  Assuring the adequate provision of safe and convenient traffic access and circulation, both vehicular and pedestrian, in new land developments; 
(4)  Assuring the provision of needed public open spaces and building sites in new land development through the dedication or reservation of land for recreational, educational and other public purposes; and 
(5)  Assuring, in general, the wise development of new areas in the county. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-2. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Accessory means a use or building subordinate to the principal building on a lot used for purposes customarily identical to the main or principal use or building located on the same lot. 
Alley means a secondary way that affords vehicular service access to the side or rear of abutting property. 
Alteration of building means any change in the supporting members of a building (such as bearing walls, columns or girders); an addition or reduction to a building; any change in use; or relocation of a building from one location or position to another. 
Boardinghouse, lodginghouse, or roominghouse means a dwelling in which meals or lodging or both are provided. 
Building means a structure completely enclosed by a roof and by exterior walls, which is movable or permanently affixed to a lot and used or intended for the shelter, support or enclosure of persons, animals or property of any kind. 
Building line means that line which represents the distance a building or structure must be set back from a lot boundary or a street right-of-way line according to the terms of this chapter. In all cases the building lines of a lot shall be determined to run parallel to and set back an appropriate distance required within the district in which the lot is located from street right-of-way lines, street centerlines, or other lot boundary lines. 
Building, principal means a building in which is conducted the principal use of the lot on which the building is situated. 
Clinic means an establishment where medical or dental patients who are not lodged overnight are admitted for examination or treatment. 
Cluster development means a change from the conventional pattern of subdivision development, which groups housing units into relatively tight units while providing a unified network of open space. A variety of housing types may be utilized in clusters, including single-family houses, townhouses, apartments, and condominiums. 
Conditional use means a use (sometimes called a special exception, but not to be confused with a variance) that would not be appropriate generally or without restriction but which, if controlled as to number, area, location, or relation to the neighborhood, would not be injurious to the public health, safety, welfare, morals, order, comfort, convenience, appearance, or general welfare. 
District means various geographical areas for purposes of interpreting the provisions of this chapter. The terms "district" and "zoning district" are synonymous and are used interchangeably throughout this chapter. 
Drive-in means a retail or service enterprise oriented to automobile-driving patrons wherein service is provided to the consumer on the outside and/or inside of the principal building. The term "drive-in" includes drive-in restaurants, dairy bars, theaters, banks, and car washes. 
Dwelling means a building or portion of a building arranged or designed to provide living quarters for one or more families. The terms "dwelling," "dwelling units" and "residence" are synonymous. 
Dwelling, one-family, means a detached dwelling designed for or occupied exclusively by one family on a single lot. 
Dwelling, two-family, means a dwelling arranged or designed to be occupied by two families in separate dwelling units living independently of each other on a single lot. 
Dwelling, group, means a building or portion of a building occupied or intended for occupancy by a number of unrelated persons or families, but in which separate cooking facilities are not provided for such resident persons or families. The term "group dwelling" includes but is not limited to roominghouse, apartment, hotel, retirement home, nursing home, fraternity or sorority home, Y.M.C.A., Y.W.C.A. and similar organizational or institutional group. A transient hotel, motel or tourist home shall not be deemed to be group dwelling. 
Dwelling, multiple-family, means a building or series of buildings on the same lot or portions thereof used or designed and rented as dwellings for three or more families living independently of each other, with the number of families in residence not exceeding the number of dwelling units provided. The terms "multiple-family" and "multifamily" are synonymous. 
Dwelling unit means one or more rooms connected together and constituting a separate, independent housekeeping establishment for use on a basis involving owner occupancy or rental-lease on a weekly, monthly or longer basis, with provisions for cooking, eating and sleeping, and physically set apart from any other dwelling units in the same structure. 
Family means one or more persons with the generic character of a family unit occupying a single dwelling unit and using common cooking facilities, provided that servants and agricultural employees employed on the premises may be housed on the premises. 
Garage, private, means an accessory building or portion of a principal building used only for the private storage of motor vehicles as an accessory use. 
Garage, public, means any garage, other than a private garage, used for storage, repair, rental, servicing, washing, adjusting, or equipping automobiles or other vehicles. 
Garage, repair, means a building and premises designed or used for repairing motor vehicles, trailers, and related transport carriers, provided that body work and painting shall be conducted within fully enclosed buildings and provided further that trailers and self-propelled vehicles in process of repair shall be stored in a fully enclosed and screened area. 
Home occupation means any use conducted entirely within a dwelling and carried on by the occupants thereof, which use is clearly incidental and secondary to the use of the dwelling for residential purposes. 
Junkyard or salvage yard means the use of any part of a lot, whether inside or outside of a building, for the storage, keeping, abandonment, sale or resale of junk, salvage or scrap materials, or the dismantling, demolition or abandonment of buildings, automobiles or other vehicles, machinery, equipment or parts thereof. 
Loading space, off-street means space logically and conveniently located for pickups and deliveries off public rights-of-way, scaled to delivery vehicles expected to be used and acceptable to such vehicles at all times. 
Lot means an area designed as a separate and distinct parcel of land or a legally recorded subdivision plot of land in a legally recorded deed as filed in the official county records. No lot shall be deeper than 3 times the road frontage of the lot. 
Lot, corner, means a lot located at the intersection of two or more streets. 
Lot, double-frontage, means a lot with frontage on more than one street; however, no corner lot shall qualify as a double-frontage lot unless the corner lot has frontage on three or more streets. 
Lot width means the distance between side lot lines measured at the front building line. 
Manufactured home means a new or used structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein; except that such term shall include any structure which meets all the requirements of this definition except the size requirements and with respect to which the manufacturer voluntarily files a certification required by the secretary of housing and urban development and complies with the standards established under the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, 42 USC 5401 et seq. The term "manufactured home" is not synonymous with the term "mobile home," "double-wide" or "home trailer," nor does it include "recreational vehicles"; but the term includes "modular home" and "prefabricated homes." Every manufactured home shall be: 
(1)  Suitable for year-round occupancy; 
(2)  Placed on a permanent masonry foundation so as to be substantially fixed as to its site; 
(3)  Connected to an approved water supply, approved waste disposal system, and electrical supply similar to site-built housing; and 
(4)  Landscaped with trees, shrubs and other plant material substantially equal to or better than one-family dwellings within 500 feet. 
Mobile home means a new or used structure, transportable in one or more sections, which in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length, or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein and built prior to June 15, 1976. The term does not include "recreational vehicles." Every mobile home shall be: 
(1)  Suitable for year-round occupancy; 
(2)  Placed on a permanent masonry foundation so as to be substantially fixed as to its site; 
(3)  Connected to an approved water supply, approved waste disposal system, and electrical supply similar to site-built housing; and 
(4)  Landscaped with trees, shrubs and other plant material substantially equal to or better than one-family dwellings within 500 feet. 
Mobile home park means a parcel of land planned and improved for the placement of two or more mobile homes for non-transient use. A permit shall be required for the establishment of a mobile home park. The term "park" includes the term "community." 
Motel means a building or buildings in which lodging is provided and offered to the public for compensation, which is open to transient or permanent guests. The word "motel" includes the terms "motor hotel" and "tourist court." 
Nonconforming use means a structure or land lawfully occupied by an existing use which does not conform with the permitted uses for the zoning districts in which it is situated, either at the effective date of this chapter or as the result of subsequent amendments to this chapter. 
Parking lot means any public or private open area used for the express purpose of parking automobiles and other vehicles, with the exception of areas on the premises of single-family dwellings used for parking purposes incidental to the principal use. Parking lots may be the principal use on a given lot or an accessory use. 
Parking space means a space not less than 9 × 18 feet plus maneuvering space within a parking lot or on a single-family dwelling lot expressly provided for purpose of parking an automobile or other vehicle. 
Patio house means a single-family dwelling in which most or all of a lot is used with yard space combined instead of divided. Front, rear, and side yards are consolidated into one garden area, either partially or completely bordered by rooms or enclosed by walls. 
Planned unit development (PUD) means a group of three or more buildings constructed on a plot of unsubdivided ground at least two acres in size, which provides for common open spaces and a variety of choices in housing types and land utilization. Land ownership or rental patterns may vary, with rental units, cooperatives, and condominiums being choices open to PUD developers. If common open spaces, including streets, are not dedicated for public use, legal agreements shall be provided for approval by the board of commissioners and shall include provision for adequate future maintenance. The terms "planned unit development" and "PUD" are interchangeable. 
Recreational vehicle means a vehicular, portable structure built on a chassis, designed to be either pulled by another vehicle or self-propelled, to be used as a temporary dwelling for travel and recreational purposes. The term "recreational vehicle" includes the terms "RV," "motor home," "travel trailer," and related wheeled recreational equipment not designed for year-round occupancy. 
Roadside stand means a small-scale business structure permanently or seasonally located within an agricultural or rural area for the sale of agricultural products primarily produced on the premises and using only signs that are removed during seasons when the business is closed. 
Sign means every outdoor advertising device, billboard, poster, panel, freestanding ground sign, roof sign, projecting sign, pylon sign, illuminated sign, sign painted on a wall, window, marquee, awning or canopy, and shall include any announcement, declaration, demonstration, display, ribbon, banner, illustration, or insignia used to advertise or promote the interests of any person when the same is placed in view of the general public traveling along a public street or road right-of-way. 
Signs, number and surface area. For the purpose of determining number of signs, a sign shall be considered to be a single display surface or display device containing elements organized, related and composed to form a unit. Where matter is displayed in a random manner without organized relationship of elements, or where there is reasonable doubt about the relationship of elements, each element shall be considered to be a single sign. The surface area of a sign shall be computed as including the entire area within a regular geometric form or combinations of regular geometric forms comprising all of the display area of the sign and including all of the elements of the matter displayed. Frames and structural members not bearing advertising matter shall not be included in computation of surface area. 
Sign, off-site, means an outdoor advertising device other than an on-site sign, including those erected by the outdoor advertising industry. 
Sign, on-site, means an outdoor advertising device relating in its subject matter to the premises on which it is located, or to products, accommodations, services or activities on the premises. The terms "point-of-sale" sign and "on-premises" signs are synonymous with "on-site" sign. 
Street means a thoroughfare which affords traffic circulation and principal means of access to abutting property, including avenue, place, way, drive, lane, boulevard, highway, road, and any other thoroughfare except an alley. A public street is a street accepted by dedication or otherwise by the governing body. A private street is a street not so accepted. 
Structure means anything constructed or erected, the use of which requires a fixed location on the ground or which is attached to something having a fixed location on the ground. 
Subdivision means the division of a lot, tract or parcel of land into two or more new lots, parcels or tracts, excluding the remaining portion of the original lot, parcel or tract out of which the new lot or lots were created. The purpose of the division of land being sale, or building development, whether immediate or future. Any division of the remaining parcel or tract, or any division of the resulting new lot or lots, by the original owner or any future owner shall be deemed a subdivision and the terms of the subdivision ordinance shall be applicable thereto. Exceptions: 
(1)  Any division of a lot, tract or parcel so that the resulting divisions create no lots less than 20 acres including the original lot, tract or parcel and no new streets or roads are created or no new utility improvements are required or; 
(2)  Any division of a lot, tract or parcel where no new streets or roads are created or no new utility improvements are required; or no new sanitary sewer or approval of a septic tank is required. 
Tourist home means a dwelling in which sleeping accommodations in less than ten rooms are provided or offered for the use of guests in return for compensation. Any dwelling in which such accommodations are offered in ten or more rooms shall be deemed to be a hotel. The use of a dwelling as a tourist home shall not be considered as an accessory use nor a customary home occupation. 
Tract means the same as " Lot. " 
Use, accessory. See " Accessory. " 
Use, conditional. See " Conditional use. " 
Use, principal, means the primary purpose for which a lot is occupied and/or used. 
Utility means public or private water or sewer piping systems, water or sewer pumping stations (including private wells), electric power lines, fuel or gas pipelines, telephone lines, roads, cable telephone lines, fiber optic cable, driveways, bridges, river/lake access facilities, storm water systems and drainage ways, and railroads or other utilities identified by the county. 
Variance means a modification of the strict terms of this chapter granted by the board of appeals where such modification will not be contrary to the public good, such as irregular lot size, topographic or other characteristics of the land, and not as the result of any action on the part of the property owner, and where a literal enforcement of this chapter would result in unnecessary and undue hardship. 
Wetlands means those lands classified as "poorly or very poorly drained soils" by the U.S. Department of Agriculture Soil Conservation Service in the Soil Survey of Schley and Sumter Counties, Georgia, dated August, 1974. 
Yard means a required space on the same lot with a principal building, open, unoccupied, and unobstructed by buildings or structures from ground to sky except where encroachments of accessory buildings and other structures are expressly permitted. 
Yard, front, means a yard situated between the front building line and the front lot line and extending the full width of the lot. 
Yard, rear, means a yard situated between the rear building line and the rear lot line and extending the full width of the lot. 
Yard, side, means a yard situated between a side building line and the front yard to the rear yard. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-3. - Right-of-way easements. 
Right-of-way easements for streets and roads shall not be considered a part of a lot or open space, or front, rear or side yard for the purpose of meeting yard requirements. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-4. - Lot reduction prohibited. 
No yard or lot existing on April 11, 1995, shall be reduced in dimension or area below the minimum requirements set forth in this chapter. Yards or lots created after April 11, 1995, shall meet at least the minimum requirements established by this chapter. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-5. - Use of substandard lots of record. 
Where the owner of a lot on April 11, 1995, does not own sufficient land to enable him to conform to the dimensional requirements of this chapter, such lot may nonetheless be used as a building site, provided that the lot requirements are not reduced below the minimum specified in this chapter by more than 20 percent. If, however, the owner of two or more adjoining lots with insufficient land dimensions decides to build on or sell off these lots, he must first combine the lots to comply with the dimensional requirements of this chapter. Any lot requiring dimensional waivers below the 20 percent minimum set forth in this section may be approved by the board of commissioners, provided that further decreased dimensional requirements shall conform as closely as possible to the required dimensions. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-6. - Street frontage. 
No building shall be erected on a lot that does not abut at least 100 feet on a public or private street, except when the public or private street is a cul-de-sac, and shall have a minimum frontage of 50 feet on the cul-de-sac. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-7. - One principal building on a lot. 
Only one principal building and its customary accessory buildings may be erected on any one lot. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-8. - Planted buffer strips. 
Where commercial or industrial districts abut residential or manufactured home park development, a ten-foot-wide buffer strip shall be provided along the abutting property lines, and the ten feet shall be added to the side or rear yard requirements as well as the lot width unless specified otherwise in this chapter. Such buffer strip shall be planted with evergreen trees or shrubs that grow at least eight feet tall and provide an effective visual screen. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-9. - Vision clearance. 
In all subdivisions no fence, wall, shrubbery or other obstruction to vision between the heights of 2½ feet and ten feet above the finished grade of streets shall be erected, permitted or maintained within 20 feet of the intersection of the right-of-way lines of streets and railroads. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-10. - Access to public or private streets. 
Access to public or private streets shall be maintained in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  No building shall be erected on a lot that does not abut at least 100 feet on a public or private street, except when the public or private street is a cul-de-sac, and shall have a minimum frontage of 50 feet on the cul-de-sac. 
(2)  Any additional dwelling shall have access to a public or private street by means of a passageway open to the sky at least 15 feet in width. 
(3)  Local streets that will carry less than 600 vehicles per day may have access points as needed to fit the development. 
(4)  For all developments fronting on a state highway, no final plat shall be approved until the approval of the state department of transportation (DOT) has been obtained regarding access points, curb radii, drainage and related engineering design of concern to the DOT, and proof of their final approval has been submitted. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-11. - Corner lots. 
On lots having frontage on more than one street at an intersection, the minimum front yard requirement may be reduced to half the regulated distance on the portion of the lot fronting on the street or streets of lesser importance. However, in no case shall the setback be reduced to less than 15 feet. The minimum front yard for the portion of the lot fronting on the street of greater importance shall be provided in accordance with the provisions established by this chapter for the district in which the lot is located. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-12. - Double-frontage lots. 
On lots having frontage on two streets, but not located on a corner, the minimum front yard shall be provided on each street in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. On lots having frontage on more than two streets, the minimum front yard shall be provided in accordance with the regulations set forth in this chapter on at least two of the street frontages. The minimum front yard on the other frontage or frontages may be reduced along the other streets. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-13. - Front yard requirements. 
The setback requirements as set forth in section 58-238 of this chapter shall not apply to any lot where the average setback on already-built-upon adjoining lots within the same block and zoning district are located wholly or in part within 100 feet on each side of such lot but not less than the average of the existing setbacks on the developed lots. However, in no case shall setbacks be less than 15 feet. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-14. - Code requirements and state regulations. 
All structures shall meet the requirements of the state minimum standard codes, as adopted and amended by the state department of community affairs, including: 
(1)  Standard Building Code (SBCC), including appendices C, D, G, J and L. 
(2)  Standard Mechanical Code (SBCCI), including appendix B. 
(3)  Standard Gas Code (SBCCI). 
(4)  National Electrical Code. 
(5)  Standard Plumbing Code (SBCCI), including appendices B, C, H and J. 
(6)  Standard Fire Prevention Code (SBCCI), including chapter 1, appendices B, C and D. 
(7)  CABO One and Two Family Dwelling Code, including appendix F. 
(8)  Georgia State Energy Code for Buildings, including chapter 1. 
(9)  Standard Housing Code. 
(10)  Georgia Department of Transportation Regulations. 
(11)  Georgia State Fire Marshal Regulations. 
(12)  Georgia State Health Department Regulations. 
(13)  Georgia Erosion and Sedimentation Act of 1975 as amended. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-15. - Conflict with other laws. 
Whenever the regulations of this chapter imposes more restrictive standards than are required under any other statute, the requirement of this chapter shall govern. Whenever the provisions of any other statute require more restrictive standards than are required by this chapter, the provisions of such statute shall govern. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-16. - Violation, penalty. 
(a)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-11. 
(b)  The county or any owner of real estate who would be damaged by such violation, in addition to other remedies, may institute injunction mandamus or other appropriate action in proceeding to stop the violation. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-17. - Amendments. 
(a)  This chapter may be amended from time to time by the county government, but no amendment shall become effective unless it shall have been proposed by or shall first have been submitted to the board of commissioners for review and recommendation. 
(b)  Before the board of commissioners enacts an amendment to this chapter, the board shall hold a public hearing thereon, at least 15 days' notice of the time and date of which shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the county. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-18. - Auction of residential or commercial land. 
In the event that any tract or lot smaller than 20 acres, or land that is otherwise subject to the subdivision ordinance (this chapter), is offered for sale at an auction, and prior approval of the subdivision of tracts less than 20 acres has not been obtained, the owner, developer, or auctioneer shall meet the requirement of this section. 
(a)  The owner, developer, or auctioneer shall place in a prominent and highly visible location, in all advertisements advertising the sale of the property at auction, the following statement: 
"The residential or commercial tracts or lots offered for sale at the auction have not met the approval of the Sumter County Subdivision Ordinance, and prior to any sale being completed, and prior to any deed or plat being recorded, the specific requirements of the Sumter County Subdivision Ordinance must be met and complied with as stated in the Sumter County Subdivision Ordinance." 
(b)  An announcement will be made by the auctioneer at the beginning of the auction stating to those present that the subdivision of the lots into tracts of less than 20 acres, has not been approved by the county subdivision ordinance, and before a conveyance can be completed, and before a deed or plat will be accepted for recordation, the subdivision of the lots must meet the approval of the county subdivision ordinance. 
(c)  That in each contract for the prospective sale of any lot that is subject to the subdivision ordinance, the contract will contain the following statement: 
"The residential or commercial tracts or lots offered for sale have not met the approval of the Sumter County Subdivision Ordinance, and prior to the sale being completed, and prior to any deed or plat being recorded, the specific requirements of the Sumter County Subdivision Ordinance must be met and complied with as stated in the Sumter County Subdivision Ordinance." 
(d)  The owner, developer, or auctioneer shall file with the Code enforcement office prior to the first advertisement being published, any and all drawings, brochures, and offering statements identifying the land to be sold, and shall file with the Code enforcement office, any changes or amendments to the drawings, brochures, or offering statements. 
(e)  The auctioneer shall notify the Code enforcement office of the date or dates of the auction and the location of the auction site. 
(f)  The failure of compliance with this section may result in the county issuing a cease and desist order to stop the sale or auction of the residential or commercial lots at the auction. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Secs. 58-19—58-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLATS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-51. - Platting authority. 
The board of commissioners shall be the platting authority, and the approval of subdivisions shall conform at all times to this chapter and the Sumter County Standard Protocol for Subdivision Approval, as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-52. - Preliminary plat approval required prior to initiation of construction. 
No construction work shall be undertaken on a proposed land subdivision until a preliminary plat has been approved by the board of commissioners and the requirements of division 2 of this article have been satisfied. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-53. - Land subdivision final plat recording. 
The clerk of the superior court shall not file or record any documentation, including plats or deeds, that effectively create a subdivision of land within the unincorporated areas of the county, until a final plat of the subdivision has been approved in accordance with this chapter, and has been signed by the chairman of the board of commissioners or his duly appointed representative. An approved plat must be recorded within six months of final approval or the approval would be considered null and void and the developer will have to resubmit the subdivision for final approval. The responsibility of recording the plat and paying the recording fee rests with the subdivision developer. Building permits shall not be issued by the county for development on land that has been subdivided in violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-54. - Use of plat. 
The transfer of, sale, agreement to sell, or negotiate to sell land by reference to or exhibition of, or other use of a subdivision that has not been given final approval by the board of commissioners and recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county is prohibited, and the description by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document shall not exempt the transaction from such penalties. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-55. - Erection of buildings. 
No building shall be erected on any lot unless the street giving access to it has been accepted as a public street or approved by the board of commissioners as a private street as having been constructed in conformity with the county standards in accordance with this chapter, or unless such street has attained the legal status of a public street prior to April 11, 1995, or has been accepted as a public street by the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-56. - Acceptance of and improvements in unapproved streets.
