The board of commissioners or other public authority shall not accept as a public street or shall not itself undertake or authorize the layout, opening, improving, grading, paving, lighting or the installation of water mains, sewers, connections or other facilities or utilities in any street unless such street is shown on a final plat approved by the board of commissioners or it has attained the legal status of a public street prior to April 11, 1995; however, the board of commissioners may locate, construct or accept any other street if the ordinance for such a street is first submitted to the board of commissioners for its review and approval. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-57. - Preapplication procedures. 
Before proceeding with a proposed land subdivision, developers are invited and encouraged to discuss their proposed development with the county inspector. A very preliminary sketch of the proposed subdivision together with a map of the area showing its principal features will be helpful in this discussion. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Secs. 58-58—58-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PRELIMINARY PLAT 

Sec. 58-81. - Application for preliminary plat approval. 
The subdivider shall submit to the office of the county inspector, at least 20 days prior to the next regular meeting of the board of commissioners, the following: 
(1)  A letter requesting review and approval of a preliminary plat, giving the name and the address of the person to whom the notice of the hearing by the board of commissioners on the preliminary plat shall be sent. 
(2)  Five copies of the preliminary plat and other documents, as specified in this division. 
(3)  A preliminary plat filing fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, plus the cost of publishing the public notice. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-82. - Review of preliminary plat. 
(a)  The county inspector shall check the plat for conformance to the regulations of this chapter; and if the preliminary plat is found to be in compliance, the county inspector will schedule the consideration of the preliminary plat on the agenda at the next board of commissioners' meeting. However, if the preliminary plat is found to be deficient, the consideration of the preliminary plat will not be placed on the agenda for the next board of commissioners' meeting; and the county inspector will notify the developer in writing of the deficiencies. The developer will have an opportunity to correct the deficiencies and resubmit the plat to the county inspector. If the plat has been resubmitted to the county inspector at least five days prior to the next meeting of the board of commissioners, the consideration of the preliminary plat will be placed on the agenda for its consideration by the board of commissioners. If the plat is resubmitted less than five days prior to the next meeting of the board of commissioners, the consideration of the plat will be placed on the agenda at the next following meeting. 
(b)  The board of commissioners shall approve or disapprove the preliminary plat. A notation of the action shall be made on two copies of the preliminary plat, including a statement of the reasons for disapproval if the preliminary plat is disapproved. One copy shall be returned to the subdivider or his agent and one copy added to the records of the county inspector. 
(c)  Approval of a preliminary plat does not constitute approval of a final plat. It indicates only approval of the layout as a guide to preparation of the final plat. Preliminary plat approval shall expire and be null and void 12 months after approval unless an extension of time is approved by the county inspector. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-83. - Scale. 
The preliminary plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn at the following minimum scales: 
1—4 acre tract: 100 feet to the inch. 
5—10 acre tract: 200 feet to the inch. 
Over 10 acre tract: 500 feet to the inch. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-84. - Sheet size. 
Original sheet size of a preliminary plat shall be 24 × 36 inches. If the complete plat cannot be shown on one sheet of this size, it may be shown on more than one sheet with an index map on a separate sheet of the same size. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-85. - Information to be provided in preliminary plat. 
The preliminary plat shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the owner of record and of the subdivider. 
(2)  Proposed name of the subdivision and its gross acreage. 
(3)  North arrow, graphic scale and date. 
(4)  Vicinity map showing the location of the subdivision and developments in its vicinity. 
(5)  Exact boundary lines of the tract by bearings and distances from a referenced P.O.B. 
(6)  Names of owners of record of adjoining land. 
(7)  Existing streets, utilities and easements on the land adjacent to the tract. 
(8)  Contour lines at intervals of not more than two feet. 
(9)  Proposed layout, including streets and alleys if the subdivision contains alleys, with proposed street names, lot lines with approximate dimensions, easements, land to be reserved or dedicated for public uses, and any land to be used for purposes other than single-family dwellings. 
(10)  Lots, consecutively numbered so that no two lots have the same lot number. 
(11)  Provisions for water supply, sewerage and drainage. 
(12)  Minimum building front yard setback lines. 
(13)  Such street cross sections and centerline profiles as may be required by the planning department. 
(14)  Present and proposed wells, watercourses, floodplains and wetland areas, water systems, sewage systems, structures and easements on the property and within 100 feet of the perimeter of the property. 
(15)  Present public water systems and public sewerage systems, within 1,000 feet of the perimeter of the property. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-86. - Certificate of approval. 
A certificate of approval of the preliminary plat by the board of commissioners shall be inscribed on the plat as follows: 
Pursuant to the Land Subdivision Regulations of Sumter County, Georgia, all the requirements of approval having been fulfilled, this preliminary plat was approved by the Sumter County Commission on ________, 20___. This approval of the preliminary plat does not constitute approval of a final plat. This certificate of approval of the preliminary plat shall expire and be null and void 12 months after approval unless an extension of time is approved by the county inspector. 

 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-87. - Initiation of improvements. 
After a preliminary plat has been approved, no improvements in the land subdivision shall be undertaken until final engineering plans and specifications have been approved by the county. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-88. - Approval of wells and septic tanks. 
Written approval from the board of health shall be submitted to the board of commissioners concerning the proposed placement of all wells and septic tanks on the platted property. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Secs. 58-89—58-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FINAL PLAT 

Sec. 58-111. - Application for final plat approval. 
After the preliminary plat of a proposed land subdivision has been approved by the board of commissioners, the subdivider may, within one year from approval, submit to the county inspector: 
(1)  A letter requesting review and approval of a final plat, giving the name and address of the person(s) to whom the notice of the hearing by the board of commissioners on the final plat shall be sent. 
(2)  Five copies of the final plat and other documents, as specified in section 58-114 et seq., the original of which shall be drawn in permanent ink on reproducible sepia paper or reproducible format, and in conformity with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 15-6-67. The copies submitted to the county inspector and for recording in the clerk's office can be a blue-lined copy, but no larger than 18″ × 24″. 
(3)  The subdivider shall be responsible for paying the recording fees as specified by the clerk of the superior court of the county. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-112. - Review of final plat. 
The county inspector shall check the final plat for the following requirements: 
(1)  The county inspector shall check the plat for conformance to the regulations of this chapter; and if the final plat is found to be in compliance, the county inspector will schedule the consideration of the final plat on the agenda at the next board of commissioners' meeting. However, if the final plat is found to be deficient, the consideration of the final plat will not be placed on the agenda for the next board of commissioners' meeting; and the county inspector will notify the developer in writing of the deficiencies and give the developer an opportunity to correct the deficiencies. The consideration of the final plat shall be placed on the board of commissioners' agenda at the second meeting that occurs after the final plat has been submitted. 
(2)  If the preliminary plat is waived by the board of commissioners to the procedures and requirements outlined in section 58-87, the board of commissioners shall examine and approve the final plat using the plat specifications outlined in section 58-84 et seq. 
(3)  The board of commissioners shall approve or disapprove the final plat. A notation of the action shall be made on the original tracing and two prints of the final plat, including a statement of the reasons therefor if the final plat is disapproved. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-113. - Approval of final plat. 
(a)  Upon approval of the final plat, the county inspector will notify the subdivider; and the subdivider may, within one year, proceed to build the roads and lay the utility, stormwater and sanitary sewer lines. 
(b)  The building inspector, after receipt of the funds from the developer to pay the clerk's recording fee of the final plat, shall record the final plat in the office of the clerk of the superior court. Subsequent to the recording of the final plat, with all certificates endorsed thereon, a copy shall be filed with the records of the county inspector and the recording information of the plat indicated on the copy. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-114. - Final plat requirements. 
The final plat shall conform to and meet the specifications of the preliminary plat and the following additional specifications. The original final plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn in permanent ink on reproducible copy paper or other reproducible media at the following minimum scale: 
1—4 acre tract: 100 feet to the inch. 
5—10 acre tract: 200 feet to the inch. 
Over 10 acre tract: 500 feet to the inch. 
Blue-lined copies of the original plat will be accepted. Original sheet sizes shall be 24 × 36 inches; and where more than one sheet is required, an index map shall be provided on the same size sheet. The final plat shall show: 
(1)  Bearings and distances of the subdivision boundaries to the nearest existing street lines or other permanent monuments (not less than three) accurately described on the plat. 
(2)  Municipal, county and land lot lines accurately tied to the boundary lines of the subdivision by distance and angles when such lines traverse or are reasonably close to the subdivision. 
(3)  Exact boundary lines of the tract, determined by a field survey, giving distances to the nearest tenth of a foot and angles to the nearest minute, which shall be balanced and closed with an error of closure not to exceed 1:5,000. 
(4)  Name of the subdivision and the exact location, widths and names of all streets and alleys within and immediately adjoining the plat. 
(5)  Street centerlines showing angles of deflection, angles of intersection, radii and lengths of tangents. 
(6)  Lot lines with dimensions to the nearest tenth of a foot. 
(7)  Lots numbered in numerical order. 
(8)  Location, dimensions, and purposes of any easements and any areas to be reserved or dedicated for public use. 
(9)  Accurate location, material and description of monuments and markers. 
(10)  A statement, either directly on the plat or in an identified attached document, of any private covenants. 
(11)  The actual location of all utility easements. 
(12)  The following certifications: 
a.  A surveyor's certification, directly on the final plat as follows: 
It is hereby certified that this plat is true and correct and was prepared from an actual survey of the property by me or under my supervision; that all monuments shown thereon actually exist and their location, size, type and material are correctly shown; and that all requirements of the Land Subdivision Regulations of Sumter County, Georgia, have been fully complied with. 

 
b.  An Owner's Certification, directly on the final plat as follows: 
Owner's Certificate  State of Georgia, County of Sumter. 
The owner(s) of the land shown on this plat and whose name(s) are subscribed hereto, in person or through a duly authorized agent, certifies that this plat was made from an actual survey, that all state and county taxes or other assessments now due on this land have been paid. 

 
c.  Certificate of dedication. A certificate by the owner setting forth the description of the areas and improvements dedicated to the public and the extent of the title should be attached to the final plat. Because of the legal consideration, this certificate shall be approved as to form by the county attorney. 
d.  A certificate of approval of the final plat by the county commission, directly on the plat, as follows: 
Pursuant to the Land Subdivision Regulations of Sumter County Georgia, all the requirements of approval having been fulfilled, this final plat was approved by the Sumter County Commission on ________, 20___. 

 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Secs. 58-115—58-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - AS-BUILT PLAT PROCEDURE 

Sec. 58-136. - As-built plat requirements. 
The as-built plat shall conform to and meet the specifications of the final plat specifications and the requirements of division 3 of this article. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-137. - Filing and recording of as-built plat. 
(a)  After the subdivision or a phase of the subdivision, if the subdivision is developed in phases, has been developed, the subdivider shall present to the county inspector the as-built plat, which shall include the following: 
(1)  Three copies, 18 × 24, of the subdivision, or that portion that has been completed. 
(2)  The actual location of all utility lines. 
(3)  Profiles and invert elevations of all stormwater and sanitary sewer lines, as built. 
(4)  Centerline profiles of all streets, as built. 
(5)  One complete set of construction plans and drawings. 
(b)  Upon receipt of the as-built plat as defined in subsection (a) of this section, the building inspector shall inspect the plat for compliance with the requirements in subsection (a) of this section. If the requirements in subsection (a) of this section have been satisfied, the building inspector shall place the consideration of the as-built plat on the agenda at the next board of commissioners' meeting. If the as-built plat is deficient, the building inspector shall not place the consideration of the as-built plat on the next agenda, but shall notify the developer in writing of the deficiencies. The developer will have an opportunity to correct the as-built plat and resubmit the as-built plat to the county inspector. If the as-built plat has been resubmitted to the county inspector at least five days prior to the next meeting of the board of commissioners, the consideration of the as-built plat will be placed on the agenda for its consideration by the board of commissioners. If the as-built plat is submitted less than five days prior to the next meeting of the board of commissioners, the consideration of the as-built plat will be placed on the agenda at the next following meeting. 
(c)  The streets of the subdivision shall not be accepted by the board of commissioners until the as-built plat has been accepted and approved by the board of commissioners. Upon acceptance and approval of the as-built plat, the following certification shall be affixed to the final as-built plat: 
Pursuant to the Land Subdivision Regulations of Sumter County, Georgia, all requirements of the as-built plat having been fulfilled, this as-built plat was approved by the Sumter County Commissioners on the _____ day of ________, 20___. 

 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Secs. 58-138—58-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DESIGN REQUIREMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-171. - Suitability of land. 
Land subject to flooding, improper drainage or erosion or land that is for topographical or other reasons unsuitable for residential use shall not be platted for residential use nor for any other use that will continue or increase the danger to health, safety or property destruction unless the hazards can be and are corrected. The board of commissioners shall seek advice from public works and the county engineer and public health officials and others as deemed appropriate by the board of commissioners on the suitability of land for residential use. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-172. - Name of subdivision. 
(a)  The developer of a subdivision shall submit the name of the subdivision on the preliminary plat for approval by the board of commissioners as part of the preliminary plat approval process as set forth herein. 
(b)  The name of the subdivision shall not duplicate nor closely approximate the name of any existing subdivision. The name of the subdivision shall be posted on a permanent, weatherproof sign, minimum size 4 × 4 feet and maximum size 4 × 8 feet, located at the main entrance or entrances of the subdivision, and not obscured by any shrubs, trees, hedges or structures. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-173. - Access. 
Access to every subdivision shall be provided over a public street; however, the streets in the subdivision may be private streets. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-174. - Entrance over dam prohibited. 
A subdivision will not be accepted or approved if the only entrance or access is over a dam. Primary access must be provided over a public street that does not traverse a dam. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-175. - Dedications. 
When features of other plans adopted by the board of commissioners (such as schools or other public building sites, parks, or other land for public uses) are located in whole or in part in a land subdivision, such features shall be either dedicated or reserved by the subdivider for acquisition within a reasonable time by the appropriate public agency. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-176. - Rejection of dedication. 
Whenever a plat proposes the dedication of land to public use that the board of commissioners finds not required or suitable for such public use, the board of commissioners shall refuse to approve the plat and shall notify the land developer and the governing body of the reasons for such action. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-177. - Large-scale developments. 
The requirements of this chapter may be modified in the case of a large-scale community or PUD such as a housing project or shopping center, which may or may not be subdivided into customary lots, blocks and streets, if the development meets the requirements of the ordinances of the county, is approved by the board of commissioners, and if it is in conformity with the purpose and intent of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-178. - Lots on existing dirt road. 
(a)  When a developer subdivides lots on an existing dirt road, and the existing right-of-way for the dirt road is less than the minimum right-of-way for county paved roads, the developer shall reserve sufficient right-of-way, as measured from the centerline of the future paved road, as set by the county engineer, for the future widening and improvement of the road. The developer shall convey a vested future interest in the reserved right-of-way to the county and the title to the right-of-way shall vest in the county at such time as the county decides to pave the road. Written notice of such intention to the then landowner over whose land the reservation is situated, shall vest the title to the right-of-way in the county at no cost to the county. 
(b)  The existing dirt road mentioned in this section means an existing public dirt road that the public has a right to use, and which road is a part of the network of the public transportation system of the county, and does not include an existing dirt road that may be located in an unapproved subdivision. The conveyance of the additional right-of-way to the county is the conveyance of a future interest and not a present interest and such conveyance does not mean the county accepts the road, nor does it exempt the road from the requirement that, if and when the road is paved, it shall be paved to county standards. 
(c)  Lots that are subdivided on an existing dirt road must otherwise meet the other requirements of the subdivision ordinance of the county. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-179. - Dam specifications. 
If the subdivision contains a pond or a lake, the following specifications and regulations shall apply: 
(1)  All dams shall be built and constructed in conformity with state department of soil conservation specifications and shall be certified by a registered engineer. 
(2)  All drawings of the dam specifications and construction shall be stamped and sealed by a certified registered engineer and submitted to the county inspector before construction begins. 
(3)  All subdivisions that have a pond or lake shall form a homeowners association prior to the selling of the first lot and shall present to the board of commissioners at the time of approval of the final plat a certificate of the secretary of state certifying the existence of the homeowners association. 
(4)  The articles of the homeowners association shall provide that the lot owners shall have a pro rata ownership interest in the improvements of the subdivision owned by the homeowners association, if any. It is recommended that upon 80 percent of the lots in the subdivision being sold, the developer convey title to the dam, lake and pond in the subdivision to the homeowners association. 
(5)  The county does not and will not accept title or responsibility for any dam or lake and will not accept title or responsibility for any street that traverses a dam, and the county does not and will not accept any responsibility for the maintenance of the dam or any street that traverses the dam. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-180. - Required improvements. 
(a)  Prior to the approval of the final plat, an agreement shall have been reached between the subdivider or his agent and the county government with regard to the installation of street improvements and utilities called for on the subdivision plat. 
(b)  Prior to the approval of the final plat, the subdivider shall be required to have installed by the appropriate county agency at his expense or, with approval of the agency concerned, to himself install the following street improvements and utilities: 
(1)  All street rights-of-way shall have ditches and tail ditches as required by the soil conservation requirements and by the county standard specifications for roads and streets. 
(2)  Where sanitary sewage facilities are available, sanitary sewer lines and manholes installed. 
(3)  When public water supply is available, water mains within the subdivision with fire hydrants and with connections to each lot. Minimum diameter of water pipes shall normally be six inches. 
(c)  All required street improvements, utilities and monuments shall be built to standards specified by the agency responsible for each. All utilities to be installed in the streets shall be placed and the soil shall be compacted prior to paving. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Secs. 58-181—58-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STREETS 

Sec. 58-201. - Continuation of existing streets. 
Existing streets in subdivisions shall be continued at the same or greater width, but in no case less than the required width. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-202. - Street names. 
Streets in subdivisions that are obviously in alignment with streets existing and named shall be given the name of the existing street. Names of new streets shall not duplicate nor closely approximate those of existing streets. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-203. - Street jogs. 
Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall not be permitted. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-204. - Culs-de-sac. 
Culs-de-sac and dead-end streets shall not be greater in length than 800 feet, except as approved by the board of commissioners when topographic or other conditions make a greater length necessary. Culs-de-sac and dead-end streets shall have a closed end with a turnaround having a property line radius of at least 80 feet, with an outside pavement radius of at least 60 feet; provided, however, that culs-de-sac and dead-end streets constructed prior to December 1, 2015 shall have a closed end with a turnaround having a property line radius of at least 60 feet with an outside pavement radius of at least 50 feet. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06; Ord. of 12-15-15(2)) 
Sec. 58-205. - Development along major thoroughfare, limited-access highway or railroad right-of-way. 
Where a subdivision abuts or contains a major thoroughfare, a limited-access highway or a railroad right-of-way, the board of commissioners may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way either as a marginal-access street or, at a distance suitable for an appropriate use of the intervening land, with a nonaccess reservation suitably planted. Due regard should be given requirements for approach grades and future grade separations in determining distances. Lots shall not have direct access to a major thoroughfare or limited-access highway, but only to access streets. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-206. - Alleys. 
Alleys may be constructed at the rear of all lots, whether they are used for one-family, multifamily, commercial or industrial purposes. If the subdivision contains alleys, such alleys shall provide access to the lot and a location for certain utilities, and facilitate garbage collection. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-207. - Easements. 
Easements having a minimum width of ten feet and located along the side or rear lot lines in subdivisions shall be provided, as required, for utilities. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-208. - Watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream traverse. 
Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater or drainage right-of-way of adequate width. Parallel streets may be required by the board of commissioners in connection therewith. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-209. - Street specifications. 
All streets, public and private, shall be built, constructed and paved in conformity with the county standard specifications for roads and streets. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-210. - Street right-of-way widths. 
(a)  Street right-of-way widths shall be the distance across a street from property line to property line. Minimum street right-of-way widths shall be as follows: 
(1)  Major thoroughfares shall be 100 feet. 
(2)  Collector streets shall be 80 feet. 
(3)  Local streets, dead-end streets, and culs-de-sac shall be 80 feet. 
(4)  Interior streets shall be 80 feet. 
(5)  Alleys shall be 20 feet. 
(b)  If paved on or before April 11, 1995, notwithstanding the street widths required in paragraphs (3) and (4) of subsection (a) of this section, local and interior streets in an extension of a subdivision shall be a minimum of 50 feet wide. If paved after April 11, 1995, but before December 1, 2015, such streets shall be a minimum of 60 feet wide. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06; Ord. of 12-15-15(2)) 
Sec. 58-211. - Street intersections. 
Street intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as possible. No street intersection shall intersect at an angle of less than 90 degrees unless required by unusual conditions and approved by the board of commissioners; provided, however, that a street intersection constructed prior to December 1, 2015, may intersect at an angle of less than 90 degrees, but not less than 60 degrees unless otherwise approved by the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06; Ord. of 12-15-15(2)) 
Sec. 58-212. - Curbline radius. 
The curbline radius at street intersections shall be at least 25 feet. Where the angle of street intersection is less than 90 degrees, a longer radius may be required. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-213. - Road bed and street paving width. 
(a)  All major thoroughfares, local streets, and interior streets shall have a road bed of reasonably sufficient width as determined by the public works director. 
(b)  Street paving widths shall not be less than the following as measured from the edge of the pavement: 
(1)  Major thoroughfares with a median shall have two 14-foot lanes in each direction of travel. 
(2)  Major thoroughfares without a median shall be 62 feet (52 feet if paved prior to December 1, 2015). 
(3)  Local streets shall be 24 feet (20 feet if paved prior to April 12, 1995; and 22 feet if paved on or after April 12, 1995, but prior to December 1, 2015). 
(4)  Interior streets shall be 24 feet (20 feet if paved prior to April 12, 1995.) 
(Ord. of 12-15-15(2)) 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Dec. 15, 2015, amended § 58-213 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 58-213, pertained to street paving width, and derived from an ordinance adopted Sept. 19, 2006. 
Sec. 58-214. - Street improvement specifications. 
All major thoroughfares, connectors, and interior and local streets shall be constructed and improved in compliance with the standards established by the Sumter County Code of Ordinances or otherwise established by law. In addition, all such construction and improvements shall comply with the Georgia Department of Transportation's design specifications for roadway base and paving as set forth in the Georgia Department of Transportation's Design Policy Manual and other applicable policies." 
(Ord. of 9-19-06; Ord. of 12-15-15(2)) 
Secs. 58-215—58-235. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BLOCKS AND LOTS 

Sec. 58-236. - Block lengths and widths. 
Block lengths and widths shall be as follows: 
(1)  Blocks shall be not greater than 1,800 feet nor less than 600 feet in length, except in unusual circumstances. 
(2)  Blocks shall be wide enough to provide two tiers of lots of minimum depth, except where abutting upon major thoroughfares, limited-access highways, or railroads or where other situations make this requirement impracticable. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-237. - Lot sizes. 
(1)  All residential lots shall conform to the minimum dimension and area requirements as established by the Sumter County Zoning Ordinance (Appendix A) for the applicable zone for each such lot. 
(2)  There shall be no more than four lots located on a cul-de-sac. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-238. - Minimum building setback lines. 
The minimum building setback lines shall conform to the minimum building setback lines as established by the Sumter County Zoning Ordinance (Appendix A) for the applicable zone for each such lot. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06) 
Sec. 58-239. - Double-frontage and reverse-frontage lots. 
Double-frontage and reverse-frontage lots should be avoided except where essential to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. A planting screen easement of at least ten feet, across which there shall be no right of access, shall be provided along the line of lots abutting such a traffic artery or other incompatible use. 
(Ord. of 9-19-06)

Sec. 62-66. - Imposed. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-8-110 et seq., there is hereby authorized to be levied and collected within the county a sales and use tax in the amount of one percent on all sales and uses in the county for a period of time not to exceed five years from the date of adoption of the resolution from which this section derives to raise not more than $10,000,000.00. Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Local depository financial institutions business license tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 

Sec. 62-101. - Levied. 
In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-6-90 et seq., and more particularly, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93, all depository financial institutions with an office located within Sumter County shall pay an annual business license tax at a rate of 0.25 percent of the depository financial institution's Georgia gross receipts. This return shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of revenue based on the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The board of commissioners shall assess and collect the tax levied pursuant to this section based upon the information provided in the return. 
(Res. of 10-11-83, § 3) 
Sec. 62-104. - Due date of taxes. 
Taxes levied pursuant to this article shall be due no later than 30 days after filing of the return prescribed by section 62-103 unless extended by the board of commissioners. 
(Res. of 10-11-83, § 4)

Footnotes:

ARTICLE VI. - AD VALOREM TAXES 

Sec. 62-170. - Judicial in rem tax foreclosures for delinquent ad valorem taxes. 
(a)  Sumter County shall be authorized to proceed with judicial in rem tax foreclosures for delinquent taxes in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-4-5. 
(b)  The right to proceed with judicial in rem tax foreclosures shall be in addition to any other rights and remedies provided under state or local law for the enforcement of tax liens, and nothing in this section shall prohibit the collection of delinquent ad valorem taxes in any other manner as allowed by state or local law. 
(c)  Proceedings in accordance with this section are designed solely to enforce a lien for ad valorem taxes against the property subject to such taxation and shall not constitute an action for personal liability for such taxes of the owner or owners of such property. 
(Ord. of 2-17-15)

ARTICLE III. - NO PARKING ZONES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate or prohibit stopping, standing or parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1); stopping, standing and parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200 et seq.; power of local authorities generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371. 

Sec. 66-66. - Enumerated. 
Parking of vehicles shall be prohibited at all times on the following roads and portions of roads within the county: 
(1)  Along the right-of-way of Murphys Mill Road from that point where Lake Jennifer Road intersects Murphys Mill Road to that point where Murphys Mill Road intersects the western right-of-way of Tommy Hooks Road. There shall be no fishing from the bridge on that road, and "No Parking" and "No Fishing" signs shall be erected. 
(2)  Along the right-of-way of Thomas Drive, beginning at the intersection of U.S. Highway 280 West, along Thomas Drive to the intersection of Felder Street. The board of commissioners does authorize and direct that "No Parking" signs be placed along the restricted zones. 
(3)  On the right-of-way of Georgia Highway 30 measuring 300 yards from each end of the bridge that traverses Muckalee Creek. The board of commissioners authorize and direct that "No Parking" signs be placed in the no parking zone. 
(4)  The right-of-way of the Hooks Mill Road, measuring 650 feet from each end of the bridge that traverses Philema Creek. The board of commissioners does resolve that no fishing be allowed from the bridge located over Philema Creek on the Hooks Mill Road. The board of commissioners does authorize and direct that "No Parking" and "No Fishing From Bridge" signs be placed in the restricted zones. 
(Res. of 10-13-87; Res. of 12-13-94; Res. of 6-11-96) 
Secs. 66-67—66-99. - Reserved. 
Sec. 66-100. - Prohibition on parking heavy vehicles on county right-of-way. 
It shall be unlawful for any vehicle designated by the department of public safety for a license tag in a weight category of 6,000 pounds or more or any vehicle which actually weighs 6,000 pounds or more to park on the right-of-way of any county road, regardless of whether the vehicle is operating. 
(Ord. of 4-14-15) 
Sec. 66-101. - Exceptions. 
This article shall not apply to a vehicle that is on the county's right-of-way for any of the following purposes: 
(1)  Engaging in any public works, law enforcement, emergency response, roadside assistance, towing, or other activities related to public safety; 
(2)  Loading, unloading, or making deliveries for a period not to exceed three hours when other adequate parking is not reasonably available; and 
(3)  Performing repairs that are reasonably necessary to enable the operator of the vehicle to safely move it to a location off the right-of-way. 
All operators of vehicles on the county's right-of-way for any of the purposes stated in this section shall take reasonable safety precautions to alert approaching motorists. 
(Ord. of 4-14-15) 
Sec. 66-102. - Violations. 
(a)  Anyone operating or in control of a vehicle which violates this article shall be responsible for any violation thereof. 
(b)  Upon the first violation of this article, the violator shall be punished in accordance with section 1-11, but in no event less than a fine of $300.00. 
(c)  Upon the second violation of this article, the violator shall be punished in accordance with section 1-11, but in no event less than a fine of $500.00. 
(d)  Upon any subsequent violation of this article and for any other violations of this article, the violator shall be punished in accordance with section 1-11 without limitation. 
(e)  Any vehicle parked in violation of this article shall be deemed a nuisance posing a threat to the public's health or safety and shall be subject to abatement as otherwise provided by law. 
(Ord. of 4-14-15) 
Sec. 66-103. - Payment for damages to road or right-of-way. 
(a)  In addition to any fine or penalty provided for herein, anyone who violates this article shall be responsible for payment of the cost of repair for any damages to any county road or right-of-way caused by said violation. 
(b)  Payment of the cost of repair shall be due in full no later than 30 days after the date the county issues a written demand for payment to the violator. 
(c)  The written demand for payment shall include a description of the damages and the cost for repair, including the total materials and labor reasonably necessary to restore any county road or right-of-way to its condition prior to the damage complained of. 
(d)  The demand may be personally delivered to the violator, mailed to the address of record on the registration of the vehicle which resulted in the violation of this article, or may be mailed to any address provided by or verified by the violator. 
(Ord. of 4-14-15)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - RIGHT-OF-WAY USE 

Sec. 70-31. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— § 1 of an ordinance adopted Jan. 19, 2016, repealed the former § 70-31, which pertained to compliance by utility companies required and derived from the preamble of an ordinance adopted Feb. 13, 1996. 
Sec. 70-32. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— § 1 of an ordinance adopted Jan. 19, 2016, repealed the former § 70-32, which pertained to utility companies and derived from § A of an ordinance adopted Feb. 13, 1996; and an ordinance adopted May 14, 1996. 
Sec. 70-33. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— § 1 of an ordinance adopted Jan. 19, 2016, repealed the former § 70-33, which pertained to private persons and corporations other than utility companies and derived from § B of an ordinance adopted Feb. 13, 1996. 
Sec. 70-34. - Installation of utilities on county's right-of-way. 
(a)  General provisions. 
(1)  Application for permit. Prior to beginning construction activity for the installation, construction, maintenance, removal, or relocation of utilities in, on, along, over, or under the public roads of the county which are a part of the county's road system lying outside the corporate limits of any municipalities, any public or private utility company, person, or entity desiring to engage in such activity shall first submit a written application for a utility right-of-way permit to the public works department. The application shall contain the nature, extent, and location of the portion of the utilities, roads, and rights-of-way affected thereby and any other information required by the public works department. An application fee of $200.00 per physical location and proof of an indemnity bond in compliance with subsection (e) of this section shall be attached to the application and shall be a prerequisite for approval of the application. A detailed drawing showing the exact location of the work to be performed shall be attached to the application. Upon request, the permittee shall also make all project drawings available to the public works department free of charge and at no expense to the county. Any proposed changes to the original or an amended application shall be submitted in writing to the public works department for its advance approval. The public works department retains the right to reject any application not in compliance with the Code of Ordinances of Sumter County or any applicable state or federal laws or as otherwise authorized by law. 
(2)  Notice. If an application is approved by the public works department and a permit issued, the permittee shall provide the public works department 48 hours' prior written notice before engaging in any actual construction activity. Written notice may be provided by U.S. mail, hand delivery, or email. 
(3)  Location of utilities. It shall be the sole responsibility of the permittee to determine the location of any existing utilities in the area in which the permittee will be working. 
(4)  General specifications. 
a.  All utilities installed pursuant to this section shall be placed in a conduit pipe and installed by road cutting, jacking, or boring. An open cut will not be permitted when, in the discretion of the public works director, it is reasonably practical to bore or tunnel under the roadway or to use another alternate method to avoid cutting the roadway. 
b.  Regardless of the type of installation, all conduits shall be 25 percent greater in diameter than the pipe or utility that will be placed within the conduit pipe. The length of the conduit pipe must be sufficiently adequate to span the entire width of the right-of-way. The grade for the top of the conduit pipe must be at a depth of not less than two feet below the lowest ditch grade. 
c.  Cuts on the shoulder of the road shall be filled, refilled, and maintained at the permittee's expense to the reasonable satisfaction of the public works department. 
(5)  Standards for installation. All installations of utilities and conduit pipes shall comply with all applicable federal, state, and local soil and erosion requirements. In addition, the public works department may require compliance with any or all of the utility accommodation standards and specifications, the manual on traffic control procedures for utilities, and any other regulations adopted by the Georgia Department of Transportation regarding utilities on the state highway system pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 32-6-174, as amended from time to time. 
(b)  Open cutting details. All open cutting of the road shall comply with the following: 
(1)  Metal plates shall be placed over any cut in the pavement to provide for the continuous flow of traffic until the pavement is repaired. 
(2)  All paving repairs shall be conducted in compliance with the Georgia Department of Transportation standards required for Class A Pavement Replacement. 
(3)  With the exception of Crisp County, Georgia, and any public utility companies, the permittee shall hire an independent, qualified expert to test the compaction of the repair and shall furnish the name and address of such expert to the public works department, along with a complete copy of the expert's reports and findings. 
(c)  Jacking details. All jacking details shall comply with the following: 
(1)  Suitable pits or trenches shall be excavated for the jacking operation as needed. Such pits or trenches shall be securely sheeted and braced when necessary to prevent caving. 
(2)  When a conduit pipe is installed under a roadway by jacking, construction shall be performed in a manner that does not interfere with the operation of the roadway and does not weaken the roadbed or roadbed structures. 
(3)  Jacks for forcing the conduit pipe through the roadbed shall have a jacking head constructed in a manner that applies uniform pressure around the ring of the pipe during the jacking operation. When jacking a conduit pipe, the conduit pipe shall be set on guides and braced together so as to properly support and direct the section of the pipe to the proper line and grade. 
(4)  The diameter of the excavation shall conform to the outside diameter and circumference of the conduit pipe as closely as possible. Any voids that develop during the jacking operation that are determined by the Public Works Department to be detrimental to the work shall be pressure grouted with a mixture approved by the public works Department. 
(5)  The line and grade must be preapproved by the public works department. 
(d)  Boring details. All boring details shall comply with the following: 
(1)  Boring shall proceed from a pit provided for the boring equipment and workmen. The holes shall be bored mechanically. 
(2)  The use of water or other fluids in connection with the boring operation shall be permitted only to the extent necessary to lubricate cuttings. Jetting or jetting operations shall not be permitted. 
(3)  The diameter of the excavation shall conform to the outside diameter and circumference of the conduit pipe as closely as possible. Any voids that develop during the boring operation that are determined by the public works department to be detrimental to the work shall be pressure grouted with a mixture approved by the public works department. 
(4)  The line and grade must be preapproved by the public works department. 
(e)  Penalties for noncompliance and bond. 
(1)  In addition to any fine or penalty, any person or entity violating any of the provisions of this article shall reimburse the county for any and all expenses incurred by the county in correcting the violator's work, whether by repair or replacement as determined by the public works department, and performing any work the violator failed to perform in full compliance with this section. Payment for any such expenses shall be due within 30 days of the date the public works department mails or hand delivers an invoice for said expenses to the violator's last known address. 
(2)  With the exception of Crisp County, Georgia, and any public utility companies, an applicant shall furnish an indemnity bond in the amount of $5,000.00 conditioned to pay any damages to any part of the county's road system or to any member of the public caused by work performed under authority of a permit issued pursuant to this section. The bond shall be a cash bond or a bond of a reputable surety acceptable to the public works department. Failure to comply with any of the requirements of this section shall result in forfeiture of the permittee's bond in the amount necessary to correct the violator's work, whether by repair or replacement as determined by the public works department, and to perform any work the violator failed to perform in full compliance with this section. 
(3)  In addition to forfeiture of any bond, any person or entity violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-11. 
(4)  Nothing in this section shall alter the county's right pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 32-4-42(6), as amended from time to time, to order the removal or discontinuance of any utility, equipment, or other items installed pursuant to this section at the sole expense of the owner of said items. 
(Ord. of 1-19-16, § 2) 
Editor's note— § 2 of an ordinance adopted Jan. 19, 2016, repealed the former § 70-34 and enacted a new section to read as set out herein. The former § 70-34 pertained to cut requirements and derived from § C of an ordinance adopted Feb. 13, 1996. 
Sec. 70-35. - Driveways. 
(a)  Anyone installing a driveway on the county's right-of-way must first apply to the code enforcement office to obtain a permit for installation of the driveway. 
(b)  All driveways installed on the county's right-of-way shall be in conformity with the specifications issued by the code enforcement office. 
(c)  The public works department may install driveways on the county's right-of-way upon request of the owner of the real property and upon payment of a fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. 
(Ord. of 1-19-16, § 3) 
Editor's note— § 3 of an ordinance adopted Jan. 19, 2016, repealed the former § 70-35 and enacted a new section to read as set out herein. The former § 70-35 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from § D of an ordinance adopted April 9, 1996. 
ARTICLE III. - STANDARDS FOR WIRELESS COMMUNICATION FACILITIES 

Sec. 70-36. - Purpose and intent. 
The purpose of this article is to establish guidelines for the siting of all wireless communications towers and antennas which will encourage the development of a competitive wireless communications marketplace while protecting the health, safety and welfare of the public and maintaining the aesthetic integrity of the community. The goals of this article are: 
(1)  To protect residential areas and land uses from potential adverse impact of telecommunications towers, antenna support structures and wireless communications facilities; 
(2)  To minimize the total number of towers and antennas within the community necessary to provide adequate personal wireless services to residents of the county; 
(3)  To promote and encourage the joint use of new and existing tower sites among service providers; 
(4)  To locate telecommunications towers and antennas in areas where adverse impacts on the community are minimized; 
(5)  To encourage the design and construction of towers and antennas to minimize adverse visual impacts; 
(6)  To avoid potential damage to property caused by wireless communications facilities by insuring that such structures are soundly and carefully designed, constructed, modified, maintained and removed when no longer used or when determined to be structurally unsound; 
(7)  To enhance the ability of the providers of wireless communications services to deliver such services to the community effectively and efficiently; and 
(8)  To preserve those areas of significant scenic or historic merit. 
(Ord. of 10-18-05) 
Sec. 70-37. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Accessory use means a tower and/or antenna is considered an accessory use if located on a lot or parcel shared with a different existing primary use or existing structure. 
Alternative tower structure means man-made trees, clock towers, bell steeples, light poles and similar alternative-design mounting structures of a type and quality consistent with structures manufactured by a qualified company that in the opinion of the planning director or his/her designee are compatible with the natural setting and surrounding structures, and effectively camouflage or conceal the presence of antennas or towers. 
Antenna means any exterior transmitting or receiving devices mounted on a tower, building or structure and used in communications that radiate or capture electromagnetic waves, digital signals, analog signals, radio, wireless, telecommunications signals or other communications signals. Such definition does not include, for purposes of this article, radar antennas, amateur radio antennas, satellite earth stations, MMDS antennas, television receiving antennas and direct broadcast satellite dishes. 
Co-location means the placement of antennas of two or more service providers on the same tower or accessory structure. 
Economically and technically feasible and viable means capable of being provided: 
(1)  Through technology which has been demonstrated in actual applications (not simply through tests or experiments) to operate in a workable manner; and 
(2)  In a manner which has a reasonable likelihood of generating a reasonable profit or other financial benefits, when measured over the term of the lease. 
Height means, when referring to a tower or other structure, height means a distance measured from the finished grade of the parcel to the highest point on the tower or other structure, including the base pad and any antenna. 
Historic or scenic views means geographic areas in the county which have been formally designated on the national historic register; have been included in any nature preserve or scenic preservation efforts; have been identified in the county comprehensive plan; or have sufficient historic or scenic merit as determined by the planning and zoning department or the board of commissioners. A scenic view may be from a stationary viewpoint or be seen as one travels along a roadway or path. 
Microcell means a wireless communication facility comprising an antenna extending no more than four feet above the structure to which it is attached, and with an area no larger than 576 square inches (e.g. 3′ × 1½′ panel antenna or 2′ diameter parabolic antenna) as viewed from any one point. 
Preexisting towers and preexisting antenna means any structure that is designed and constructed primarily for the purpose of supporting one or more antennas, including self-supported or monopole towers. The term includes radio and television transmission towers, microwave towers, common-carrier towers and cellular telephone or PCS towers. 
Principal use means a tower and/or antenna is considered a principal use if located on any lot or parcel of land as the sole or primary structure. 
Tower means any structure that is designed and constructed primarily for the purpose of supporting one or more antennas, including self-supported or monopole towers. The term includes radio and television transmission towers, microwave towers, common carrier towers, and cellular telephone or PCS towers. 
Wireless transmission facilities means the buildings, cabinets, equipment and property, including but not limited to, generating and switching stations, repeaters, cables, wires, conduits, ducts, pedestals, antennas, towers, alternative towers structures, electronics and other appurtenances used to transmit, receive, distribute, provide or offer low-power mobile voice transmission, data transmission or other wireless communications by linking a wireless network of radio wave transmitting devices through a series of short range, contiguous cells that are part of an evolving cell grid. 
(Ord. of 10-18-05) 
Sec. 70-38. - Applicability. 
All new towers and antennas shall be subject to the regulations contained within this article except as provided in subsections (1)—(3), inclusive: 
(1)  Public property. Nothing in this article shall be read to prohibit a government owned tower from being located at a specific site when the tower is required to protect the public welfare or safety. 
(2)  Amateur radio, receive-only antennas. This article shall not govern any amateur radio tower, or the installation of any antenna, that is under 70 feet in height and is owned and operated by a federally licensed amateur radio station operator or is used exclusively for receive only antennas. 
(3)  Pre-existing towers and antennas. Any tower or antenna for which a permit has been properly issued prior to the effective date of this article shall not be required to meet the provisions of this article, other than the requirements of section 70-42. Any such towers or antennae shall be referred to in this article as "preexisting towers" or "preexisting antennae." 
If additional antennas are co-located upon a pre-existing tower after adoption of this article, then fencing and landscaping requirements shall be met as part of the permitting process. 
(Ord. of 10-18-05) 
Sec. 70-39. - General requirements. 
(a)  An application shall be required for the construction or placement of all new wireless transmission facilities within the county limits. Approval of any application for the construction of a tower or placement of an antenna shall be based on consideration of the following factors: 
(1)  The proposed height of the tower, if any; 
(2)  Proximity to residential structures and residential district boundaries; 
(3)  Nature of uses on adjacent properties; 
(4)  Surrounding topography, tree coverage and foliage; 
(5)  Design of the facility, with particular reference to design characteristics which have the effect of reducing or eliminating visual obtrusiveness; 
(6)  Proposed ingress and egress; 
(7)  Availability of suitable existing towers, other structures, or alternative technologies (microcells) not requiring the use of towers or structures; 
(8)  Demonstrated need for the telecommunications facility at the specified site; 
(9)  Approval of applications for co-location shall be based on all the foregoing factors, but primarily on consideration of factor (8). 
(b)  All applications submitted to the planning and zoning department shall include a complete inventory of the applicant's existing wireless transmission facilities including towers and receivers/transmitters located within the county and a one-half mile surrounding the county limits, including each asset's location (plane coordinates), height and co-location usage or capabilities, and any special design features. The planning and zoning department shall utilize such information, subject to any restrictions on disclosure requested by the applicant, to promote co-location alternatives for other applicants. 
(c)  At the time of filing the application for construction or placement of a wireless transmission facility, the applicant shall provide a site plan and information regarding tower or accessory structure location, neighboring uses and proposed landscaping as described below. Additional documentation to be submitted with the site plan and certified by an experienced radio frequency engineer shall delineate coverage and propagation zones, identify types of antenna and mounting location, specify the type of band currently in use and state co-location capabilities. 
(1)  The scaled site plan shall clearly indicate the location, type and height of the proposed tower or accessory structure to be utilized, on-site land uses and zoning, adjacent land uses and zoning including proximity to historic or scenic view corridors, adjacent roadways, proposed means of access, setbacks for property lines, elevation drawings of the proposed tower, accessory structure and any other structures, topography, parking and other information deemed necessary by the planning director or his/her designee to assess compliance with this article. 
(2)  Legal description of the parent tract and leased parcel (if applicable). 
(3)  A definition of the area of coverage and radio frequency goals to be served by the antenna or tower and the extent to which such antenna or tower is needed for coverage and/or capacity. 
(4)  The setback distance between the proposed wireless transmission facility and the nearest residential unit or residentially used structure if less than 500 feet. 
(5)  Structural integrity analysis where antennas and equipment will be attached to an existing structure. 
(6)  Landscaping shall be designed in such a way as to preserve existing mature growth and to provide in the determination of the planning director or his/her designee, a suitable buffer of plant materials that mitigates the view of the telecommunications facility and accessory structures from surrounding property. 
(d)  Each application shall be accompanied by a fee, determined by the board of commissioners, to offset the costs associated with processing such application. In addition, applicants shall be responsible for independent engineering costs incurred by the county which exceed such fee up to an additional $300.00 and any fees commonly charged for a rezoning if one is required, or for any other required permit fees. 
(e)  Landscaping plans and the design and placement of the wireless transmission facility on an approved site plan shall require review and approval of the planning director or his/her designee prior to issuance of a building permit to insure compliance with this article. 
(f)  Prior to issuance of a building permit, compliance with Section 106 of the National Historic Preservation Act, 16 U.S.C. § 461 et seq. shall be demonstrated. 
(g)  In approving any application, the planning director may impose additional conditions to the extent determined necessary to minimize adverse effects on adjoining properties. 
(Ord. of 10-18-05) 
Sec. 70-40. - Development requirements for towers. 
(a)  Towers may be located only in the following zoning districts subject to the restrictions and standards contained herein, and subject to Appendix A ("Zoning") of Sumter County Ordinances: 

 
Wireless transmission facilities in any other zoning districts shall be accessory uses or alternative tower structures only; provided however, towers may be allowed on publicly owned property regardless of zoning district. 
(b)  Separation. Except in cases of co-location on the same tower or accessory structure, no wireless transmission facilities shall be located within 2,500 feet of any preexisting tower or preexisting antenna within the county unless such facility or preexisting tower or antenna is concealed through use of alternative tower structures or otherwise camouflaged in such a way that the presence of telecommunications equipment is virtually undetectable from any adjoining property. 
(c)  All applicants seeking to erect a tower must demonstrate that no existing tower or structure can accommodate the proposed antenna(s). Evidence of an engineering nature shall be documented by the submission of a certification by an engineer. Such evidence may consist of the following: 
(1)  No existing towers or structures are located within the geographic area required to meet applicant's engineering requirements. 
(2)  No existing structure is of sufficient height to meet the applicant's engineering requirements. 
(3)  No existing tower or structure has sufficient structural strength to support applicant's proposed antenna(s) and related equipment. 
(4)  Applicant's proposed antenna(s) would cause electromagnetic interference with the antenna(s) on the existing tower or structure. 
(5)  That the cost or contractual provisions required by the tower owner to share an existing tower or structure or to adapt an existing tower or structure for sharing are unreasonable. Costs exceeding new tower development are presumed to be unreasonable. 
(6)  Such other limiting factor(s) as may be demonstrated by the applicant. 
All evidence submitted shall be signed and sealed by appropriate licensed professionals or qualified industry experts. Such evidence shall be subject to independent verification by an engineer of the county's choosing. 
(d)  Setbacks. Setbacks for tower and above-ground transmission facilities shall be as follows: 
(1)  All transmission facilities, except buried portions, shall be set back from all adjoining properties zoned non-residential the distance required for that zoning district. 
(2)  When a tower is adjacent to a residential use, the tower and entire transmission facility must be set back from the nearest residential lot line a distance equal to the height of the tower. 
(e)  Unless otherwise specified by the planning director or his/her designee, tower shall be enclosed by vinyl chain link security fencing or other approved alternative not less than six feet in height and shall be equipped with an appropriate anti-climbing device. 
(f)  All new towers in excess of 100 feet which do not incorporate alternative design features must be designed and built in a manner that allows other entities to co-locate on the structures using the following guidelines: 
Maximum Telecommunications Tower Heights 

 
(g)  All towers and their related structures shall maximize the use of building materials, colors, textures, screening and landscaping that, in the opinion of the planning director or his/her designee, effectively blend the tower facilities within the surrounding natural setting and built environment. Where appropriate, towers shall be painted so as to reduce their visual obtrusiveness, subject to any applicable standards of the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA). 
(h)  If upon receipt of an application for the erection of any tower or alternative tower structure governed by this article, the planning director or his/her designee deems that the proposed structure may interfere with the use of the airways of the county by the public or interfere with the operation of existing or proposed airport facilities, a copy of the application shall be submitted by the planning and zoning department to the airport division of the department of transportation for review and recommendation. 
(Ord. of 10-18-05) 
Sec. 70-41. - Approval process. 
(a)  Uses subject to administrative approval. Subject to certification by the planning director of compliance with the general requirements, development requirements and standards enumerated above, the following uses may be administratively approved within 30 days of receiving application, supporting engineering certification and lease approval, if any, without the necessity of public hearing. 
(1)  Antennas or towers located on property owned, leased or otherwise controlled by the county provided accessory structures are located underground where technically feasible and a license, permit or lease authorizing such tower is thereafter approved by the county. 
(2)  Installing an antenna on an existing structure, so long as said installation is considered to be a stealth technology installation that does not significantly change the profile of the existing structure and so that the installation is not readily noticeable to the untrained eye. Such installations including cables leading to the antennas shall be painted to match the paint and colors on the existing structure and shall not protrude from the existing structure in a noticeable fashion. 
(3)  Co-location by installing an antenna on any existing tower or alternative tower structure. 
(4)  Replacing an existing tower with a new tower designed to accommodate two or more users so long as such new tower does not exceed the height limitations of subsection 70-40(f) and setback requirements of this article are met. After the replacement tower is built only one tower shall remain on such site. Support equipment shall, where technically feasible, be located underground. 
(5)  Locating any alternative tower structures (man-made trees, clock towers, bell steeples, or light poles that, based on staff determination, effectively camouflage or conceal towers and antennas) provided accessory structures are located underground where technically feasible or otherwise incorporated into the alternative structure. 
(6)  Installing any antenna or tower not to exceed the limitations contained in subsection 70-40(f) and provided accessory structures are located underground where technically feasible or shielded to the satisfaction of the planning director or his/her designee. 
If the planning director or his/her designee determine that any application for an administratively approved use does not meet the general application requirements, development requirements and/or standards enumerated herein, administrative approval of the application shall be denied provided substantial evidence exists to support such denial. Such evidence shall be summarized for the applicant along with a recommendation as to whether the applicant should pursue a variance or proceed to a public hearing as specified in subsection (b) below. Applicants may appeal the administrative denial to the county board of commissioners pursuant to the procedures described in Section _______ of Appendix A ("Zoning") of Sumter County Ordinances. Any other party aggrieved by the decision of the planning director or his/her designee may file an appeal to the board of commissioners including payment of the filing fee. For purposes of this section an aggrieved party is one who demonstrates that his or her property will suffer special damage as a result of the decision complained of rather than merely some damage that is common to all property owners and citizens similarly situated. 
The board of commissioners shall dispense with the appeal by either: 
(7)  A determination that the application is valid and meets all applicable criteria for an administratively approved use under this article, which shall result in the issuance of a permit. 
(8)  A determination that the application does not satisfy all applicable criteria for an approved administratively use under this article, but, owing to special conditions, a variance as to separation or setback requirements: 
a.  Will not be contrary to the public interest; 
b.  Will relieve unnecessary hardship; and 
c.  Shall preserve the intent and spirit of this article. 
(9)  A determination that the application does not satisfy all applicable criteria for an administratively approved use under this article and the deficiencies cannot, subject to the conditions listed above, properly be cured by a variance. 
Applications which do not satisfy all applicable criteria must, as a result, apply for a public hearing before the board of commissioners as specified in subsection (b) below. 
(b)  Other uses—Public hearing required. 
(1)  If the proposed tower or antenna is not included under the above described administratively approved uses, or the application does not on its face satisfy the development standards and other criteria specified herein, then a public hearing before the board of commissioners shall be required for the approval of the construction of a wireless transmission facility in all zoning districts. Applicants shall apply for a public hearing through the planning and zoning department and pay the required fee at such time. Applications, when complete, shall be placed on the next available agenda of the board of commissioners. At least 30 days prior to any scheduled hearing, the planning and zoning department shall cause a sign to be posted on the property and the publication of a public notice in a newspaper of general circulation. Said notice shall state the nature of the application, street location of the proposal and height of the proposed structure. 
(2)  Before approving an application for an "other use," the governing authority may impose conditions to the extent necessary to buffer or otherwise minimize any adverse effect of the proposed tower on adjoining properties. The factors considered in granting such a permit include those enumerated in sections 70-39 and 70-40. The board of commissioners may waive or reduce the burden on the applicant of one or more of these criteria, if, in their discretion doing so will advance the goals of this article as stated in section 70-36. 
(Ord. of 10-18-05) 
Sec. 70-42. - Maintenance of facilities. 
(a)  All wireless transmission facilities and related landscaping shall be maintained by the facility owner in good condition, order, and repair so that they shall not endanger the life or property of any person, nor shall they be a blight upon the property. 
(b)  To ensure the structural integrity of towers, the applicant of a tower or alternative tower structure shall ensure that it is maintained in compliance with standards contained in applicable local building codes and the applicable standards for towers that are published by the Electronic Industries Association, as amended from time to time. If, upon inspection, the county concludes that a tower fails to comply with all applicable codes and standards, or constitutes a danger to persons or property, then upon receipt of written notice to the applicant, said applicant shall have 15 days to bring the tower into compliance with such standards. If the applicant fails to bring the tower into compliance within the 15 days, the county may remove the tower at the applicant's expense. Prior to removal of any tower, the county may consider detailed plans submitted by the applicant for repair of substandard towers, and may grant a reasonable extension of the above referenced compliance period. Any such removal by the county shall be in the manner provided in O.C.G.A., §§ 41-2-7—41-2-17. 
(c)  All towers must meet or exceed current standards and regulations of the FAA, the FCC, and any other agency of the federal government with the authority to regulate towers and antennas. If such standards and regulations are changed, the owners of the towers and antennas governed by this article shall bring such towers and antennas into compliance with such revised standards and regulations within six months of the effective date of such standards and regulations unless a more or less stringent compliance schedule is mandated by the controlling federal agency. Failure to bring towers and antennas into compliance with such revised standards and regulations shall constitute grounds for the removal of the tower or antenna at the owner's expense. Any such removal by the county shall be in the manner provided in O.C.G.A., §§ 41-2-7—41-2-17. 
(d)  All maintenance or construction on wireless transmission facilities shall be performed by persons employed by or under contract to the owner between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. Monday through Friday except in cases of emergency. Access to facilities on county owned property shall be determined on a case-by-case basis by the department responsible for such property. The hours of access to county sites shall not exceed those specified above. Persons may not be present on site unless performing construction or maintenance at such site. 
(e)  The owner or user of any telecommunications facility shall be required to submit a "facility in use certification" annually to the license and permits department. Any antenna or tower that is not operated for a continuous period of 12 months or is not properly maintained shall be considered abandoned, and the owner of such antenna or tower shall remove same and any structures housing supporting equipment within 90 days of receipt of notice from the governing authority of such abandonment. If such antenna or tower is not removed or returned to good condition within said 90 days, the governing authority may remove such antenna or tower at the owner's expense. If there are two or more users of a single tower, then this provision shall not become effective until all users cease using the tower. 
(Ord. of 10-18-05) 
Sec. 70-43. - Waiver of requirements. 
No exception, waiver or variance to the conditions and requirements contained herein shall be granted unless expressly provided for in this article, or the board of commissioners find that the proposed tower or wireless transmission facility is necessary and essential to providing the applicant's service. 
(Ord. of 10-18-05) 
Secs. 70-44, 70-45. - Reserved. 
Sec. 70-46. - Facilities lease. 
The board of commissioners may, in its sole discretion which is hereby reserved, approve facilities leases for the location of wireless transmission facilities and other telecommunications facilities upon county-owned property. Neither this section, nor any other provision of this article shall be construed to create an entitlement or vested right in any person or entity of any type. 
(Ord. of 10-18-05) 
Sec. 70-47. - Lease application. 
Any person that desires to solicit the board of commissioners' approval of a facilities lease pursuant to this article shall file a lease proposal with the county's planning and zoning department which, in addition to the information required by section 70-39, shall include the following: 
(1)  A description of the wireless transmission facilities or other equipment proposed to be located upon county property; 
(2)  A description of the county property upon which the applicant proposes to locate wireless transmission facilities or other equipment; 
(3)  Preliminary plans and specifications in sufficient detail to identify: 
a.  The location(s) of existing wireless transmission or telecommunications facilities or other equipment upon the county's property, whether publicly or privately owned. 
b.  The location and source of electric and other utilities required for the installation and operation of the proposed facilities. 
(4)  Accurate scaled conceptual drawings and diagrams of sufficient specificity to analyze the aesthetic impacts of the proposed wireless transmission facilities or other equipment; 
(5)  Whether the applicant intends to provide cable service, video dialtone service or other video programming service from the facility, and sufficient information to determine whether such service is subject to cable franchising; 
(6)  An accurate map showing the location of any wireless transmission or telecommunications facilities in the county that applicant intends to use or lease; 
(7)  Such other and further information as may be requested by the county; and 
(8)  An application fee for lease negotiation in the amount consistent with fee schedule adopted by the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. of 10-18-05) 
Sec. 70-48. - Determination by the board of commissioners. 
Recognizing that the board of commissioners is under no obligation to grant a facilities lease for the use of county property, the board of commissioners shall strive to consider and take action on application for facilities leases within 60 days after receiving a complete application for such a lease. When such action is taken, the board of commissioners or their designee shall issue a written determination granting or denying the lease in whole or in part, applying the standards set forth below, or any other such criteria as the board of commissioners may choose to apply. If the lease application is denied, the determination shall include the reason for denial following review of these factors: 
(1)  The capacity of the county property and public rights-of-way to accommodate the applicant's proposed facilities. 
(2)  The capacity of the county property and public rights-of-way to accommodate additional utility and wireless transmission or telecommunications facilities if the lease if granted. 
(3)  The damage or disruption, if any, of public or private facilities, improvements, service, travel or landscaping if the lease is granted. 
(4)  The public interest in minimizing the cost and disruption of construction upon county property and within the public ways. 
(5)  The service that applicant will provide to the community and region. The effect, if any, on public health, safety and welfare if the lease requested is approved. The availability of alternate locations for the proposed facilities. 
(6)  Whether the applicant is in compliance with applicable federal and state telecommunications laws, regulations and policies, including, but not limited to, the registration requirements administered by the state public service commission. 
(7)  The potential for radio frequency and other interference with existing public and private telecommunications or other facilities located upon the county property. 
(8)  The potential for radio frequency and other interference or impact upon residential, commercial and other uses located within the vicinity of the county property.
